Such officer shall be charged with the enforcement of all laws and ordinances within the city insofar as their enforcement is within the powers of the city. (Code 1969, § 2-21; Code 1981, § 2-41; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-111. - General duties; residence requirement. It shall be the duty of the city manager to execute and administer the policies, ordinances, rules, and resolutions of the city government as fixed by the city council. During such officer's tenure of office such officer shall reside within the city, and shall devote fulltime to duties as city manager. (Code 1969, § 2-22; Code 1981, § 2-42; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-112. - Assisting council and committees—Making documents available. It shall be the duty of the city manager to make such person's self available, during normal working hours, to the council and the various committees of the council and to furnish them such reports, either oral or written, as they may from time to time require. The city manager shall at all times make available to the committees of the council all of the books, papers, records, maps, plats, vouchers, plans, specifications, and other documents or data concerning any function of the city and shall cause to be made copies thereof for the use of such committee member, as they may require. (Code 1969, § 2-25; Code 1981, § 2-45; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-113. - Same—Inspection tours; availability for advice and consent; calling special meetings; attending meetings. The city manager shall make such inspection tours with the committees of the council as they may require, and shall at all times make such officer's self available to the council or its committees for advice and consent. The city manager shall, at the direction of the mayor or a majority of the council, call a special meeting of the council, and shall attend all regular and special meetings of the same, having with such officer such reports and data as are necessary for prompt understanding of any problem or situation before the city council. (Code 1969, § 2-26; Code 1981, § 2-46; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-114. - Regular employees. The city manager shall hire and discharge all regular employees authorized by the city council to be hired, at such compensation as may be set or authorized by the city council. All employees shall perform their duties subject to the direction of the city manager or that of the superior to whom such manager may assign such employee. Before the city manager shall hire or discharge any regular employee such officer shall first consult with the council committee member in charge of the department for which the employee is to be hired or discharged and shall advise the mayor and city council of their action at the next regular meeting of the council. (Code 1969, § 2-27; Code 1981, § 2-47; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-115. - Examining, etc., contracts. (a) The city manager shall examine all proposed contracts to which the city may be a party, and may sign on behalf of the city any contract authorized by the city council, except where the council directs that some other officers shall do so. (b) It shall be the duty of such manager to see to it that all terms of any contract to which the city is a party are fully performed by all parties thereto. (Code 1969, § 2-29; Code 1981, § 2-48; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-116. - Purchases. (a) The city manager shall be general purchasing agent of the city, and except where specific provision to the contrary is made by law or by the council, the city manager shall make all purchases of supplies, materials and equipment authorized by the council, in the manner prescribed by, and subject to the limitations imposed by law. No purchases shall be made or obligation incurred except upon authorization by the council, and no expense shall be incurred if the amount of the expense is not covered by an unexpended appropriation as required by law. (b) All purchases shall be made according to the purchasing policy as established by the city manager and/or mayor from time to time. Any purchase in excess of $2,000.00 must be made on the requisition of the department head, approved by the city manager and may be made only after the solicitation and receipt of competitive bids, and then only after the approval of the city council. Any expenditure over $200.00 requires the mayor and/or city manager's approval. (Code 1969, § 2-30; Code 1981, § 2-49; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1; Ord. No. 1984-5, § 1, 10-1-1984) Sec. 2-117. - Appropriation and levies. (a) It shall be the duty of the city manager to cause to be prepared each year the annual appropriation ordinance in time for consideration and enactment by the council during the quarter preceding the fiscal year, and to prepare the tax levy ordinance for passage, and file a certified copy thereof with the county tax commissioner. (b) The city manager shall keep current accounts of the amounts appropriated and the amounts spent out of each appropriation, showing the unexpended appropriations at all times. (Code 1969, § 2-31; Code 1981, § 2-50; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-118. - Keeping accounts; collecting money. It shall be the duty of the city manager to keep current accounts showing at all times the fiscal condition of the city, including the current and anticipated expenses, appropriations, cash on hand and anticipated revenue of all municipal funds and accounts; and such officer shall see to the collection of all money due the city. (Code 1969, § 2-32; Code 1981, § 2-51; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-119. - Collection of business licenses. The business license clerk shall be responsible for the collection of all business licenses. (Code 1969, § 2-37; Code 1981, § 2-52; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-120. - Inventories of property. The city manager shall keep a current inventory showing all real and personal property of the city and its locations, and shall be responsible for the care and custody of all such property, including equipment, buildings, parks and all other city property, which is not by law assigned to some other officer or body for care and control. (Code 1969, § 2-33; Code 1981, § 2-53; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-121. - Preparing reports; publications. It shall be the duty of the city manager to see to the publication of all notices, ordinances or other documents required by law to be published, and to prepare or cause to be prepared, all reports which the city or any of the officials thereof are required by law to prepare. (Code 1969, § 2-34; Code 1981, § 2-54; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-122. - Furnishing election materials. The city council, in its discretion, may authorize the city manager to prepare for the city clerk all notices, ballots and election supplies necessary in connection with municipal elections. (Code 1969, § 2-35; Code 1981, § 2-55; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-123. - Records; certificates. The city clerk shall prepare and have custody of all municipal records required by law to be kept by the city and not by a specific officer. Where the law makes it the duty of a specific officer to keep or maintain records the city clerk shall make available to such officer all necessary clerical assistance for the preparation of such records and shall make available a place for the custody of such records. And in compliance herewith, the city clerk shall make available to the clerk, stenographic or clerical assistance necessary for the preparation of the journal of council proceedings, and the record of ordinances and all other documents which by law the clerk is required to keep; and he/she shall perform similar service for the treasurer in the maintenance of bond registers, and all other records or documents which by law the treasurer is required to keep or prepare. (Code 1969, § 2-36; Code 1981, § 2-56; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) State Law reference— Georgia Records Act, O.C.G.A. § 50-18-90 et seq. Sec. 2-124. - Water and sewer department duties. (a) The public works director shall, with the advice and consent of the council committee member for the water and sewer department, prepare such reasonable rules and regulations as are needful for the conduct of the water and sewer department. (b) It shall be the duty of the public works director to keep a running inventory of all pipes, fittings, supplies, machinery, and equipment used in connection with the water and sewer department and to run such cost analyses of the various operations therein conducted as are reasonable and needful for the clear understanding of the operation of such department. (c) The public works director shall be responsible for the collecting of all fees and assessments in connection with sewerage connections and water services as fixed by the council. In the event the city performs a service for a patron of the water or sewer services wherein a fee has not been fixed by the council, the city manager is authorized to fix a reasonable fee for such work done or services performed, collect therefor, and report same to the council at the next regular or special meeting. (d) The public works director may authorize city employees to make regular water and sewer connections at the property line of any patron of either system, but the public works director shall not cause to be run or permit to be run and constructed any sewer line or water line on private property and shall not extend over city property a water line longer than 300 feet or a sewer line longer than 300 feet from then existing facilities, without approval of the water and sewer council committee member. (Code 1969, § 2-37; Code 1981, § 2-57; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-125. - Work on private property; competition with private enterprise; lending equipment. In the absence of direction from the city council by resolution or ordinance, in no event shall the city manager cause city employees to do work of any nature on private property, nor shall the city manager at any time place the city in competition with private enterprise, nor shall the city manager lend or allow the use of city machinery or equipment by third parties. (Code 1969, § 2-38; Code 1981, § 2-58; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Secs. 2-126—2-149. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - CITY CLERK DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 2-150. - Election; term. The city clerk shall be appointed annually by the mayor and council, as provided by the Charter. (Code 1969, § 2-251; Code 1981, § 2-70; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-151. - Bond. Before entering upon the duties of office, the city clerk shall execute a bond in an amount not less than $100,000.00, conditioned upon the faithful performance of such officer's duties. (Code 1969, § 2-252; Code 1981, § 2-71; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-152. - Sealing and attesting documents. The city clerk shall seal and attest all contracts of the city and all licenses, permits and such other documents as shall require this formality. (Code 1969, § 2-253; Code 1981, § 2-72; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-153. - Keeping accounts. The clerk shall keep accounts showing all money received by such officer and the source and disposition thereof; and such other accounts as may be required by the Charter, statute or ordinance. (Code 1969, § 2-255; Code 1981, § 2-74; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-154. - Records. (a) In addition to the record of the proceedings of the council, the record of ordinances and other records which the clerk is required by law to keep, such officer shall keep: (1) A register of all licenses and permits issued and the payments thereon; (2) A record showing all of the officers and regular employees of the city; and (3) Such other records as may be required by the city council. (b) The city clerk is responsible for records management activities, acting for and in behalf of the city in directing and coordinating all records management matters, and records shall be maintained in accordance with approved retention schedules as adopted by the state records committee on March 7, 1983, and as on file with the secretary of state's office. (Code 1969, § 2-256; Code 1981, § 2-75; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1; Res. No. 1983-8, 11-7-1983) Sec. 2-155. - Seal. The clerk shall be the custodian of the city seal, and shall affix its impression on documents whenever this is required. (Code 1969, § 2-257; Code 1981, § 2-76; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-156. - Custodian of documents. The clerk shall be the custodian of all documents belonging to the city which are not assigned to the custody of some other officer. (Code 1969, § 2-258; Code 1981, § 2-77; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-157. - Indexing documents and records. The clerk shall keep and maintain a proper index to all documents and records kept by such officer, so that ready access thereto and use thereof may be had. (Code 1969, § 2-259; Code 1981, § 2-78; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-158. - Additional duties. In addition to the duties herein provided the clerk shall perform such other duties and functions as may be required by the Charter, statute or ordinance. (Code 1969, § 2-260; Code 1981, § 2-79; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Secs. 2-159—2-184. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - DEPUTY CLERK
Sec. 2-185. - Office created; execution of documents. There is hereby created the office of deputy clerk. The city clerk is authorized to appoint a deputy clerk, subject to confirmation by the mayor and city council, who shall have the power and duty to execute all documents required by law or ordinance to be executed by the clerk, and affix the seal of the city thereto whenever required. (Code 1969, § 2-262; Code 1981, § 2-80; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-186. - Signing documents. When signing any documents the deputy clerk shall sign the name of the city clerk followed by the term "by" and the deputy clerk's own name and the term "deputy clerk." (Code 1969, § 2-263; Code 1981, § 2-81; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-187. - Time of authority. (a) The powers and duties herein described shall be exercised by such deputy clerk only in the absence of the city clerk from such city clerk's office in the city hall, and only when either written direction has been given by the city clerk to exercise such power, or the city council has determined by resolution that the city clerk is temporarily or permanently incapacitated to perform such function. (b) Such deputy clerk shall have the authority and power herein described, and such further power and authority as may be provided by law. (Code 1969, § 2-264; Code 1981, § 2-82; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Secs. 2-188—2-212. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - CITY ATTORNEY
Sec. 2-213. - Prosecuting and defending suits. The attorney shall prosecute or defend all suits and actions at law or equity to which the city may be a party, or in which it may be interested, or which may be brought against, or by, any officer of the city on behalf of the city, or in the capacity of such person as an officer of the city. Acting with the advice and consent of the mayor and council, the city attorney shall also have the right to associate other attorneys as the city attorney may deem proper to assist in legal matters affecting the city. The city attorney shall be appointed annually by the mayor and council. (Code 1981, § 2-90; Ord. of 8-19-1974, § b) Sec. 2-214. - Enforcing judgments. It shall be the duty of the city attorney to see to the full enforcement of all judgments or decrees rendered or entered in favor of the city, and of all interlocutory orders. (Code 1981, § 2-91; Ord. of 8-19-1974, § c) Sec. 2-215. - Advising officers; attending council meetings. The city attorney shall be the legal advisor of the city, and shall render advice on all legal questions affecting the city, whenever requested to do so by any city official. Upon request by the mayor or by the city council, the city attorney shall reduce any such opinion to writing. The city attorney shall attend all regular meetings of the council and such special meetings as requested by the mayor or council and shall keep them informed as to the legal matters affecting the city and shall recommend to the council such actions on these matters as may be necessary and expedient for the welfare of the city. (Code 1981, § 2-92; Ord. of 8-19-1974, § d) Sec. 2-216. - Supervising special assessment, bond and condemnation proceedings. It shall be the duty of the city attorney to supervise and to see to the completion of all special assessment proceedings, bond issue proceedings and condemnation proceedings. (Code 1981, § 2-93; Ord. of 8-19-1974, § e) Sec. 2-217. - Drafting documents. It shall be the duty of the city attorney to draft or supervise the phraseology of any contract, lease or other document or instrument, to which the city may be a party; and upon request of the city council, to draft ordinances covering any subjects within the power of the city. (Code 1981, § 2-94; Ord. of 8-19-1974, § f) Sec. 2-218. - Compensation. The city attorney shall receive for such officer's services such retainer fee as the council may authorize. Such fee shall be full compensation for attendance at all regularly held meetings and advisory services at said meetings. For any service not covered by the retainer, the city attorney shall receive such compensation as may be authorized by the city council. (Code 1981, § 2-95; Ord. of 8-19-1974, § g) Sec. 2-219. - Supervising legislation. It shall be the duty of the city attorney to supervise the enactment and passage of ordinances and resolutions and to see that said enactment and passage are in compliance and conformity with the law. (Code 1981, § 2-96; Ord. of 8-19-1974, § h) Sec. 2-220. - Membership in city attorneys' association. Immediately upon appointment of a city attorney, the city manager shall proceed to secure membership in the state city attorneys' association for the city attorney. The city shall bear the cost of said membership. (Code 1981, § 2-97; Ord. of 8-19-1974, § i) Secs. 2-221—2-248. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - FINANCE DEPARTMENT
Sec. 2-249. - Created; composition. There is hereby created the department of finance for the city. This department shall consist of the city clerk and such other officers and employees as may be provided for by the council. (Code 1981, § 2-100; Ord. of 11-11-1974, § 1) Sec. 2-250. - Supervision of employees. There is hereby established the office of treasurer, who shall be appointed by the city council as provided by law. The city manager shall serve as ex officio treasurer unless and until a separate appointment is made to this office. The city clerk shall have control and supervision over all employees assigned to this department, subject to the supervision of the city manager. (Code 1981, § 2-101; Ord. of 11-11-1974, § 2) Sec. 2-251. - Bond. Before entering upon the duties of office, the city clerk shall execute and file a bond in such amount and with such sureties as may be required by the council, conditioned upon the faithful performance of such officer's duties. (Code 1981, § 2-102; Ord. of 11-11-1974, § 3) Sec. 2-252. - Duties as prescribed; receiving and paying out money. The city clerk shall perform such duties as may be prescribed by statute or ordinance. The city clerk shall receive all money paid to the city, either directly from the person paying it or from the hands of such other officer as may receive it, and shall pay out only in vouchers or order properly signed by the city clerk and the mayor or voucher or requisition signed by the city manager. (Code 1981, § 2-103; Ord. of 11-11-1974, § 4) Sec. 2-253. - Depositing of funds. The city clerk shall deposit the city funds in such depositories as may be selected from time to time as is provided by statute, and shall not intermingle such officer's own money with it or make private or personal use of city funds. (Code 1981, § 2-104; Ord. of 11-11-1974, § 5) Sec. 2-254. - Keeping records. The city clerk shall keep such records showing all money received by such officer, the source from which it was received, and the purpose for which it was paid out, and shall keep a record showing at all times the financial status of the city. (Code 1981, § 2-105; Ord. of 11-11-1974, § 6) Sec. 2-255. - Keeping accounts. The city clerk shall keep such books and accounts as may be required by the city council, and shall keep them in the manner required by law. The treasurer shall keep a current account of the amount appropriated each year and the sums spent out of each appropriation showing the encumbered and unexpended balances for each item. The city clerk shall keep accounts showing at all times the fiscal condition of the city, including the current and anticipated revenues, expenses, and encumbrances of all municipal funds and accounts. (Code 1981, § 2-106; Ord. of 11-11-1974, § 7) Sec. 2-256. - Making reports. The city clerk shall make monthly reports to the city manager and council showing the state of the finances of the city, and the amounts received, encumbered and disbursed during the month, which reports shall be filed; and shall make an annual report at the close of the fiscal year with the total amount of all receipts and expenditures of the city and transactions during the preceding year and shall prepare for signature and publication the annual report and any other report required by law. (Code 1981, § 2-107; Ord. of 11-11-1974, § 8) Sec. 2-257. - Estimate of expenses. (a) No later than 45 days before the beginning of each fiscal year, and before the annual appropriation ordinance is prepared, the city clerk shall submit to the city manager a report of such city clerk's estimate, as nearly as may be, of the money necessary to defray the expenses of the city during the next fiscal year. For the purpose of making this report, the city clerk shall require all officers of the city to submit statements of the condition and expenses of their offices or departments; and any proposed improvements and the estimated expense thereof; a statement of all unperformed contracts, and the amount of all unexpended appropriations of the preceding year. (b) The report shall also: (1) Classify the objects and purposes of such estimated expenditures and the amounts required for each; (2) Show the aggregate income of the preceding fiscal year, from all sources; (3) Show the amount of liability on which interest is to be paid; (4) Show the bonds and debts due and payable and the dates when such are due and payable; and (5) Give such other information regarding the financial situation of the city as the city manager may require. (Code 1981, § 2-108; Ord. of 11-11-1974, § 9) Sec. 2-258. - Ex officio city collector. The city clerk shall be ex officio city collector and shall perform the following duties: (1) Preserve all warrants returned to such officer. (2) Keep such books and accounts as the city council or city manager may direct. (3) Keep all warrants, books, vouchers and papers pertaining to the office of collector open for the inspection of the mayor, or any member or committee of the city council. (4) At the close of the fiscal year, the city clerk shall place on file with the city council a statement of all money collected by such treasurer during the year, the particular warrant, or special assessment or account on which collected, the balance of money uncollected on all warrants in such city clerk's possession, and the balance remaining on all warrants during the preceding fiscal year, and shall cause such statement to be published as provided by statute. (Code 1981, § 2-109; Ord. of 11-11-1974, § 10) Sec. 2-259. - Register of warrants. The city clerk shall keep a record of all warrants or orders filed with such officer or paid by such officers and all vouchers as is required by statute. (Code 1981, § 2-110; Ord. of 11-11-1974, § 11) Sec. 2-260. - Register of bonds. The city clerk shall keep in such city clerk's office in books used solely for that purpose, a correct list of all the outstanding bonds of the city, showing the number and amount of each, and for whom and to whom the bonds were issued. The city clerk shall also show therein when any city bonds are purchased, paid or cancelled, and shall show, in the annual report the bonds sold during the year, the terms of such sale and every item of expense incurred therewith. (Code 1981, § 2-111; Ord. of 11-11-1974, § 12) Sec. 2-261. - Special assessments. The city clerk shall keep all money received on any special assessment in a separate fund, to be applied to the payment of the improvement for which the assessment was made, and the money shall be used for no other purposes, except to reimburse the city for money expended for such improvement. (Code 1981, § 2-112; Ord. of 11-11-1974, § 13) Sec. 2-262. - Additional duties and powers. The city clerk shall perform such additional duties and have such additional powers as the council may by ordinance or resolution confer upon such officer or which the city manager may delegate to such officer. (Code 1981, § 2-113; Ord. of 11-11-1974, § 14) Secs. 2-263—2-287. - Reserved. ARTICLE VIII. - POLICE DEPARTMENT
Sec. 2-288. - Created; composition. There is hereby created a police department for the city which shall consist of the chief of police, who shall be ex officio superintendent of police, and such other members as may be provided for by the council. (Code 1981, § 2-120; Ord. of 10-7-1974, § a) Sec. 2-289. - Chain of command. Levels of rank and authority may be created as needed at the discretion of the chief of police. Job descriptions and authority will be assigned for each position created. (Code 1981, § 2-121; Ord. of 10-7-1974, § b) Sec. 2-290. - Appointments and promotions. The chief of police shall be appointed by the council. All other appointments to or promotions within the department shall be made as provided by law. (Code 1981, § 2-122; Ord. of 10-7-1974, § c) Sec. 2-291. - Records and reports; supervision of department. The chief of police shall keep such records and make such reports concerning the activities of the department as may be required by statute or by the city council or by the city manager. The chief shall be responsible for the performance by the police department of its functions, and all persons who are members of the police department shall serve subject to the orders of the chief of police. (Code 1981, § 2-123; Ord. of 10-7-1974, § d) Sec. 2-292. - Responsibility of chief of police. The chief of police shall be specifically charged with the supervision of all members of the department and shall be held strictly responsible for the conduct and efficiency of all such members for the general good order of the department, and shall be responsible to the mayor and the city council and the city manager. The chief shall have regular hours of duty during each working day. The chief shall have a thorough knowledge of all sections of the city, and when going on duty shall immediately familiarize such officer's self with all police business transacted since such officer's last tour of duty. It shall be the duty of the chief to inform the commanding officer coming on duty of all important matters which may require attention. The chief shall diligently inquire into all complaints and charges of laxity and misconduct in the performance of duty by members under such officer's command and shall take such steps as set forth in these rules and regulations, or as such officer may deem necessary when not in conflict with these rules and regulations. (1) The chief of police in the exercise of such officer's duties shall have the power to establish and enforce rules and regulations for the government of the members and employees of the department, which rules shall, however, be consistent with the ordinances of the city and the laws of the state. (2) It shall be the duty of the chief of police to cause the public peace to be preserved and to enforce all ordinances of the city of which the police department must take cognizance. The chief of police shall receive and give proper attention to complaints for all persons referred to such officer and perform such other duties as may be required from time to time as prescribed by the rules and regulations. (3) The chief of police shall have full power and authority to reprimand any member of the police department, and to file charges against any member of the police department with the city manager or city council for a hearing, for nonconformance with these rules and regulations. (4) The chief of police shall have custody and control of all books, records, machines, tools, apparatus or equipment of every kind necessary for the use of the department. (5) Further, all the rules and regulations set forth in sections 2-293 through 2-295 which are applicable to the members of the police department are also applicable to the chief of police. (Code 1981, § 2-124; Ord. of 10-7-1974, § 1) Sec. 2-293. - Rules and regulations—Promulgation. The city manager or chief of police may make or prescribe such rules and regulations as shall be deemed advisable; such rules, when approved by the city council, shall be binding on such members. Such rules and regulations may cover, besides the conduct of the members, uniforms and equipment to be worn or carried, hours of service, vacations and all other similar matters necessary or desirable for the better efficiency of the department. (Code 1981, § 2-125; Ord. of 10-7-1974, § i) Sec. 2-294. - Same—Posting. Rules and regulations shall be posted in the police department quarters. (Code 1981, § 2-126; Ord. of 10-7-1974, § 32) Sec. 2-295. - Same—Other laws; enforcement of rules. (a) In addition to the rules and regulations set forth in this section and sections 2-293 and 2-294 as established by the city manager and the city council, the laws of the state, ordinances of the city, and federal laws pertaining to and affecting police officers shall be the governing factors in the conduct of all members of the police department, who shall at all times be subject to the same. (b) It shall be the duty of the chief of police and the city manager to enforce the rules and regulations. (c) A copy of the rules and regulations shall be delivered as promptly as possible by the chief of police to each member of the police department. (Code 1981, § 2-127; Ord. of 10-7-1974, § 36) Sec. 2-296. - Special police officers. Any person of good character having duties which require it may be appointed a special police officer by the mayor, provided that, except upon authorization by council, no such special police officer shall be entitled to any compensation from the city, nor shall such special police officer be considered an employee of the city by reason of such appointment. Special police officers shall obey all rules of the police department applicable to them and may be removed from their position by the chief at any time. (Code 1981, § 2-128; Ord. of 10-7-1974, § j) Sec. 2-297. - General duties of members. It shall be the duty of the members of the police department to see to the enforcement of all of the ordinances of the city and all statutes applicable therein; and to preserve order and prevent infractions of the law and arrest violators thereof. (Code 1981, § 2-130; Ord. of 10-7-1974, § 3) Sec. 2-298. - Serving process. No member of the police department, except the chief, shall serve any process except on command of the chief of police. (Code 1981, § 2-132; Ord. of 10-7-1974, § f) Sec. 2-299. - Appearing as witnesses. Every member of the police department shall appear as witnesses whenever it is necessary in a prosecution for a violation of an ordinance or of any state or federal law. No such members shall retain any witness fee for service as witness in any action or suit to which the city is a party; any fees paid for such services shall be turned over to the chief of police, who shall deposit the same with the city treasurer or proper official. (Code 1981, § 2-133; Ord. of 10-7-1974, § h) Sec. 2-300. - False reports. No member of the department shall knowingly make a misstatement or make a false report. (Code 1981, § 2-138; Ord. of 10-7-1974, § 10) Sec. 2-301. - Care of equipment. (a) Members and employees of the police department shall be responsible for the good care of department property whether fixed or movable, assigned to their use or keeping, and shall promptly report to their commanding officers the loss or damage to, or unserviceable condition of such property. Roughness or carelessness in the handling of such property will not be tolerated and will be made the subject of charges of superior officers who will be responsible for the strict enforcement of this rule. (b) Any member found guilty of damages to or destruction of property, either through willfulness or negligence, shall be required to pay all costs of repairs or replacements thereto, besides suffering any penalty for the violation of this section. (Code 1981, § 2-143; Ord. of 10-7-1974, § 16) Sec. 2-302. - Lost equipment. All members of the department shall immediately report to the chief of police the loss of any city equipment that has been furnished to the individual. (Code 1981, § 2-144; Ord. of 10-7-1974, § 17) Sec. 2-303. - Contraband; lost, stolen or abandoned property—Custody. The chief of police shall have the custody of all lost, abandoned or stolen property and contraband recovered in the city. The council shall direct the deposition of all such property and no such property may be removed, sold or destroyed except upon direction of the council. (Code 1981, § 2-148; Ord. of 10-7-1974, § k) Sec. 2-304. - Same—Disposition by officers. It shall be the duty of all officers, upon the finding or recovery of any contraband, abandoned vehicle or other abandoned property or stolen property, to bring such vehicle or property to the police station, placing such vehicle or property in the care of the chief of police. (Code 1981, § 2-149; Ord. of 10-7-1974, § 27) Sec. 2-305. - Accepting rewards or presents—Reward for services in line of duty; condition to acceptance. No member of the department shall receive or accept any reward from any person for any services rendered in the line of his/her duty. However, as to all rewards received for members of the department, where the individual has contributed outstanding work in the recovery of property, etc., a written report thereof will be made to the secretary of the city council outlining the case in question and submitting the reward to the city council to be acted upon by it. (Code 1981, § 2-150; Ord. of 10-7-1974, § 28) Sec. 2-306. - Same—Gifts or presents. No member of the police department shall accept any fee, reward or gift of any kind, from persons arrested or from any friend in such arrested person's behalf while such person is in custody, or after release or discharge. Members of the department shall not accept presents or gifts from other members of the department, groups, clubs, associations, societies, citizens, lodges or political parties. Members of the department shall not solicit contributions for a fund for the purposes of presenting other members of the department with a gift, unless authorized by the chief of police. (Code 1981, § 2-151; Ord. of 10-7-1974, § 29) Sec. 2-307. - Same—Permission. The chief of police, for meritorious service rendered by any member of the police force in the due discharge of duty, may permit such member to retain for such member's own benefit, so far as may be permitted by law, any reward or present tendered therefor, and it shall be cause of removal for any member of the force to receive any such reward or present without notice thereof to the city council and without the city council's permission. (Code 1981, § 2-152; Ord. of 10-7-1974, § m) Secs. 2-308—2-334. - Reserved. ARTICLE IX. - FIRE DEPARTMENT DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 2-335. - Created; composition; appointments. There is created a fire department, consisting of a chief, and such other members as may from time to time be provided for the city council. Members shall be appointed in the manner provided by law. (Code 1981, § 2-160; Ord. of 10-7-1974, § a) Sec. 2-336. - Function. It shall be the function and duty of the fire department and every member thereof to extinguish accidental or destructive fires and to prevent the occurrence or spread of such fires. (Code 1981, § 2-161; Ord. of 10-7-1974, § f) Sec. 2-337. - Supervision by fire chief. The fire chief shall have the control, subject to the order and direction of the city manager or council, of the fire department and all fire apparatus belonging to the city. The fire chief shall see to maintenance and repair of all fire equipment and apparatus and shall cause the same to be done without delay. (Code 1981, § 2-162; Ord. of 10-7-1974, § b) Sec. 2-338. - Command at fires. In case of fire, the fire chief and the chief's assistants shall rank in the order named and the officer of the highest rank at the fire shall take command of the fire department, and direct the management thereof for the suppression of the fire in the best manner possible; and when it may be necessary for the protection of other property and to prevent the spread of the conflagration, the officer in command may cause buildings to be removed, torn down or destroyed in the best manner possible. (Code 1981, § 2-163; Ord. of 10-7-1974, § c) Sec. 2-339. - Keeping records; annual report. The fire chief shall keep or cause to be kept a record of all meetings of the company and the attendance of the members, a record of all fires and, annually, file with the city clerk a full report of such records and attendance and fires, which report shall be under oath. (Code 1981, § 2-164; Ord. of 10-7-1974, § d) Sec. 2-340. - Service outside corporate limits. Members of the fire department are authorized to go outside the corporate limits of the city for the purpose of rendering aid in the case of accidents; provided, the fire department shall not render such service outside the corporate limits except upon orders of the mayor, city manager, chief of the fire department or assistant chief. However, where the city has undertaken by contract to render service to property outside the corporate limits the fire department may leave the corporate limits in the fulfillment of such contract. (Code 1981, § 2-166; Ord. of 10-7-1974, § j) Secs. 2-341—2-368. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - MUTUAL AID
Sec. 2-369. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Aiding municipality means a municipality furnishing fire equipment to a stricken municipality, or to another aiding municipality. Municipality means a city, town, village or incorporated fire protection district. Mutual fire aid program means a plan or program as provided for herein whereby the municipalities participating in the program agree to come to one another's assistance in case of fire or other disaster too large for local equipment and personnel to handle. Participating municipality means a municipality that participates in the mutual fire aid program by adopting an ordinance authorizing or approving the program and entering into an appropriate agreement (substantially as provided herein) with other participating municipalities for rendering and receiving aid in case of fire or other disaster. Stricken municipality means a participating municipality in which a fire or other disaster occurs that is of such magnitude that it cannot be adequately coped with by local firefighting equipment and personnel. (Code 1981, § 2-167; Ord. of 10-7-1974, § 1) Sec. 2-370. - Agreement to effectuate program. The chief of the fire department of this city, or the city manager, with the approval of the city council, is authorized on behalf of the city to enter into (and from time to time alter and amend) an agreement with any or all of the municipalities in the mutual aid area defining and putting into effect a mutual aid program providing generally, as follows: (1) In the event that, in the judgment of the officer in charge of the fire department of a stricken municipality, the available firefighting equipment of that municipality is inadequate to effectively cope with a fire or other disaster therein, said officer may call on a neighboring participating municipality to furnish firefighting equipment and personnel (to the extent specified in the agreement) to the stricken municipality, for use, either: a. In combating the fire or other casualty; or b. As a standby reserve to meet other calls that may occur before the local firefighting equipment is free to take care of them. (2) Each aiding municipality furnishing firefighting equipment to a stricken municipality shall have the right to call on another participating municipality for firefighting equipment and personnel (to the extent specified in the agreement) as a standby reserve to take the place, in part, of the equipment furnished to the stricken municipality until such equipment shall be returned. (3) On receipt of a call under subsection (1) or (2) of this section, the aiding municipality called upon shall (to the extent provided in the agreement) furnish the equipment and personnel called for by the stricken municipality, or by the first aiding municipality except that each aiding municipality may always be permitted to retain sufficient firefighting equipment and personnel to fight any fire or to meet any emergency within its own boundaries that may reasonably be anticipated. (Code 1981, § 2-168; Ord. of 10-7-1974, § 2) Sec. 2-371. - Preparation. The chiefs of the fire departments of the municipalities participating in such mutual aid shall prepare a mutual aid program which shall incorporate the necessary provisions. Such mutual aid program shall, after approval by the corporate authorities of the municipalities participating, be in full force and effect and binding on such participating communities. (Code 1981, § 2-169; Ord. of 10-7-1974, § 3) Sec. 2-372. - Obligation of the city. The city shall furnish firefighting equipment and personnel for use outside its boundaries, as provided in the mutual fire aid program as provided for herein, to any municipality that has agreed to conform to said program and has assumed the obligations imposed upon it thereby. (Code 1981, § 2-170; Ord. of 10-7-1974, § 4) Secs. 2-373—2-402. - Reserved. ARTICLE X. - PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT
Sec. 2-403. - Created; composition. There is hereby created the department of public works for the city. This department shall consist of the director of public works and such other officers and employees as may be provided by the council. (Code 1969, § 2-301; Code 1981, § 2-180; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-404. - Office of director of public works created; appointment; ex officio director; control of department. There is hereby created the office of director of public works, who shall be appointed by the city council. The city manager shall serve as ex officio director of public works until this office is filled by appointment. The director shall have control and supervision over all officers and employees assigned to the department subject to the control of the city manager. (Code 1969, § 2-302; Code 1981, § 2-181; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-405. - Duties of director. (a) The director of public works shall have charge of and supervision over all public property of the city, including all streets, parks, parkways, sidewalks, municipal buildings and all other property of the city not specifically assigned to some other officer. (b) The director shall have charge of, and be responsible for the care, maintenance and operation of the city water distribution system; the sanitary sewer system and disposal plant; the street lighting system and all streets and sidewalks and the drainage thereof. (c) All construction, repair or extension of any pavement, building, sewer or lighting system, water mains, and any appurtenances thereto, and all other construction, repair or maintenance work conducted by the city, shall be done by or under the supervision of the director of public works unless specified direction to the contrary is made by the city council. (d) The director of public works shall have charge and custody of all physical property of the city, other than records, not assigned to some other officer or employee, subject to the supervision of the city manager. (Code 1969, § 2-303; Code 1981, § 2-182; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-406. - Maintenance of city buildings. The director of public works shall have care and custody of all city owned buildings, and shall see to it that the same are kept in good order and repair. (Code 1969, § 2-304; Code 1981, § 2-183; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-407. - Construction and maintenance of streets and drains. The director of public works shall have charge of the construction and care of all public streets, sidewalks, alleys, and driveways in the city, and with the keeping of the same clean. The director shall see to it that all gutters and drains therein function properly and that the same are kept free from defects. (Code 1969, § 2-305; Code 1981, § 2-184; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-408. - Maintenance of drainage systems. The director of public works shall have charge and custody of storm sewer and surface water drainage systems of the city, and shall see to it that the same are kept in good repair and that they function properly. (Code 1969, § 2-306; Code 1981, § 2-185; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-409. - Erection and maintenance of traffic markings. The director of public works shall have charge of the construction, erection, maintenance and care of all traffic control signals, signs and street markings. The director shall see to it that all signs and markings are placed as directed by the police chief or the city manager. (Code 1969, § 2-307; Code 1981, § 2-186; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-410. - Construction and maintenance of waterworks. The director of public works shall have charge of the construction, maintenance, repair and operation of the water distribution system of the city, and of all intakes, wells, reservoirs, mains, hydrants, meters and other appurtenances thereto. (Code 1969, § 2-308; Code 1981, § 2-187; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-411. - Construction and maintenance of sanitary sewers. The director of public works shall have charge of the construction, maintenance, repair and operation of the sanitary sewer collection, treatment and disposal system of the city, and of all collector lines, manholes, pumping stations, treatment facilities and other appurtenance thereto. (Code 1969, § 2-309; Code 1981, § 2-188; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-412. - Construction and maintenance of cemetery, parks and parkways. (a) The director of public works shall have charge of the construction, maintenance, operation and improvement of the city cemeteries, parks and parkway. (b) The director's duties shall not include location and designation of cemetery lots. However, the director shall have the duty of supervising and inspecting all improvements made in the cemetery by private firms, including the installation and erection of vaults, monuments, coping, headstones, markers, greenery and landscaping. The director shall: (1) Have charge of the care and upkeep of all city-owned parks; (2) See that the parks are kept in a clean and sanitary condition; and (3) Report to the city manager when any park buildings need repair. (c) The director shall see to it that all play areas and facilities are kept in a clean and sanitary condition. (Code 1969, § 2-310; Code 1981, § 2-189; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-413. - Installation and maintenance of street lighting. The director of public works shall have charge of the installation, maintenance, repair and operation of the street lighting system of the city and all appurtenances thereto. (Code 1969, § 2-311; Code 1981, § 2-190; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-414. - Maintenance of solid waste disposal service. The director of public works shall have charge of the maintenance, repair and operation of the city solid waste collection and disposal service. Solid waste shall include all garbage, rubbish, refuse, trash, debris, junk, discarded household goods, white goods, junk or abandoned vehicles, leaves, limbs and other items as the council may designate. The director shall designate collection routes and schedules of collections in order to provide the level and regularity of service as provided by the council. (Code 1969, § 2-312; Code 1981, § 2-191; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-415. - Custody and care of equipment. The director of public works shall also have charge of and be responsible for the condition of all motor vehicles, trucks and other equipment of the city assigned to the department of public works, and of all buildings or places in which the same are housed or kept. (Code 1969, § 2-313; Code 1981, § 2-192; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-416. - Custody and care of shop. The director of public works shall have charge of and be responsible for the operation and care of the city shop, and of the buildings, equipment, special tools, inventory and goods stored and personnel which are provided for the operation thereof. (Code 1969, § 2-314; Code 1981, § 2-193; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-417. - Establishing departmental rules and regulations, equipment, etc., standards. (a) The director of public works, shall establish rules and regulations for the operation of the public works department as such director deems necessary; upon council approval these rules and regulations shall be binding upon all employees. (b) The director shall, where possible, establish sets of standards and specifications to control construction, operation, maintenance, repairs and purchases of the department by the city, and shall prepare and recommend to the city manager or, if appropriate, the city council such standards as to quality, size and variety of articles, equipment, supplies and materials used by the public works department as will make possible uniform operations and purchasing when consistent with efficiency and good service. (Code 1969, § 2-315; Code 1981, § 2-194; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Sec. 2-418. - Work on private property; competition with private enterprise; lending equipment. In the absence of direction by the city manager and except as authorized by the abatement of nuisance provisions or by any other provisions of this Code, in no event shall the director of public works cause city employees or city equipment to do work of any nature on private property, nor shall the director at any time place the city in competition with private enterprise, nor shall the director lend or allow the use of city machinery or equipment by third parties. (Code 1969, § 2-316; Code 1981, § 2-195; Ord. of 5-16-1977, § 1) Secs. 2-419—2-449. - Reserved. ARTICLE XI. - CODE ENFORCEMENT DEPARTMENT
Sec. 2-450. - Created; composition. There is hereby created the code enforcement department of the city. This department shall consist of the code enforcement officer and such other officers and employees as may be provided for by the city council. (Code 1981, § 2-200; Ord. of 11-11-1974, § 1) Sec. 2-451. - Office of code enforcement officer; city manager ex officio officer until appointment; supervision of employees. The city council shall appoint the code enforcement officer on an annual basis. The city manager shall serve as ex officio code enforcement officer unless or until the office is filled by appointment. The code enforcement officer shall have control and supervision over all employees assigned to the code enforcement department, subject to the control of the city manager. Reference in this Code or any code adopted herein to building inspector or building official shall be deemed to refer to the code enforcement officer. (Code 1969, § 5-1; Code 1981, § 2-201; Ord. of 11-11-1974, § 2) Sec. 2-452. - Enforcing laws; making inspections; issuing permits. The code enforcement officer shall enforce all laws and ordinances in the city relating to the construction, repair, alteration or reinspection of buildings or structures, and the use of streets or parkways in connection therewith, and other matters assigned to such officer, and shall make or cause to be made all inspections needed for that purpose. The code enforcement officer shall issue or cause to be issued all proper permits for such work after payment of the fees required therefor to the city clerk. If the positions of plumbing inspector, electrical inspector, mechanical inspector, or other such inspectors, are provided for, they shall be assigned to the code enforcement department. (Code 1969, § 5-3; Code 1981, § 2-202; Ord. of 11-11-1974, § 3) Sec. 2-453. - Enforcement of zoning and subdivision ordinances. The code enforcement officer shall be the zoning enforcement officer of the city and shall see to the enforcement of the zoning ordinances and subdivision regulations (chapters 78 and 94). (Code 1981, § 2-203; Ord. of 11-11-1974, § 4)

div.head: Chapter 6 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES
div.p:
FOOTNOTE(S): --- (1) --- State Law reference— Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Code, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-1 et seq.; authority to adopt rules and regulations relating to manufacture, sale and distribution of distilled spirits, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-49. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 6-1. - Definitions. The definitions set forth in O.C.G.A. § 3-1-2 (Alcoholic Beverages; General Provisions; Definitions), shall be effective as definitions of the words, terms and phrases used in this chapter. All words, terms and phrases used herein, other than those specifically defined elsewhere in this chapter, shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them in O.C.G.A. § 3-1-2, and shall have the same scope and effect that the same words, terms and phrases have where used in O.C.G.A. § 3-1-2. Sec. 6-2. - Retail license required. Each retail dealer of malt beverages, wines or spirituous liquors, as such terms are defined under state law, who does business within this city shall be required to obtain a license from the city clerk in the manner specified in this chapter. (Code 1969, § 3-20; Code 1981, § 3-1; Ord. of 5-15-1978, § 1) Sec. 6-3. - Wholesale beer license and payment of tax prerequisite to doing business. It is unlawful for any person to engage in the business of wholesaling malt beverages within the city without first obtaining the license from the city clerk and paying the required license tax. (Code 1969, § 3-20; Code 1981, § 3-2) Sec. 6-4. - License application, personnel statement—Required. (a) Each applicant for either a new or renewal licenses as a retail dealer of spirituous liquors shall submit an application for license upon a form approved by the council. Said application shall be complete in every detail and shall be accompanied by the appropriate license fee. If the application is for a new license or transfer of an existing license to a new owner or a different location, the application shall be submitted to the clerk who shall submit the same to council for consideration under the guidelines set forth under this chapter. The council shall consider the application at its next regular meeting which occurs no less than five days subsequent to the application being submitted. If the application is for a renewal license with no change of ownership and no change of location, the application must be submitted to the clerk prior to December 1 of the year preceding the year for which the application is made. The clerk shall review said application and if there are no changes in ownership or location, then the clerk shall issue a license for the coming calendar year to said applicant. All application shall be accompanied by a verified personnel statement for said applicant. (b) Each applicant for either a new or renewal licenses as a retail dealer of malt beverages and wines shall submit an application for license upon a form approved by the council. Said application shall be complete in every detail and shall be accompanied by the appropriate license fee. If the application is for a new license or transfer of an existing license to a new owner or a different location, the application shall be submitted to the clerk who shall review the same under the guidelines set forth under this chapter and issue said license if the application meets the guidelines. If the application is for a renewal license with no change of ownership and no change of location, the application must be submitted to the clerk prior to December 1 of the year preceding the year for which the application is made. The clerk shall review said application and if there are no changes in ownership or location, then the clerk shall issue a license for the coming calendar year to said applicant. (Code 1981, § 3-3; Ord. of 5-15-1978, § 3; Ord. No. 1992-2, 9-21-1992; Ord. No. 2008-9, § 1, 3-18-2002) Sec. 6-5. - Same—Misstatement or concealment of material fact. Any misstatement or concealment of a material fact in the application or verified personnel statement required by this chapter by the licensee or any employee or any director or officer of any corporation shall be grounds for the revocation of the license issued under this chapter. (Code 1981, § 3-4; Ord. of 5-15-1978, § 24) Sec. 6-6. - License fees—Schedule. The annual business license fee for retail dealers whose place of business is located within the city shall be as established by the city council from time to time. (Code 1981, § 3-5; Ord. of 5-15-1978, § 2) Sec. 6-7. - Same—Payment; fee to defray investigative and administrative cost. Each application for initial license or transfer of an existing license, excluding renewals, under this chapter shall be accompanied by a certified check for the full amount of the license fee, together with a separate check or cash, to defray investigative and administrative costs. If the application is denied and the license refused, or if the applicant withdraws the application prior to its being submitted to the council, the deposit representing the license fee shall be refunded, but the cost paid for investigation shall be retained. The amount of the fee to defray the license investigation and administrative costs shall be as established by the city council from time to time. (Code 1981, § 3-6; Ord. of 5-15-1978, § 11) Sec. 6-8. - Factors for council consideration. The council, in passing upon an initial application for a license or a transfer of an existing license shall be guided by the following factors as to whether to grant or deny such application: (1) The proximity of other establishments selling malt beverages, wines or spirituous liquors to the proposed location; (2) The character of the neighborhood immediately adjacent to the proposed location; (3) The proximity of churches, schools and playgrounds to the proposed location; (4) Whether the proposed location has adequate off-street parking facilities or other parking available for its patrons; (5) Whether the location would tend to increase and promote traffic congestion and resulting hazards therefrom; (6) Whether any similar license previously issued for such location was ever revoked for cause by the city council; and (7) Whether the applicant has ever sold malt beverages, wine or spirituous liquors illegally. (Code 1969, § 3-1; Code 1981, § 3-7; Ord. of 5-15-1978, § 4) Sec. 6-9. - Licensee—Qualifications. (a) It shall be unlawful to issue a license for the retail sale of spirituous liquors to: (1) A person who is not a resident of the county for a period of 12 months prior to such person's making application. (2) A person who is not a citizen of the United States. (3) A person disqualified under section 6-10. (4) A partnership, unless all partners qualify under this chapter and subsections (a)(1), (2) and (3) of this section. (5) A corporation, unless all shareholders, officers and directors qualify under this chapter and subsections (a)(1), (2) and (3) of this section. (6) A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent unless said manager or agent possesses the same qualifications as a licensee. (7) Any law enforcing public official or employee or elected public official of the city. (b) It shall be unlawful to issue a license for the retail sale of malt beverages and wine to: (1) A person who is not a resident of the state. (2) A person who is not a citizen of the United States. (3) A person disqualified under section 6-10. (4) A partnership, unless all partners qualify under this chapter and subsection (b)(2) and (3) of this section. (5) A corporation, if any officer, manager or director thereof, or any stockholder owning 25 percent or more of the stock of such corporation, would not be eligible to receive an alcoholic beverage license hereunder section 6-10. (6) A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent unless said manager or agent possesses the same qualifications as a licensee. (7) Any law enforcing public official or employee or elected public official of the city. (Code 1981, § 3-8; Ord. of 5-15-1978, § 14; Ord. No. 1990-1, § 1, 3-5-1990; Ord. No. 2008-9, § 2, 3-18-2002) Sec. 6-10. - Same—Moral character; criminal record. In no event shall any license be granted to any person or officer or director of any such corporation who has been convicted or has plead guilty or entered a plea of nolo contendere to any crime involving moral turpitude, lottery or illegal possession or sale of narcotics or other controlled substances, within a period of ten years immediately prior to the filing of such application, nor shall any such person sell spirituous liquors, malt beverages or wine. Should any applicant's partner, officer or employee engaged in the sale of spirituous liquors, malt beverages or wine, after a license has been granted, be convicted or plead guilty or nolo contendere to a crime involving moral turpitude or the violation of any laws regulating the sale of narcotics, or other controlled substances, liquor, wine or beer, or the lottery laws of the state, such license shall be instantly revoked and cancelled. (Code 1969, § 3-21; Code 1981, § 3-9; Ord. of 5-15-1978, § 22) Sec. 6-11. - Qualifications of manager or agent. The manager or agent of any place of business shall be required to possess the same qualifications as a licensee; and the licensee shall be responsible for the manager or agent making application on a form furnished by the city and being approved before beginning such duties. (Code 1981, § 3-10; Ord. of 5-15-1978, § 17) Sec. 6-12. - License expiration and renewal. All licenses granted hereunder shall expire on December 31 of each year. Licensees who desire to renew their license shall file an application with the city clerk on the form provided by the council for the renewal of the license for the ensuing year. Application for renewal must be filed before December 1 of each year; otherwise, no renewal license shall be granted, but an application for renewal, in the event that it is not timely filed, shall be treated as an initial application, and the applicant shall be required to comply with all the rules and regulations for the granting of licenses as if no previous license had been held. All licenses granted hereunder shall be for the calendar year and the full license fee must be paid for a license issued at any time during a calendar year except for the transfer of an existing license. The requisite license fee shall be paid to the business license clerk. (Code 1981, § 3-11; Ord. of 5-15-1978, § 12) Sec. 6-13. - Transfer of license—Conditions. A license for the retail sale of malt beverages, wine or spirituous liquors shall not be transferable to another person or location without the expressed consent of the city council under the guidelines set forth under sections 6-4, 6-8 through 6-10, 6-14 and 6-21. The transfer of an existing license shall not require the payment of an additional license fee. (Code 1981, § 3-12; Ord. of 5-15-1978, § 5) Sec. 6-14. - Same—Change of ownership. (a) Nothing in this chapter shall prohibit one or more of the partners in a partnership holding a license or one or more of the shareholders in a corporation holding a license to withdraw from the partnership or corporation in favor of one or more of the other partners or shareholders, who were partners or shareholders at the time of the issuance of the license. However, such a withdrawal shall not serve to bring any new ownership into the partnership or corporation. (b) Where a transfer of an existing store location is approved and there is no change in the ownership of the business, the license fee paid for the old location shall be applied to the new location. (c) A licensee may take in partners of additional stockholders. Under this section, an additional partner or new stockholder must be approved by the city council, in accordance with the requirements of this chapter, and a new license must be obtained, but said license will be issued without the payment of a new license fee. (Code 1981, § 3-13; Ord. of 5-15-1978, § 13) Sec. 6-15. - Consumption on the premises. (a) No malt beverages or wine shall be sold for consumption on the premises except in an establishment which derives at least 75 percent of its total annual gross food and beverage sales from the sale of prepared meals or food and which is located within a proper zoning district. (b) Any establishment where malt beverages or wine is sold for consumption on the premises shall have a seating capacity of 40 persons, excluding stools and counters. (1) Premises. No malt beverage or wine license shall be issued to any person unless the building in which the business will be located is complete and detailed plans of the building and outside premises are attached to the application, or unless proposed plans and specifications and a building permit of a proposed building to be built are attached to the application. The completed building or the proposed building shall comply with ordinances of the city, regulations of the state revenue commissioner and the state. The proposed building shall also be subject to final inspection and approval when completed by the building inspector. Each building in which the business will be located shall contain sufficient lighting so that the building itself and the premises on all sides of the building are readily visible at all times from the front of the street on which the building is located so as to reveal all of the outside premises of such building. Each applicant for a malt beverage and wine license shall attach to the application evidence of ownership of the building or proposed building or a copy of the lease if the applicant is leasing the building. If the applicant is a franchisee, then such applicant shall attach a copy of the franchise agreement or contract with the application. All premises for which a malt beverage or wine license shall be issued shall afford therein adequate sanitary toilet facilities and shall be adequately illuminated so that all hallways, passageways and open areas may be clearly seen by the customers therein. (2) Open area and patio sales. (3) Malt beverage and wine sales can be made by a licensed consumption on-premises establishment in a patio/open area type environment if the establishment has been approved to do so by the mayor and city council. (4) The requirement for approval is that the patio/open area be enclosed by some structure providing for public ingress/egress only through the main licensed premises. The purpose of this requirement is to prevent a customer from leaving the outside sales area with an open drink without the licensee's knowledge. (5) The height of such structure shall be a minimum of four feet above ground level. It does not have to be solid nor does it have to restrict visibility into and out of the patio/open sales area. It must be permitted and approved by the city's building inspection department and all other applicable governing regulations or codes. (6) The only exit from this type area is to be through the licensed establishment's main premises and through an approved fire exit (not for general public use unless an emergency exists). The fire exit should be of the type that sounds an alarm so that the establishment will be alerted in the event of unauthorized use when no emergency exists. (7) If a licensee desires a patio/open sales area inside an existing structure, plans will be reviewed and approved on an individual basis by the mayor and city council. Interior type patio/open sales areas must also meet the requirements of the city's development and fire codes. (8) Nothing contained in this section shall prohibit a hotel or motel with a on-premises consumption license from making sales and allowing consumption of malt beverages and wine in ballrooms, meeting rooms, reception rooms, or patio areas of such hotel or motel provided such functions are catered in connection with a meeting, conference, convention or similar type gathering at such hotel or motel. (9) No outside consumption. (10) It is prohibited for customers to leave the premises with open beer or wine beverages and it is the licensee's responsibility to ensure that no open beverages are sold and carried out. (11) It is prohibited for customers to gather outside a malt beverage and/or wine establishment and consume beer and/or wine. (12) It is prohibited for the manager or any employee to allow persons to gather outside a beer and wine establishment and consume a malt beverage or wine. (13) Noise from establishments prohibited. Noise will not be allowed that can be heard outside the physical boundaries of establishments licensed under this chapter. (14) Types of entertainment, attire and conduct prohibited. The following types of entertainment, attire and conduct are not permitted upon any premises licensed to sell, serve or dispense beer or wine or upon any premises licensed under the business and occupational ordinances of the city in which malt beverages and/or wine are consumed, allowed or dispensed on the premises: a. The employment or use of any person, in any capacity, in the sale or service of beer and/or wine while such person is unclothed or in such attire, costume or clothing as to expose to view any portion of the female breast below the top of the areola or of any portion of the pubic hair, anus, cleft of the buttocks, vulva or genitals; or b. The holding, promotion or allowance of any contest, promotion, special night or any other activity where patrons of the licensed establishment are engaged or allowed to engage in any of the conduct prohibited in this section or prohibited under O.C.G.A. § 3-3-41. (15) Enforcement. The chief of police will cause periodic inspections of all establishments licensed to sell beer and/or wine under this chapter during the hours in which the premises are open for business to ensure compliance with this chapter and state law. If a violation of this chapter is observed the licensee or employee who is in violation of this chapter will be issued a summons to appear at the next session of municipal court. A thorough investigation of the violation will be conducted and the results of the investigation forwarded to the city manager. (16) Establishment closure in cases of emergency. The chief of police, or his/her designee, may immediately close an establishment licensed under this chapter in case of emergency, for the safety of the public or to investigate a crime, for a period of time not to exceed 24 hours. (17) Any prior license for on-premises consumption. Any prior license for on-premises consumption now in existence shall be allowed to continue and said license may be renewed and transferred under the applicable provisions of this chapter. (Code 1981, § 3-14; Ord. of 5-15-1978, § 8; Ord. No. 2008-7, 3-15-2004) Sec. 6-16. - Number of licenses available. (a) The maximum number of licenses for the retail sale of spirituous liquors which may be outstanding at any one time shall not exceed five; provided, however, that an additional license for the retail sale of spirituous liquors shall become available for each population increase in the city of 700 residents according to any future decennial census or adjusted census report published by the U.S. Bureau of Census as compared to the population of the city for the year 2000 according to the 2000 decennial census. (b) For the purposes of issuing a new license, applications for a new license shall be considered by the mayor and council in the chronological order in which said applications are submitted to the city clerk, after the additional license becomes available under the terms of this section. Any new license shall be granted to the first qualified applicant and no other applications shall be considered by the council. The requisite license fee shall be paid to the business license clerk. (Code 1981, § 3-15; Ord. of 5-15-1978, § 21; Ord. No. 2008-6, § (A), 2-18-2002) Sec. 6-17. - Proximity to churches, schools, etc. No license for off-premises consumption shall be issued hereunder unless the business premises described in the license application meets the distance requirements of O.C.G.A. § 3-3-21. Every application for a license shall include a scale drawing of the location of the proposed premises showing the distance to the uses described as set forth in this section and state law and a certificate of a registered land surveyor or professional engineer that such location complies with these requirements. (Code 1981, § 3-16; Ord. of 5-15-1978, § 23; Ord. No. 1991-1, § 2, 3-5-1990; Ord. No. 2008-6, § (B), 2-18-2002) Sec. 6-18. - Hours of sale. It shall be unlawful to sell, or offer for sale, in or upon any licensed premises, any malt beverages, wine or spirituous liquors, except between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight on weekdays and Saturdays; provided, however, that any premises which is licensed for on-premises consumption shall be allowed to remain open on Friday nights until 12:00 midnight and for three hours thereafter until 3:00 a.m., Saturday. (Code 1969, § 3-4; Code 1981, § 3-17; Ord. of 5-15-1978, § 7; Ord. No. 1983-2, § 1, 5-21-1983; Ord. No. 1985-8, § 1, 12-16-1985) Sec. 6-19. - Closing on Sundays and election days. It shall be unlawful to open any malt beverage, wine or spirituous liquor store in the city on Sundays or on election days. (Code 1969, § 3-5; Code 1981, § 3-18) State Law reference— Sale of alcoholic beverages on Sundays and election days prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-20. Sec. 6-20. - Safe and sanitary conditions. All premises used for the sale of malt beverages, wine or spirituous liquors shall be kept in a safe and sanitary condition as required by the ordinances of the city and the laws of the state. (Code 1981, § 3-19; Ord. of 5-15-1978, § 6) Sec. 6-21. - Zoning. No license for the retail sale of malt beverages, wine or spirituous liquors shall be issued unless the location subject to the license is properly classified as B-2 according to the zoning ordinances of the city (as set forth in chapter 94). (Code 1981, § 3-20; Ord. of 5-15-1978, § 10) Sec. 6-22. - Employment of minors. No retail dealer in malt beverages, wines or spirituous liquors in the city shall employ or permit to be employed, in the establishment or place of business at which malt beverages, wines or spirituous liquors are sold or dispensed, any person under the age of 18 years. (Code 1981, § 3-22; Ord. of 5-15-1978, § 16) Sec. 6-23. - Regulations of package store for off-premises consumption—Interior visibility. For the purpose of regulating the package store establishment, the following regulations shall apply: (1) Each licensed establishment shall have an open glass front and shall be well-lighted for clear vision from the outside. (2) No sign of advertisement shall be posted on the glass which may mar or obstruct the view. (3) Prices shall not be advertised for either wine, malt beverages or spirituous liquors by painting on or attaching to glass or by standing or hanging up inside or outside of glass in such manner as to reduce vision from the outside to the inside of the package store. (Code 1981, § 3-23; Ord. of 5-15-1978, § 18) Sec. 6-24. - Same—Opening or consuming alcoholic beverage. It shall be unlawful for the operator of any package store to permit any person to open any containers of alcoholic beverages or to drink any alcoholic beverages in such store. (Code 1981, § 3-24; Code 1969, § 3-6) Sec. 6-25. - Procedure for suspension or revocation of licenses. A suspension or revocation of any malt beverage license, wine license or spirituous liquor license shall be as follows: (1) Whenever the police chief or assistant police chief has knowledge of a violation of this chapter or any state or federal law on the part of an employee or licensee, this information shall be immediately brought to the attention of the city manager, or in the city manager's absence, to the attention of the mayor. (2) The chief of police or assistant chief of police with concurrence of the city manager or the mayor must as soon as possible advise the licensee of the time and place of a hearing before the council to determine whether the license involved shall be suspended pending the outcome of the case in court. Said licensee shall be notified in writing at least 24 hours prior to said hearing. Said notice shall specify the charges against said licensee. Said licensee may be represented by counsel at the hearing. (3) If for any reason a quorum of the council is not available to convene promptly for a hearing, then the city manager and mayor may suspend the license involved pending the hearing, which shall be held at the earliest possible time, and in any event no later than five days, excluding Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays. (4) At a hearing before the council, all parties shall present any evidence or facts they deem necessary. The appearance of the licensee at the hearing shall be entirely voluntary on such licensee's part. From the facts and information submitted without attempting to determine a verdict of guilty or not guilty the council shall decide what will or will not be done regarding the suspension of the license pending the outcome of the case in court. The licensee shall have the right to present witnesses on such licensee's behalf and the right to cross examine other witnesses. (5) After conviction in court, the council, no later than its regular meeting, shall decide if the license involved shall be restored, revoked or remain in suspension, and if the suspension is continued, for what length of time. If a not guilty verdict shall result in court, any suspension shall be immediately lifted. Any bond forfeiture or plea of nolo contendere, for the purpose of this section, may be treated as a conviction by the court. (6) For the purpose of this chapter and this section, the term "licensee" includes all partners in a partnership which holds a license, as well as all shareholders, officers and directors of a corporation which holds a license. (Code 1969, § 3-22; Code 1981, § 3-27; Ord. of 5-15-1978, § 15) Sec. 6-26. - Customer regulations where beverages sold for off-premises consumption. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to remain on the premises wherein malt beverages, wines, spirituous liquors are sold for off-premises consumption for a period of time exceeding 15 minutes. It shall also be unlawful for any person to park or permit a vehicle to be parked on the premises where malt beverages, wines or spirituous liquors are sold for off-premises consumption for a period of time longer than 15 minutes.
