This section shall not apply to the licensed dealer, manager or licensed employee of said establishment provided that the requirements of section 6-4 have been complied with. (b) Any automobile parked in violation of subsection (a) of this section may be impounded by the city police and shall not be released to the owner or operator until such time as the tow bill has been paid in addition to an impoundment fee of $3.00 per day for each day said automobile shall remain impounded. (c) The owner of any establishment wherein malt beverages, wines or spirituous liquors are sold for off-premises consumption shall be required to post at two conspicuous places on the premises a sign in substantially the following language: NOTICE Section 3-28(a) of the Code of Ordinances for the City of Alma Makes it Unlawful for any Customer or any Customer's Automobile to Remain on these Premises for a Period of Time Exceeding 15 Minutes. Any Violation may be Punishable by a Fine Not Exceeding $1,000.00 or Imprisonment for a Period of Time Not Exceeding 12 Months or Both. Any Automobile Found in Violation of this Ordinance may be Subject to Impoundment by the City of Alma. (d) For purposes of this chapter, the term "premises" means the building in which the malt beverage, wine or spirituous liquor is sold and any area within 150 feet of any part of said building. (Code 1981, § 3-28; Ord. No. 1984-8, 12-3-1984; Ord. No. 2008-9, § 3, 3-18-2002) Secs. 6-27—6-55. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - EXCISE TAX
FOOTNOTE(S): --- (2) --- State Law reference— Excise tax on distilled spirits for sale by the package, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-80. Sec. 6-56. - Levied. (a) There is hereby imposed, levied and assessed a special or excise tax upon the wholesale sale of malt beverages, wines and distilled spirits, at the following rates: (1) Wholesale dealers in distilled spirits, per liter (excluding fortified wines) ..... $0.22 (2) Wholesale dealers in wines, per liter ..... 0.22 (3) Wholesale dealers in malt beverages, commonly known as tap or draft beer, sold in or from a barrel or bulk container, per each container sold containing not more than 15½ gallons ..... 6.00 (4) Wholesale dealers in malt beverages sold in bottles, cans or other containers, except barrel or bulk containers, per 12 ounces ..... 0.05 (b) The taxes assessed by subsection (a) of this section shall be in addition to any and all other taxes or licenses now imposed upon such wholesale dealers. (Code 1969, § 3-40; Code 1981, § 3-30) Sec. 6-57. - When and by whom paid. Each wholesale liquor dealer shall pay the taxes imposed under this article, measured or computed with respect to containers of liquor purchased from such wholesale liquor dealer. Said taxes shall be by such wholesaler paid to the city treasurer in advance, in the manner provided by the state revenue commissioner. (Code 1969, § 3-41; Code 1981, § 3-31) Sec. 6-58. - Violations; penalties. (a) It shall be unlawful for any retail liquor dealer to own, hold, possess or sell any liquor within the city on which the excise tax herein imposed has not been paid to the city. (b) Any such violation by a retail liquor dealer or a wholesale liquor dealer shall be deemed a sufficient ground for revocation of the license issued to the violator by the city, and the refusal thereafter again to issue any license or permit to such violator. (c) Any person who shall violate the excise tax requirements, or who shall assist or aid another in so doing, or who shall assist another in evading the payment of such taxes, shall be punished as provided in section 1-8, for each such offense, and in addition such person's license as a liquor dealer in the city may be revoked at the discretion of the council. (Code 1969, § 3-42; Code 1981, § 3-32) Sec. 6-59. - Wholesale dealers selling malt beverages—Tax levy and payment. There is hereby levied and imposed upon all wholesale dealers selling malt beverages within the city a specific excise tax to be paid as follows: (1) Each wholesale dealer selling malt beverages within the city shall file a report by the tenth day of each month showing for the preceding calendar month the exact quantities of malt beverages, by size and type of container, constituting a beginning and ending inventory for the month, sold within the city. Each such wholesale dealer shall remit to the city on the tenth day of the month next succeeding the calendar month in which such sales were made, the amount of excise tax due in accordance with this section. (2) No decal, stamp or other identifying marking shall be required on malt beverages sold within the city. (Code 1969, § 3-50; Code 1981, § 3-33; Ord. of 5-7-1973, § 1) Sec. 6-60. - Same—Tax additional to other fees. The excise tax provided for in section 6-59 shall be in addition to any license fee, tax or charge which may now or in the future be imposed upon the business of selling malt beverages at retail or wholesale, within the corporate limits of the city. (Code 1969, § 3-50; Code 1981, § 3-34; Ord. of 5-7-1973, § 2) Sec. 6-61. - Same—Delinquency penalties. The failure to make a timely report and remittance shall render a wholesale dealer liable for a penalty equal to ten percent of the total amount due during the first 30-day period following the date such report and remittance were due and a further penalty of five percent of the amount of such remittance for each successive 30-day period or any portion thereof, during which such report and remittance are not filed. The filing of a false or fraudulent report shall render the wholesale dealer making such report liable for a penalty equal to 50 percent of the amount of the remittance which would be required under an accurate and truthful report. (Code 1981, § 3-35; Ord. of 5-7-1973, § 3) Sec. 6-62. - Same—Punishment. Any violation of section 6-59 by a retail beer dealer or a wholesale beer dealer shall be deemed a sufficient ground for revocation of the license or permit issued to the violator by the city. Any person who shall violate any provision of such section, or who shall assist any other person in evading the payment of the tax imposed, may be punished as provided in section 1-8 for each offense. (Code 1969, § 3-53; Code 1981, § 3-36)

div.head: Chapter 10 - ANIMALS AND FOWL
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): --- (1) --- State Law reference— Authority to exercise animal control, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(3); dogs generally, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-1 et seq.; Georgia Animal Protection Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-11-1 et seq.; rabies control and licensing of animals by local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-1 et seq. Sec. 10-1. - Animal control officers—Animal control unit established; ex officio officers. There is hereby created an animal control unit for the city which shall be under the direct supervision of the chief of police, who shall, with the approval of the city manager, hire such animal control officers as may be authorized by the city council from time to time. All fulltime police officers shall be ex officio animal control officers and be under the supervision of the chief of police on all matters pertaining to animal control. (Code 1981, § 4-1; Ord. of 1-8-1979, § 1; Ord. No. 1991-4, 10-7-1991) Sec. 10-2. - Same—Authority to issue summonses. Officers of the city police department, and officers of the animal control unit, are hereby authorized to issue a summons relative to the enforcement of this chapter. (Code 1981, § 4-2; Ord. of 1-8-1979, § 17) Sec. 10-3. - Same—Records. The animal control unit shall keep accurate written records showing the final disposition of all animals impounded by such unit, the date of impoundment, the description and other identifying data of the animal, the fees collected, the disposition of the animal and the date thereof, which record shall be open and available for inspection to citizens and residents of the city at a reasonable place during the regular business hours for a period of 24 months after the date of impoundment. (Code 1981, § 4-3; Ord. of 1-8-1979, § 14) Sec. 10-4. - Same—Interference therewith. Any person who interferes with any animal control officer in the performance of said officer's duty as provided for in this chapter shall be subject to punishment as described in section 1-8. (Code 1981, § 4-4; Ord. of 1-8-1979, § 11) Sec. 10-5. - Enforcement—Complaint of citizen. (a) Any resident of the city may file a written complaint with the animal control unit against the owner of any animal who has violated the provisions of this chapter. Said complaint shall contain the following information: (1) The name and residence of the owner of such animal; (2) The facts surrounding the alleged violation; (3) The date of said violation. (b) The complaint shall be sworn to before an officer authorized to administer oaths and said complainant shall be required to be and appear in the municipal court at the time and place set by the animal control unit to testify as to facts alleged in said complaint. (Code 1981, § 4-5; Ord. of 1-8-1979, § 12) Sec. 10-6. - Same—Procedure. The provisions of this chapter shall be enforced by the officers of the animal control unit and the police department as established by the governing authority of the city. Upon information known to, or a sworn complaint lodged with, any officer or member of the animal control unit that any owner of a dog, cat or other domestic pet is in violation of this chapter, a summons may be served, by an officer of the animal control unit requiring the owner of said animal to appear before the municipal court of the city on a day and time certain, to stand trial for violation of this chapter. If such violation of this chapter has not been witnessed by an officer, a subpoena may be issued to the person supplying the information on which a formal charge may be made to appear at said time and date to testify on behalf of the city. In the event that the owner of any dog is not known and such dog is upon the streets, alleys, sidewalks, school grounds, public places or premises of another, as prohibited by this chapter, upon complaint made or information known, to the animal control unit, it shall be the duty of the code enforcement department to immediately take possession of such dog and impound it according to the rules and regulations provided herein. (Code 1981, § 4-6; Ord. of 1-8-1979, § 16) Sec. 10-7. - Same—Summons in lieu of impoundment. The animal control officer, at such officer's discretion, may decide not to impound a dog or other animal found in violation of this chapter, and may return the animal to its owner or keeper and issue or cause to be issued a summons directed to the owner or keeper of the dog or other animal to appear before the municipal court on a certain day to stand trial for the violation of this chapter. (Code 1981, § 4-7; Ord. of 1-8-1979, § 7) Sec. 10-8. - Impoundment—Authorized. All dogs, cats or other animals found to be in violation of this chapter shall be subject to impoundment by the city and, to this end, all animal control officers shall have the right to go upon private property as is reasonably necessary to enforce the provisions of this chapter. (Code 1969, §§ 4-4, 4-22; Code 1981, § 4-9; Ord. of 1-8-1979, § 6) Sec. 10-9. - Same—Notice. Notice of the impounding of any dog, cat or other animal shall be given to the owner or keeper of such animal, if known and if the owner is unknown, then notice shall be given by the posting of a notice on the bulletin board at the city hall or the city pound, which notice shall contain a general description of the dog, cat, or other animal impounded, with the kind, color and sex thereof. (Code 1969, § 4-5; Code 1981, § 4-10; Ord. of 1-8-1979, § 8) Sec. 10-10. - Same—Holding period; redemption; disposition of unclaimed animals. (a) Any impounded dog, cat or other animal may be disposed of on the seventh day after the giving of notice to the owner or keeper as set forth in section 10-9, unless before such time the owner shall have claimed the animal and paid a fee to the city for impoundment, plus a per-day fee for the feeding of said animal plus all other costs incurred by the city in the impoundment of said animal; provided, however, no such animal shall be released by the city until said animal shall have been vaccinated as set forth in this chapter. Said animal shall be disposed of by the city in as humane and painless a manner as possible. The animal control unit may offer for adoption to any person, any dog, cat or other animal unredeemed or unclaimed by the owner after five days notice upon the payment of the required fees for impoundment and board. (b) The amounts of the fees described in this section shall be as established by the city council from time to time. (Code 1969, § 4-5; Code 1981, § 4-11; Ord. of 1-8-1979, § 9) Sec. 10-11. - Bird sanctuary—City designated. The entire area embraced within the corporate limits of the city is designated as a bird sanctuary. (Code 1969, § 4-1; Code 1981, § 4-12) Sec. 10-12. - Same—Birds protected; abating nuisance condition. It shall be unlawful to trap, hunt, shoot or attempt to shoot or molest in any manner any bird or wild fowl or to rob birds' nests or wildfowl nests. However, if starlings, English sparrows, jays, crows, sharp-shinned hawks or Cooper's hawks are found in such numbers in any locality that they constitute a nuisance, or a menace to health, property or other birds, they may be destroyed, dispersed or controlled by the city. (Code 1969, § 4-2; Code 1981, § 4-13) Sec. 10-13. - Stock at large. It shall be unlawful for any person to allow such person's cattle, hogs or other stock to run or be at large in the city. (Code 1969, § 4-3; Code 1981, § 4-14) State Law reference— Livestock running at large prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 4-3-3. Sec. 10-14. - Fowl at large. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any domestic fowl to allow the same to run or be at large within the city off the premises of the owner thereof. (Code 1969, § 4-6; Code 1981, § 4-15) Sec. 10-15. - Hogs prohibited; exceptions. No person shall keep in the city any hog or other swine for any purpose, except that this prohibition shall not apply to livestock markets and other related businesses duly licensed by the city, or as to hogs or swine kept or used in conjunction with a farm provided that they are far enough from any residence so that they do not cause a nuisance by odor or other means and at least 300 feet from adjoining landowner's property. (Code 1981, § 4-16; Ord. of 6-12-1972, § 1) Sec. 10-16. - Keeping horses. Horses may be kept in the city provided that they are kept on a field that contains at least one acre per horse and provided that the horse is kept at least 100 feet from any residence. (Code 1981, § 4-17; Ord. of 6-12-1972, § 3) Sec. 10-17. - Number of dogs and cats limited. (a) Pemitted number of dogs. No resident of the city may keep more than two dogs upon their residence at any one time; provided, however, this section shall not apply to puppies under the age of three months. (b) Housing authority properties. No dogs shall be permitted to be kept on any property owned by the housing authority of the city. This includes dogs inside or outside of any apartment or other residence. (c) Pemitted number of cats. No resident of the city may keep more than two cats upon their residence at any one time; provided, however, this section shall not apply to kittens under the age of three months. (Code 1981, § 4-18; Ord. of 6-12-1972, § 2; Ord. of 1-8-1979, § 15; Ord. No. 1996-1, 2-20-1996; Ord. of 7-10-2006; Ord. No. 2008-19, 7-10-2006) Sec. 10-18. - Nuisances—Generally; dogs at large. (a) Generally. The owner or keeper of each dog, cat or other domestic pet within the city shall be responsible for keeping it from becoming a nuisance or from endangering or injuring any other person or property, and to that end, each dog shall at all times: (1) Be kept in an enclosed structure from which it cannot escape; (2) Be tied on the owner's property so that it cannot reach the property of any adjoining owner or any public right-of-way; (3) When allowed off the property of the owner, be accompanied by the owner or other responsible person and be restrained on a leash held by such owner or other person; or (4) Be kept within a vehicle being driven or parked on the streets, or within the property limits of its owner or keeper. (b) Housing authority properties. No animal, domestic or otherwise, shall be kept by anyone on any property owned by the city housing authority. The keeping of any domestic or other animal on any property of the housing authority shall be deemed to be a nuisance. (Code 1981, § 4-19; Ord. of 1-8-1979, § 3; Ord. No. 1996-1, 2-20-1996) Sec. 10-19. - Same—Examples. It shall be unlawful for any owner to fail to exercise proper care and control of such person's animals to prevent them from becoming a public nuisance. Excessive, continuous or untimely barking, molesting passersby, chasing vehicles, habitually attacking other domestic animals, trespassing upon school grounds, or trespassing upon private property in such manner as to damage property, shall be deemed a nuisance. (Code 1969, § 4-24; Code 1981, § 4-20) Sec. 10-20. - Vaccination; tag. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any dog or cat or any other animal which is kept as a pet, to keep or maintain such animal within the city unless it shall have been vaccinated by a licensed veterinarian with anti-rabies vaccine, within one year preceding the date on which such domestic or domesticated animal is kept or maintained. It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or keep any such animal on any premises within the city unless such animal wears a collar or harness securely attached to its body to which shall be securely attached a tag issued for such animal by a licensed veterinarian showing that the animal has been, within the preceding 12 months, vaccinated against rabies. (Code 1969, §§ 4-21—4-23; Code 1981, § 4-21; Ord. of 1-8-1979, § 2) Sec. 10-21. - Vicious animals. Any animal that has attacked or bitten a person or other animal without provocation or has attempted to bite a person or other animal without provocation shall be deemed a vicious animal by any officer of the animal control unit and it shall be unlawful for any person to cause, permit, accompany or be responsible for the presence of any vicious animal on the streets or public places of the city or allow the same to run on the premises of another, at any time, unless and in addition to the other requirements of this chapter, such animal shall be securely muzzled to effectively prevent it from biting any person or other animal. (Code 1981, § 4-22; Ord. of 1-8-1979, § 4) State Law reference— Mercedes' Law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-40 et seq. Sec. 10-22. - Confinement and disposition of biting animal. All dogs, cats or other animals known to have bitten a person shall be confined to the animal control unit or veterinarian's hospital for a period of ten days. All expenses incurred for boarding of such animal for such period of time shall be paid by the owner or keeper of said animal. If said animal is not claimed by its owner or other responsible person within a period of 15 days, said animal may be destroyed by the animal control unit in the manner hereinafter set forth. (Code 1981, § 4-23; Ord. of 1-8-1979, § 5) Sec. 10-23. - Disposal of injured, etc., animals. The animal control unit shall have the authority to humanely dispose of dogs, cats or other domestic pets which are diseased or injured and lying in the streets, or public ways of the city, whenever it shall appear that any such animal is injured and suffering great pain, and whenever such animal does not bear a tag identifying the owner, and no determination as to the owner of such animal can be made with a reasonable inquiry or investigation. (Code 1981, § 4-24; Ord. of 1-8-1979, § 13) Sec. 10-24. - Animal quarters. All animals and animal quarters are kept in a clean and sanitary condition and so maintained as to eliminate objectionable odors. (Code 1981, § 4-25; Ord. of 7-10-2006; Ord. No. 2008-19, 7-10-2006)

div.head: Chapter 14 - BUILDINGS AND CONSTRUCTION
div.p:
FOOTNOTE(S): --- (1) --- State Law reference— Authority to adopt technical codes, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(12); construction standards generally, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-1 et seq.; minimum state construction codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25; enforcement of minimum state construction codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-26. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 14-1. - Fire districts. All land within the city limits shall be fire district No. 1. (Code 1969, § 5-5; Code 1981, § 5-1) Sec. 14-2. - Contractors, builders, etc. (a) License prerequisite to enforcing claim. No person shall have the right to enforce in any court any claim for compensation, profit or fees of any nature whatsoever, for any business, work, labor or construction, as a contractor, plumber, builder, electrician or any related business or service in the city without having previously obtained the license required by the city for such business, trade, vocation, occupation or service. (b) Allowing illegal use of name, license or bond. No person engaged in the general contracting business shall allow such person's name to be used by any other person, directly or indirectly, to obtain a permit or for the construction of any work under such person's name, license; nor shall such person make any misrepresentations or omissions in such person's returns. Such action shall be cause for revoking the license and permit. (Code 1969, § 5-4; Code 1981, §§ 5-3, 5-4; Ord. of 3-12-1973) Secs. 14-3—14-22. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - TECHNICAL CODES
Sec. 14-23. - References to officials in adopted technical codes. Where reference is made to the duties of certain officials named within the technical codes which are adopted by reference in this chapter, then that designated official of the city, who has duties corresponding to those of the named official in said technical code, shall be deemed to be the responsible official insofar as enforcing the provisions of that technical code are concerned. Sec. 14-24. - Technical codes adopted. (a) The following technical and building codes, the latest edition of each as adopted and amended by the state department of community affairs, are adopted by reference and incorporated into this Code as if set out fully herein, including the administration chapter and appendices: (1) International Building Code (IBC), 2010 edition; (2) National Electrical Code (NEC), 2010 edition; (3) International Fuel Gas Code (IFGC), 2010 edition; (4) International Mechanical Code (IMC), 2010 edition; (5) International Plumbing Code (IPC), 2010 edition; (6) International Residential Code for One- and Two-Family Dwellings (IRC), 2010 edition; (7) International Energy Conservation Code (IECC), 2010 edition; (8) International Fire Code (IFC), 2010 edition; (9) International Existing Building Code (IEBC), 2010 edition; and (10) City of Alma Property Maintenance Code. (b) If any of the publications listed in subsection (a) of this section are adopted as a state minimum code pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 8-2-20 et seq., then the edition adopted by the state shall control. If any of the publications listed in subsection (a) of this section are less stringent than the state minimum codes promulgated pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 8-2-20 et seq., then the state minimum code shall control. (c) A copy of each of the publications listed in subsection (a) of this section, as adopted by the state, is filed in the office of the code enforcement officer and available for review by the public. The same is adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein, and from the date on which this section shall take effect, the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the corporate limits of the city. (d) The city manager or the code enforcement officer shall enforce the state minimum codes adopted herein. Secs. 14-25—14-50. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - PLUMBING
Sec. 14-51. - Flow-rate restrictions on plumbing fixtures. (a) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection (a)(1), except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. The definitions set forth in O.C.G.A. § 8-2-3(b) (High-efficiency plumbing fixtures; exemptions) shall be effective as definitions of the words, terms and phrases used in this chapter. All words, terms and phrases used herein, other than those specifically defined elsewhere in this chapter, shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them in O.C.G.A. § 8-2-3(b), and shall have the same scope and effect that the same words, terms and phrases have where used in O.C.G.A. § 8-2-3(b). Commercial means any type of building other than residential. Construction means the erection of a new building or the alteration of an existing building in connection with its repair or renovation or in connection with making an addition to an existing building, and shall include the replacement of a malfunctioning, unserviceable or obsolete faucet, showerhead, toilet or urinal in an existing building. Residential. (1) The term "residential" means any building or unit of a building intended for occupancy as a dwelling. (2) The term "residential" does not include a hotel or motel. (b) Prohibited construction for residential buildings. There shall be no new construction of any building initiated within the city for any residential or commercial building of any type which does not meet the following requirements or contain the following standards: (1) A water closet or toilet that: a. Is a dual flush water closet that meets the following standards: 1. The average flush volume of two reduced flushes and one full flush may not exceed 1.28 gallons; 2. The toilet meets the performance, testing, and labeling requirements prescribed by the following standards, as applicable: (i) American Society of Mechanical Engineers Standard A112.19.2-2008; (ii) American Society of Mechanical Engineers Standard A112.19.14-2006 six-liter water closets equipped with a dual flushing device; and (iii) Is listed to the WaterSenseTM tank-type high efficiency toilet specification; or b. Is a single-flush water closet, including gravity, pressure assisted and electro-hydraulic tank types that meets the following standards: 1. The average flush volume may not exceed 1.28 gallons; 2. The toilet must meet the performance, testing, and labeling requirements prescribed by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers Standard A112.19.2/CSA B45.1 or A112.19.14; and 3. The toilet must be listed to the WaterSenseTM tank-type high efficiency toilet specification; (2) A shower head that allows a flow of no more than an average of 2.5 gallons of water per minute at 60 pounds per square inch of pressure; (3) A urinal and associated flush valve that: a. Uses no more than 0.5-gallon of water per flush; b. Meets the performance, testing, and labeling requirements prescribed by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers Standard A112.19.2/CSA B45.1; c. For flushing urinals, meets all WaterSenseTM specifications for flushing urinals; and d. Where nonwater urinals are employed, complies with American Society of Mechanical Engineers Standard A112.19.3/CSA B45.4 or A112.19.19/CSA B45.4. Nonwater urinals shall be cleaned and maintained in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions after installation. Where nonwater urinals are installed they shall have a water distribution line roughed-in to the urinal location at a minimum height of 56 inches (1,422 mm) to allow for the installation of an approved backflow prevention device in the event of a retrofit. Such water distribution lines shall be installed with shutoff valves located as close as possible to the distributing main to prevent the creation of dead ends. Where nonwater urinals are installed, a minimum of one water supplied fixture rated at a minimum of one water supply fixture unit shall be installed upstream on the same drain line to facilitate drain line flow and rinsing; (4) A lavatory faucet or lavatory replacement aerator that allows a flow of no more than 1.5 gallons of water per minute at a pressure of 60 pounds per square inch in accordance with American Society of Mechanical Engineers Standard A112.18.1/CSA B.125.1 and listed to the WaterSenseTM high-efficiency lavatory faucet specification; and (5) A kitchen faucet or kitchen replacement aerator that allows a flow of no more than 2.0 gallons of water per minute. (c) Exemptions. (1) New construction and the repair or renovation of an existing building shall be exempt from the requirements of this article when: a. The repair or renovation of the existing building does not include the replacement of the plumbing or sewerage system servicing toilets, faucets or showerheads within such existing buildings; b. When such plumbing or sewerage system within such existing building, because of its capacity, design or installation, would not function properly if the toilets, faucets or showerheads required by this article were installed; c. Such system is a well or gravity flow from a spring and is owned privately by an individual for use in such individual's personal residence; or d. Units to be installed are: 1. Specifically designed for use by persons with disabilities; 2. Specifically designed to withstand unusual abuse or installation in a penal institution; or 3. Toilets for juveniles. (2) The owner or his/her agent of a building undergoing new construction or repair or renovation who is entitled to an exemption as specified in subsection (c)(1)b., c., or d. of this section shall obtain the exemption by applying at the office of the building inspector for the county. A fee in an amount as established by the city council from time to time, shall be charged for the inspection and issuance of such exemption. (Code 1981, § 5-61; Ord. No. 1991-3, §§ 1—6, 2-18-1991) State Law reference— Flow-rate restrictions on plumbing fixtures, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-3. Sec. 14-52. - Provisions allowing contractor self-inspection of water and sewer projects inapplicable. Pursuant to the authority contained in section 3 of Act 1046 Georgia Laws, 1996, pages 1632 to 1634, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-26(d), relating to self-inspection of water and sewer projects by master plumbers or utility contractors, shall not be applicable within the city. (Code 1981, § 5-62; Ord. No. 1996-3, § 1, 9-16-1996) Secs. 14-53—14-77. - Reserved. ARTICLES IV, V. - RESERVED
Secs. 14-78—14-128. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - SOIL EROSION AND SEDIMENT CONTROL
FOOTNOTE(S): --- (2) --- State Law reference— Erosion and Sedimentation Act of 1975, O.C.G.A. § 12-7-1 et seq.; local land disturbing activity ordinances, O.C.G.A. § 12-7-4. Sec. 14-129. - Definitions. The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this article, unless otherwise specifically stated: Certification means a signed, written statement by the code enforcement officer that specific constructions, inspections or tests have been performed where required and that such comply with the applicable requirements of this article or regulations adopted. Cut means a portion of land surface or area from which earth has been removed or will be removed by excavation; the depth below original ground surface to excavated surface; also known as excavation. Debris dam means a barrier or dam built across a waterway or at other suitable locations to retain rock, sand, gravel, silt or other material. District means the soil and water conservation district for this area, if any. Erosion and sediment control plan means a plan for the control of soil erosion and sediment resulting from a land disturbing activity; also known as plan. Existing grade means the vertical location of the existing ground surface prior to cutting or filling. Finished grade means the final grade or elevation of the ground surface forming the proposed design. Grading means altering surfaces to specified elevations, dimensions, or slopes. The term "grading" includes stripping, cutting, filling, stockpiling and shaping or any combination thereof and includes the land in its cut or filled condition. Issuing authority means the Georgia Environmental Protection Division. Land disturbing activity means any land change which may result in soil erosion from water or wind and the movement of sediments into state waters or onto lands within the state, including, but not limited to, clearing, dredging, grading, excavating, transporting and filling of land. Natural ground surface means the ground surface in its original state before any grading, excavation or filling. Permit means the authorization necessary to begin a land disturbing activity under the provisions of this article. Person means as defined in section 1-2, and more specifically, any individual, partnership, firm, association joint venture, public or private corporation, trust, estate, commission, board, public or private institution, utility, cooperative, state agency, municipality or other political subdivision of this state, any interstate body, or any other legal entity. Sediment means solid material, both mineral and organic, that is in suspension, is being transported, or has been moved from its site of origin by air, water, ice, or gravity as a product of erosion. Sediment basin means a depression formed from the construction of a barrier or dam built at a suitable location to retain sediment and debris. Stabilization means the process of establishing an enduring soil cover of vegetation or mulch or other ground cover in combination with installing temporary or permanent structures for the purpose of reducing to a minimum the transport of sediment by wind, water, ice or gravity. Vegetative practice means the stabilization of erosive or sediment producing areas by covering the soil with: (1) Permanent seeding, producing long-term vegetative cover; (2) Short-term seeding, producing temporary vegetative cover; or (3) Sodding, covering areas with a turf of perennial sod-forming grass. Watercourse means any natural or artificial watercourse, stream, river, creek, channel, ditch, canal, conduit, culvert, drain, waterway, gully, ravine, or wash in which water flows either continuously or intermittently and which has a definite channel, bed and banks, and including any area adjacent thereto subject to inundation by reason of overflow or floodwater. (Code 1981, § 5-100) Sec. 14-130. - Enforcement—Inspections; notice to comply; investigations; right of entry. (a) The Georgia Environmental Division will periodically inspect, or cause to be inspected, the sites of land disturbing activities for which permits have been issued to determine if the activities are being conducted in accordance with the plan and if the measures required in the plan are effective in controlling erosion and sedimentation. (b) If, through inspection, it is determined that a person engaged in land disturbing activities, as defined herein, has failed to comply with the approved plan, a written notice to comply shall be served upon that person. The notice shall set forth the measures necessary to achieve compliance with the plan and shall state the time within which such measures must be completed. If the person engaged in the land disturbing activity fails to comply within the time specified, such person shall be deemed in violation of this article. (c) The city shall have the power to conduct such investigations as it may reasonably deem necessary to carry out its duties as prescribed in this article, and for this purpose to enter at reasonable times upon any property, public or private, for the purpose of investigating and inspecting the sites of land disturbing activities. (d) No person shall refuse entry or access to any authorized representative or agent who requests entry for purposes of inspection, and who presents appropriate credentials, nor shall any person obstruct, hamper or interfere with any such representative while in the process of carrying out such representative's official duties. (Code 1981, § 5-101) Sec. 14-131. - Same—Violations; performance and maintenance bonds. (a) Any person violating this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-8. For each day such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. (b) The city council may require a performance and maintenance bond on major projects when the same is found to be in the best interest of the general public. (Code 1981, § 5-102) Sec. 14-132. - Liability. Neither the approval of a plan under the provisions of this article, nor the compliance with the provisions of this article, shall relieve any person from the responsibility for damage to any person or property otherwise imposed by law nor impose any liability upon the city or the district for damage to any person or property. (Code 1981, § 5-103) Sec. 14-133. - Appeals. (a) The suspension, revocation, modification or grant with condition of a permit by the city upon a finding that the holder is not in compliance with the approved erosion and sediment control plan; or that the holder is in violation of permit conditions; or that the holder is in violation of any ordinance, resolution, rule or regulation adopted or promulgated pursuant to this article; shall entitle the person submitting the plan or holding the permit to a hearing before the city council within 45 days after receipt by the city of written notice of intent to appeal. (b) Any person, aggrieved by a decision or order of the issuing authority, after exhausting his/her administrative remedies, shall have the right to appeal de novo to the superior court. (Code 1981, § 5-104) Sec. 14-134. - Applicability; exclusions. (a) This article shall apply to any major or minor land disturbing activity undertaken by any person on any lands in the city other than federal lands, exclusive of the following: (1) Minor land disturbing activities such as home gardens and individual home landscaping, repairs, maintenance work, and other related activities which result in minor soil erosion; (2) Agricultural practices involving the establishment, cultivation or harvesting of products of the field or orchard, forestry land management practices and preparing and planting of pasture land with such practices including harvesting, farm ponds, dairy operations, livestock and poultry management practices, and the construction of farm buildings; (3) The term "surface mining" means the same as defined in subsection (a) of section 3 of the Georgia Surface Mining Act of 1968 (O.C.G.A. § 43-14-3(a)), as now or hereafter amended; (4) Granite quarrying and land clearing for such quarrying; (5) Construction or maintenance projects, or both, undertaken or financed in whole or in part, or both, by: a. The state tollway authority; b. The state department of transportation; c. The state highway authority; d. Any county or municipality of the state; (6) Any project carried out under the technical supervision of the soil conservation service of the United States Department of Agriculture; (7) Activities conducted by any airport authority or by any public utility under the regulatory jurisdiction of the public service commission; (8) Any activity for which bids have been let or a construction contract signed prior to the date of adoption of the ordinance from which this section is derived, provided that said activity was completed within 12 months after said date. (b) Nonexcluded land disturbing activities are identified as major or minor as follows: (1) Major (state-regulated requirements). All land disturbing activities other than those excluded by subsection (a) of this section and additionally excluded as: a. The construction of single-family residences when they are constructed by or under contract with the owner for his/her own occupancy; b. Any project involving land change to five acres or less, provided this land change does not occur within 200 feet of the banks of any major stream or river which drains a land area of at least 100 square miles; c. Any project involving the movement of not more than 500 cubic yards of land, provided this land change does not occur within 200 feet of the banks of any major stream or river which drains a land area of at least 100 square miles. (2) Minor (city-regulated requirements). a. The construction of single-family residences. b. Any project involving land change to five acres or less. c. Any project involving the movement of 500 cubic yards or less of land. d. The construction of farm buildings. (Code 1981, § 5-105) Sec. 14-135. - Familiarization with governmental plans and regulations. The landowner, developer and designated planners and engineers are encouraged to review the general development plans and detailed plans of any unit of government that affect the tract to be developed and the areas surrounding it. They are also encouraged to become acquainted with the zoning ordinance (as set forth in chapter 94), subdivision ordinance (as set forth in chapter 78), this article and other ordinances which regulate the development of land within the city. (Code 1981, § 5-106) Sec. 14-136. - Permit—Required; compliance before occupancy; fees. No person shall perform any land disturbing activities as defined herein within the corporate limits of the city without first obtaining a permit from the Georgia Environmental Division to perform such activities. Further, no approval for permit for occupancy shall be considered or issued for any building or structure unless all required erosion control measures have been completed or substantially provided for in accordance with the standards and specifications of this article and as submitted to the city. (Code 1981, § 5-107) Sec. 14-137. - Same—Application; plans; referrals. (a) Applications for permits shall be submitted to the city clerk. Applications for permits will not be accepted unless accompanied by three copies of the applicant's soil erosion and sediment control plan. Said plans for major land disturbing activities shall include, as a minimum, the data specified in section 14-138. Said plans for minor land disturbing activities shall include as much of the data specified in said section as the code enforcement officer shall determine to be required for each application. Soil erosion and sediment control plans shall conform to the technical principles and standards as specified in section 14-140. (b) Immediately upon receipt of an application for permit for major land disturbing activity, the city shall refer the application and plan to the district, if any, for its review and recommendations. Immediately upon receipt of an application for permit for minor land disturbing activity, the city shall refer the application and plan to the code enforcement officer for his/her review and recommendations. If the code enforcement officer recommends that application and plans should be referred to the district, if any, the city will do so. The results of the district review or code enforcement officer's review, as applicable, shall be forwarded to the city. (Code 1981, § 5-108) Sec. 14-138. - Same—Data required. The applicant's erosion and sediment control plan shall include, as a minimum, the following information for the entire tract of land to be disturbed, whether or not the tract will be developed in stages: (1) A narrative description of the overall project. This narrative shall include: a. Anticipated starting and completion dates of each sequence and stage of land disturbing activities and the expected date the final stabilization will be completed; b. A description of the sediment control program, sediment control practices and stormwater management program; c. An adequate description of general topographic and soils conditions of the tract as available from the code enforcement officer or the district office, if any; d. A description of the zoning classification of adjacent property and a description of existing structures, buildings and other fixed improvements located on surrounding properties; and e. A description of the maintenance program for sediment control facilities including inspection programs, vegetative establishment of exposed soils, method and frequency of removal and disposal of solid waste material removed from control facilities and disposition of temporary structural measures. (2) Maps, drawings and supportive computations bearing the seal of the professional engineer or landscape architect and containing: a. A site location drawing of the proposed project, indicating the location of the proposed project in relation to roadways jurisdictional boundaries, streams and rivers; b. A boundary line survey of the site on which the work is to be performed; c. A topographic map containing contours at an interval and scale that will adequately depict the existing and finished grades, existing and proposed watercourses, and the proposed features of the proposed development; d. A plan for temporary and permanent vegetative and structural erosion and sediment control measures; e. Specifications of soil erosion and sedimentation control measures in accordance with the standards and specifications of this article; and f. Computations, timing schedules and other supportive data required for review of applicant's plan. (Code 1981, § 5-109) Sec. 14-139. - Same—Issuance; denial; suspension, revocation or modification. (a) A permit for major land disturbing activities, and for such minor land disturbing activities that have been referred to the district, if any, will be issued after the district has determined that the plans for erosion and sedimentation control comply with the requirements of section 14-140 and after the city has determined that the plans comply with all ordinances, rules and regulations in effect within the city. A permit for minor land disturbing activities that had not been referred to the district will be issued after the code enforcement officer has determined that the plans for erosion and sedimentation control comply with the requirements of section 14-140, and after the city has determined that the plans comply with all ordinances, rules and regulations in effect within the city. (b) Permits will be issued or denied as soon as practical after receipt of application by the city but in any event not later than 45 days after receipt of a completed application. If the permit is denied, the reason for denial shall be furnished to the applicant. (c) If the tract is to be developed in phases, then a separate permit shall be required for each phase. (d) Said permit may be suspended, revoked or modified by the city upon finding that the holder is not in compliance with this article. (Code 1981, § 5-110) Sec. 14-140. - Principles and standards. (a) Implementation. Excessive soil erosion and resulting sediment pollution can take place during land disturbing activities. Therefore, plans for those land disturbing activities which are not excluded by this article shall contain provisions for application of soil erosion and sediment control measures. These provisions shall be incorporated into the final plans and construction drawings that are filed with the application. Soil erosion and sediment control measures shall conform to the standards and specifications of this article. The application of measures shall apply to all features of the site, including street and utility installations, drainage facilities and other temporary and permanent improvements. Measures shall be installed to prevent or control erosion and sediment pollution during all stages of any land disturbing activity. (b) General design principles. Practical combinations of the following principles shall be utilized, as a minimum, in planning measures to be installed for any land disturbing activity: (1) The land disturbing activity shall conform to existing topography and soil type so as to create the lowest practical erosion potential. (2) Land disturbing activities shall be conducted in a manner minimizing erosion. (3) The disturbed area and the duration of exposure to erosive elements shall be kept to a practicable minimum. (4) Cut-fill operations must be kept to a minimum. (5) Disturbed soil shall be stabilized as quickly as practicable. (6) Whenever feasible, natural vegetation shall be retained, protected and supplemented. (7) Temporary vegetation or mulching shall be employed to protect exposed critical areas during development. (8) Permanent vegetation and structural erosion control measures shall be installed as soon as practicable and provisions shall be made to effectively accommodate runoff resulting from a change in topography, vegetation and soil conditions. (9) Adequate provisions must be provided to minimize damage from surface water to the cut face of excavations and the sloping surface of fills. (10) To the extent necessary, sediment runoff water must be trapped by the use of debris basins, sediment basins, silt traps or similar measures until the disturbed area is stabilized, and all cut and fill slopes shall be designed to retain their finished grade. (11) Cuts and fills and other permanent structures shall not endanger adjoining property. (12) Fills shall not encroach upon natural watercourses or constructed channels in a manner so as to adversely affect other property owners or the natural floodplain. (13) Grading equipment must cross flowing streams by means of bridges or culverts except when such methods are not feasible and provided, in any case, that such crossings are kept to a minimum. (c) Standards and specifications. Plans for land disturbing activities shall contain soil erosion and sediment control plans and specifications which conform to the publication entitled Manual for Erosion and Sediment Control in Georgia which is on file in the office of the city clerk. Such publication is incorporated by reference in this article. (d) Maintenance. (1) The applicant carrying out soil erosion and sedimentation control practices, whether temporary or permanent, shall at all times be the responsibility of the owner. (2) Permanent structures which are to be incorporated into the landscape shall remain the responsibility of the original owner until such time as the property is legally deeded to a subsequent owner who will assume responsibility for maintenance of these facilities. (3) Soil erosion and sediment control practices which, in the opinion of the issuing authority, might be considered hazards to life or property shall be properly fenced and posted by signs in accordance with the standards and specifications of this article. (4) Sediment basins and stormwater detention basins shall be considered hazardous to life or property and shall be fenced and posted in accordance with the standards and specifications incorporated by reference in this article. (Code 1981, § 5-111) Secs. 14-141—14-185. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 14-186. - Title; purpose. (a) Title. These regulations shall be known as the city property maintenance code for residential dwellings and commercial properties, hereinafter referred to as "this article." (b) Scope. The provisions of this article shall apply to: (1) All such existing premises and constitute minimum requirements and standards for premises, structures, equipment, and facilities for light, ventilation, space, heating, sanitation, protection from the elements, life safety, safety from fire and other hazards, and for safe and sanitary maintenance; (2) The responsibility of owners, operators and occupants; (3) The occupancy of existing structures and premises; and (4) The administration, enforcement and penalties of same. The provisions in the appendices shall not apply unless specifically adopted. (c) Intent. This article shall be construed to secure its expressed intent, which is to ensure public health, safety and welfare insofar as they are affected by the continued occupancy and maintenance of structures and premises. Existing structures and premises that do not comply with these provisions shall be altered or repaired to provide a minimum level of health and safety as required herein. (Code 1981, § 11-101; Ord. No. 2008-16, § 101, 12-5-2005) Sec. 14-187. - Applicability. (a) Matters affecting structures and premises; most restrictive shall govern. The provisions of this article shall apply to all matters affecting or relating to structures and premises, as set forth in section 14-186. Where, in a specific case, different sections of this article specify different requirements, the most restrictive shall govern. (b) Maintenance. Equipment, systems, devices and safeguards required by this article or a previous regulation or code under which the structure or premises was constructed, altered or repaired shall be maintained in good working order. The requirements of this article are not intended to provide the basis for removal or abrogation of fire protection and safety systems and devices in existing structures. Except as otherwise specified herein, the owner or the owner's designated agent shall be responsible for the maintenance of buildings, structures and premises. (c) Application of other codes. Repairs, additions or alterations to a structure, or changes of occupancy, shall be done in accordance with the procedures and provisions of the state minimum construction codes and other applicable state and local laws and ordinances listed in division 8 of this article. (d) Existing remedies. The provisions in this article shall not be construed to abolish or impair existing remedies of the jurisdiction or its officers or agencies relating to the removal or demolition of any structure, which is dangerous, unsafe and unsanitary. (e) Workmanship. Repairs, maintenance work, alterations or installations which are caused directly or indirectly by the enforcement of this article shall be executed and installed in a workmanlike manner and installed in accordance with the manufacturer's installation instructions and the provision of all applicable state codes, laws and ordinances. (f) Historic buildings. The provisions of this article shall be mandatory unless exempted by state statute on buildings that have been identified by such statutes as historic buildings. The city official shall determine the structure to be safe and in the public interest of health, safety and welfare. (g) Referenced codes and standards. The codes and standards referenced in this article shall be those that are listed in division 8 of this article and considered part of the requirements of this article to the prescribed extent of each such reference. Where differences occur between provisions of this article and the referenced standards, the provisions of the applicable code or law shall apply. (h) Requirements not covered by this article. Requirements necessary for the strength, stability or proper operation of an existing structure or equipment, or for the public safety, health and general welfare, not specifically covered by this article, shall be determined by the city official. (Code 1981, § 11-102; Ord. No. 2008-16, § 102, 12-5-2005) Sec. 14-188. - Rules of construction. (a) Scope. Unless otherwise expressly stated, the terms set forth in this section shall, for the purpose of this article, have the meanings shown in this division. (b) Interchangeability. Words stated in the present tense include the future; words stated in the masculine gender include the feminine and neuter; the singular number includes the plural and the plural the singular. (c) Terms defined in other codes. Where terms are not defined in this article and are defined in the state minimum construction codes listed or other applicable codes listed in division 8 in this article, such terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them as in those codes. (d) Terms not defined. Where terms are not defined, through the methods authorized by this section, such terms shall have ordinarily accepted meanings such as the context implies. (e) Parts. Whenever the terms "dwelling unit," "premises," "building," "roominghouse," "rooming unit" or "story" are stated in this article, they shall be construed as though they were followed by the term "or any part thereof." (Code 1981, § 11-151; Ord. No. 2008-16, § 201, 12-5-2005) Sec. 14-189. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Approved means approved by the code official. Basement means that portion of a building that is partly or completely below grade. Bathroom means a room containing plumbing fixtures including a bathtub or shower. Bedroom means any room or space used or intended to be used for sleeping purposes. City official means the city administrator, building official, city marshal or any authorized agent of the city. Condemn means to adjudge unfit for occupancy. Dwelling unit means a single unit providing complete, independent living facilities for one or more persons, including permanent provisions for living, sleeping, eating, cooking and sanitation. Exterior property means the open space on the premises and on adjoining property under the control of owners or operators of such premises. Extermination means the control and elimination of insects, rats or other pests by: (1) Eliminating their harborage places; (2) Removing or making inaccessible materials that serve as their food; (3) Poisoning, spraying, fumigating, trapping; or (4) Any other recognized and legal pest elimination methods. Garbage means the animal or vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food. Habitable space. (1) The term "habitable space" means space in a dwelling unit used for living, sleeping, eating or cooking. (2) The term "habitable space" does not include bathrooms, toilet rooms, closets, halls, storage or utility spaces and similar areas. Imminent hazard means a condition which could cause serious or life-threatening injury or death at any time. Infestation means the presence, within or contiguous to, a structure or premises of insects, rats, vermin or other pests. Inoperable motor vehicle means one which cannot be driven upon the public streets for reasons including but not limited to being unlicensed, wrecked, abandoned, in a state of disrepair, or incapable of being moved under its own power. Let for occupancy or let means to permit, provide or offer possession or occupancy of a dwelling unit, rooming unit, building, premises or structure by a person who is or is not the legal owner of record thereof pursuant to a written or unwritten lease, agreement or license, or pursuant to a recorded or unrecorded agreement of contract for the sale of land. Occupancy means the purpose for which a building or portion thereof is utilized or occupied. Occupant means any individual living or sleeping in a building; or having possession of a space within a building. Openable area means that part of a window, skylight or door which is available for unobstructed ventilation and which opens directly to the outdoors. Operator means any person who has charge, care or control of a structure or premises which is let or offered for occupancy. Owner means any person, agent, operator, firm or corporation: (1) Having a legal or equitable interest in the property; (2) Recorded in the official records of the state, county or municipality holding title to the property; or (3) Otherwise having control of the property, including the guardian of the estate of any such person, and the executor or administrator of the estate of such person if ordered to take possession of real property by a court. Person means an individual, corporation, partnership or any other group acting as a unit. Premises means a lot plot or parcel of land including any structure thereon. Rooming unit means any room or group of rooms forming a single habitable unit occupied or, intended to be occupied for sleeping or living, but not for cooking purposes. Roominghouse means a building arranged or occupied for lodging, with or without meals, for compensation and not occupied as a one-family dwelling or a two-family dwelling. Rubbish means combustible and noncombustible waste materials, except garbage. The term "rubbish" includes the residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke and other combustible materials, paper, rags, cartons, boxes, wood, excelsior, rubber, leather, tree branches, yard trimmings, tin cans, metals, mineral matter, glass, furniture, appliances, crockery and dust and other similar materials. Structure means that which is built or constructed or a portion thereof. Tenant means a person, corporation, partnership or group, whether or not the legal owner of record, occupying a building or portion thereof as a unit. Toilet room means a room containing a water closet or urinal but not a bathtub or shower. Unsafe building means any building or structure that has any of the following conditions, such that the life, health, property or safety of its occupants or the general public are endangered: (1) Any means of egress or portion thereof is not of adequate size or is not arranged to provide a safe path of travel in case of fire or panic. (2) Any means of egress or portion thereof, such as, but not limited to, fire doors, closing devices and fire-resistive ratings, is in disrepair or in a dilapidated or nonworking condition such that the means of egress could be rendered unsafe in case of fire or panic. (3) The stress in any material, member or portion thereof, due to all imposed loads including dead-loads that exceed the stresses allowed in the state minimum construction codes for new buildings. (4) The building, structure or portion thereof has been damaged by fire, flood, earthquake, wind or other cause to the extent that the structural integrity of the building or structure is less than it was prior to the damage and is less than the minimum requirement established by the state minimum construction codes for new buildings. (5) Any exterior appendage or portion of the building or structure is not securely fastened, attached or anchored such that it is capable of resisting wind, seismic or similar loads as required by the state minimum construction codes for new buildings. (6) If for any reason the building, structure or portion thereof is manifestly unsafe or unsanitary for the purpose for which it is being used. (7) The building, structure or portion thereof as a result of decay, deterioration or dilapidation is likely to fully or partially collapse. (8) The building, structure or portion thereof has been constructed or maintained in violation of a specific requirement of the state minimum construction codes or of a city, county or state law. (9) Any building, structure or portion thereof that is in such a condition as to constitute a public nuisance. (10) Any building, structure or portion thereof that is unsafe, unsanitary or not provided with adequate egress, or which constitutes a fire hazard, or is otherwise dangerous to human life, or, which in relation to existing use, constitutes a hazard to safety or health by reason of inadequate maintenance, dilapidation, obsolescence or abandonment. Ventilation means the natural or mechanical process of supplying conditioned or unconditioned air to, or removing such air from, any space. Yard means an open space on the same lot with a structure. (Code 1981, § 11-152; Ord. No. 2008-16, § 202, 12-5-2005) Secs. 14-190—14-216. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION
Sec. 14-217. - Duties and powers of the city official. (a) Enforcement authority. The city official shall enforce the provisions of this article. (b) Rule-making authority. The city official shall have authority to: (1) Recommend to the city council, the adoption of rules and procedures necessary in the implementation of this article; (2) Interpret and implement the provisions of this article; (3) Secure the intent thereof. Such rules shall not have the effect of waiving structural or fire performance requirements specifically provided for in this article, or of violating accepted engineering methods involving public safety. (c) Inspections. The city official shall make or cause to be made all of the required inspections, or is hereby authorized to accept reports of inspection by approved agencies or individuals. AH reports of such inspections shall be in writing and be certified by a responsible officer of such approved agency or by the responsible individual. The city official is authorized to engage such expert opinion as deemed necessary to report upon unusual technical issues that arise. (d) Right of entry. The city official shall enforce the provisions of this article, and or his/her duly authorized representative upon presentation of proper identification to the owner, agent or tenant in charge of such property, may enter any building, structure, apartment, apartment house or premises during all reasonable hours, except in cases of emergency where extreme hazards are known to exist which may involve the potential loss of life or severe property damage, in which case the limitations set forth in this subsection shall not apply. (e) Identification. The city official or his/her authorized representative shall carry proper identification when inspecting structures or premises in the performance of duties under this article. (f) Notices, citations and orders. The city official is authorized to issue all necessary notices, citations and orders in accordance with all sections of this article and this Code of Ordinances. (g) Department records. The city official shall keep official records of all business and activities of the department specified in the provisions of this article. Such records shall be retained in the official records as long as the building or structure to which such records relate remains in existence, unless otherwise provided for by other laws or regulations. (h) Coordination of inspections. Whenever in the enforcement of this article or another code or ordinance, the responsibility of more than one official of the jurisdiction is involved, it shall be the duty of the official involved to coordinate their inspections and administrative orders as fully as practicable so that the owners and occupants of the structure shall not be subjected to visits by numerous inspectors or multiple or conflicting orders. Whenever an inspector from any agency or department observes an apparent or actual violation of some provision of some law, ordinance or code not within the inspector's authority to enforce, the inspector shall report the findings to the official having jurisdiction. (Code 1981, § 11-103; Ord. No. 2008-16, § 103, 12-5-2005) Sec. 14-218. - Approval. (a) Modifications. Whenever there are practical difficulties involved in carrying out the provisions of this article, the city official shall have the authority to grant modifications for individuals cases, provided the city official shall first find that special individual reason makes the strict letter of this article impractical and the modification is in compliance with the intent and purpose of this article and that such modification does not lessen health, life and fire safety requirements. The details of action granting modifications shall be recorded and entered in the department files. (b) Alternative materials, methods and equipment. The provisions of this article are not intended to prevent the installation of any material or to prohibit any method of construction not specifically prescribed by this article, provided that any such alternative has been approved. An alternative material or method of construction shall be approved where the city official finds that the proposed design is satisfactory and complies with the intent of the provisions of this article, and that the material, method or work offered is, for the purpose intended, at least the equivalent of that prescribed in this article in quality, strength, effectiveness, fire resistance, durability and safety. (c) Required testing. Whenever there is insufficient evidence of compliance with the provisions of this article, or evidence that a material or method does not conform to the requirements of this article, or in order to substantiate claims for alternative materials or methods, the city official shall have the authority to require tests as evidence of compliance to be made at no expense to the jurisdiction as follows: (1) Methods. Test methods shall be as specified in this article or by another recognized test standard. In the absence of recognized and accepted test methods, the city official shall approve the testing procedures. (2) Agency. All tests shall be performed by an approved agency. (3) Reports. Reports of tests shall be retained by the city official for the period required for retention of public records. (d) Material and equipment reuse. Materials, equipment and devices shall not be reused unless such elements have been reconditioned and tested when necessary, placed in good and proper working condition and approved by the city official. (Code 1981, § 11-104; Ord. No. 2008-16, § 104, 12-5-2005) Sec. 14-219. - Violations. (a) Prohibited acts. A person, firm or corporation shall not be in conflict with or in violation of any of the provisions of this article. (b) Notice. The city official and or other duly appointed officials of the city is authorized to serve a notice of violation or order in accordance with all sections of this article. (c) Prosecution. If the notice of violation is not complied with, the city official and or other duly appointed official of the city shall institute the appropriate proceeding at law or in equity to restrain, correct or abate such violation, or to require the removal or termination of the prohibited occupancy of the structure in violation of the provisions of this article or of the order or direction made pursuant thereto. (d) Penalties. Any person who shall violate a provision of this article, or fail to comply therewith, or with any of the requirements thereof shall be prosecuted within the limits provided by local laws and be subject to the penalties provided for in this Code of Ordinances and any other codes adopted by reference. (e) Abatement. The imposition of the penalties herein prescribed shall not preclude the city official of the jurisdiction from instituting appropriate action to restrain, correct or abate a violation, or to prevent illegal occupancy of a building, structure or premises, or to stop an illegal act, conduct business or utilization of the building, structure or premises. (Code 1981, § 11-105; Ord. No. 2008-16, § 105, 12-5-2005) Sec. 14-220. - Notices and orders. (a) Notice to owner or designated agent. Whenever it is determined that there has been a violation of this article, and grounds exist to believe that a violation has occurred or when a building or structure presents an immediate danger to the public or occupants, notice shall be given to the owner or the owner's designated agent responsible therefor in the manner prescribed in subsections (b) and (c) of this section. Notices for condemnation procedures shall also comply with section 14-221(c). (b) Form. (1) Such notice prescribed in subsection (a) of this section shall: a. Be put in writing and delivered as soon as practical after determination has been made that a violation has occurred or imminent danger exists. b. Include a statement of the reasons why it is being used. c. Allow up to 45 days to correct major violations and up to 60 days to correct minor violations after notice has been received from the city official; and there is an exception for the care of premises in section 14-245, a ten-day notice may be required in lieu of the 60 days as determined by the city official. d. If the building or structure is to be vacated or demolished, indicate the time within which vacation or demolition is to be completed. e. State that, if such repairs, reconstruction, alterations, removal or demolition are not voluntarily completed within the stated time as set forth in notice, the city official shall institute such legal proceedings charging the person with a violation of this article. (2) Prior to expiration of the notice, the city official is authorized to extend the time with just cause being documented by the owner or the owner's designated agent. (c) Method of service. Such notice shall be deemed to be properly served if a copy thereof is: (1) Delivered personally to owner or the owner's designated agent; (2) Sent by certified mail addressed to the owner or the owner's designated agent at the last known address; or (3) In the case of an unsafe structure, posted in a conspicuous place in or about the structure affected by such notice. (d) Penalties. Penalties for noncompliance with orders and notices shall be as set forth in section 14-219(d). (e) Recording of notice. If the notice is not complied with nor an appeal filed within the allotted time, the city official may file in the office of superior court of the county a certificate describing the property and certifying that the building or structure is unsafe and that the owner of record has been served. This certificate shall remain on file until such time as the conditions rendering the building or structure unsafe have been abated. At such time, the city official shall file a new certificate indicating that corrective action has been taken and the building or structure is no longer unsafe for that condition. Recording of notices shall not be required for minor violations as determined by the city official. (f) Permits. Whenever a notice involves demolition of a structure by owner or city official or the repair of a structure, the owner or designated agent shall obtain the necessary permits from the building department prior to proceeding. When such work occurs in the historic district established by the historic preservation commission and involves demolition or exterior renovations or modifications, the building department shall not issue such permits without verification that a certificate of appropriateness has been issued by the historic preservation commission. Nothing in this requirement, however, shall prohibit the city official from taking appropriate action when in the interest of public safety. (Code 1981, § 11-106; Ord. No. 2008-16, § 106, 12-5-2005) Sec. 14-221. - Unsafe structures and equipment. (a) Condemnation. When a structure or equipment is found by the city official to be unsafe, or when a structure is found unfit for human occupancy, or is found to present an imminent danger, such structure shall be condemned pursuant to the provisions of this article. (1) Unsafe structures. An unsafe structure is one that is found to be dangerous to the life, health, property or safety of the public or the occupants of the structure by not providing minimum safeguards to protect or warn occupants in the event of fire, or because such structure contains unsafe equipment or is so damaged, decayed, dilapidated, structurally unsafe or of such faulty construction or unstable foundation, that partial or complete collapse is possible. (2) Unsafe equipment. Unsafe equipment includes any boiler, heating equipment, elevator, moving stairway, electrical wiring or device, flammable liquid containers or other equipment on the premises or within the structure which is in such disrepair or condition that such equipment is a hazard to life, health, property or safety of the public or occupants of the premises or structure. (3) Structure unfit for human occupancy. A structure is unfit for human occupancy whenever the city official finds that such structure is unsafe, or presents an imminent danger or, because of the degree to which the structure is in disrepair or lacks maintenance, is unsanitary, vermin- or rat-infested, contains filth and contamination, or lacks ventilation, illumination, sanitary or heating facilities or other essential equipment required by this article, or because the location of the structure constitutes a hazard to the occupants of the structure or to the public. (b) Closing of vacant structures. If the structure is vacant and unfit for human habitation and occupancy, and is not in danger of structural collapse, the city official is authorized to post a placard of condemnation on the premises and order the structure closed up so as not to be a nuisance. Upon failure of the owner to close up the premises within the time specified in the order, the city official is authorized to have the structure closed through any available public agency or by contract or arrangement by private persons and the cost thereof shall be charged against the real estate upon which the structure is located an shall be a lien upon such real estate. If the monetary resources are not available to the city official, the city official shall proceed with notice procedures as outlined in section 14-220. (c) Notice. Whenever the city official has condemned a structure or equipment under the provisions of this section, notice shall be posted in a conspicuous place in or about the structure affected by such notice and served on the owner or the owner's designated agent responsible for the structure or equipment in accordance with section 14-220. (d) Placarding. Upon failure of the owner or the owner's designated agent responsible to comply with the notice provisions within the time given, the city official shall post on the premises or on defective equipment, a placard bearing the term "Unsafe" and a statement of the penalties provided for occupying the premises, operating the equipment or removing the placard. (e) Prohibited occupancy. Any person who shall occupy placarded premises or shall operate placarded equipment, or the owner or owner's designated agent responsible for the premises who shall let anyone occupy placarded premises or operate placarded equipment shall be liable for the penalties provided by this article. (f) Removal of placard. The city official shall remove the condemnation placard whenever the defects upon which the condemnation and placarding action were based have been eliminated. Any person who defaces or removes a condemnation placard without the approval of the city official shall be subject to the penalties provided by this article. (Code 1981, § 11-107; Ord. No. 2008-16, § 107, 12-5-2005) Sec. 14-222. - Emergency measures. (a) Imminent danger. When, in the opinion of the city official, there is imminent danger of failure or collapse of a building or structure which endangers life, or when any structure or part of a structure has fallen and life is endangered by the occupation of the structure, or when there is actual or potential danger to explosives, explosive fumes or vapors or the presence of toxic fumes, gases or materials, or operation of defective or dangerous equipment, the city official is hereby authorized and empowered to order and require the occupants to vacate the premises forthwith. The city official shall cause to be posted at each entrance to such structure a notice reading as follows: "This structure presents an imminent danger and its occupancy has been prohibited by the city official." No person shall enter such structure except for the purpose of securing the structure, making the required repairs, removing the hazardous condition or of demolishing the same. (b) Temporary safeguards. Notwithstanding other provisions of this article, whenever, in the opinion of the city official, there is imminent danger due to an unsafe condition, notice shall be served in accordance with section 14-220.
