(4) Whenever a building, structure or portion thereof has been damaged by fire, flood, earthquake, wind or other cause to the extent that the structural integrity of the buildings or structures is less than it was prior to the damage and is less than the minimum requirement established by the International Building Code (IBC) for new buildings. (5) Whenever any exterior appendages or portion of a building or structure is not securely fastened, attached or anchored such that it is capable of resisting wind, seismic or similar loads as required by the International Building Code (IBC) for new buildings. (6) Whenever for any reason a building, structure or portion thereof is manifestly unsafe or unsanitary for the purpose for which it is being used. (7) Whenever any building, structure or portion thereof as a result of decay, deterioration or dilapidation is likely to fully or partially collapse. (8) Whenever any building, structure or portion thereof has been constructed or maintained in violation of a specific requirement of the standard codes or of a city, county or state law. (9) Whenever any building, structure or portion thereof is in such a condition as to constitute a public nuisance. (10) Whenever any building, structure or portion thereof is unsafe, unsanitary or not provided with adequate egress, or which constitutes a fire hazard, or is otherwise dangerous to human life, or, which in relation to existing use, constitutes a hazard to safety or health by reason of inadequate maintenance, dilapidation, obsolescence or abandonment. Weed means a plant considered undesirable, unattractive or troublesome, especially one growing where it is not wanted. (Code 1981, § 11-1; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987; Ord. of 6-29-2009) Sec. 50-2. - Penalty for violation. Any person who shall create, or continue after notice to abate, a nuisance which tends to annoy the community, to injure the health of the citizens in general, or to corrupt the public morals, shall be punished as provided in section 1-8. (Code 1969, § 9-27; Code 1981, § 12-27) Sec. 50-3. - Abatement procedure. The method of abating nuisances within the city shall be the method prescribed in O.C.G.A. § 41-2-1 et seq. In all cases reasonable notice shall be given to the parties interested of the time and place of the meeting held for the purpose of determining whether a nuisance exists and the ordering the abatement of same. (Code 1969, § 9-26; Code 1981, § 12-26) Sec. 50-4. - Noises—Purpose of prohibitions. The purpose of section 46-5 is to control noises and the nuisance thereby created in such a manner as to cause the least hardship or offense to the greatest number of people. (Code 1969, § 9-22; Code 1981, § 12-22) Sec. 50-5. - Same—Prohibited. The following noises and other noises of the same characteristics, intensity or annoyance are prohibited at all times and at all places within the city: (1) Horns, signaling devices, etc. The sounding of any horn or signaling device on any automobile, motorcycle, bus or other vehicle on any street or public place of the city except as a danger warning; the creation by means of any such signaling device of any unreasonably loud or harsh sound; the sounding of any such device for an unnecessary and unreasonable period of time; the use of any signaling device except one operated by hand or electricity; the use of any horn, whistle or other device operated by engine exhaust; and the use of any such signaling device when traffic is for any reason held up. (2) Radios, phonographs, etc. The use or operation of any radio receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound in such manner as to disturb the peace, quiet and comfort of the neighboring inhabitants or at any time with louder volume than is necessary for convenient hearing for the person of normal hearing who is in the room, vehicle or chamber in which such machine or device is operated and who is a voluntary listener thereto or allowing such use or operation. The operation of any such set, instrument, phonograph, machine or device between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. in such a manner as to be plainly audible at a distance of 50 feet from the building, structure or vehicle in which it is located shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this section. (3) Loudspeakers, amplifiers, etc. The use or operation of any radio, receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph, loudspeaker, sound amplifier or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound which is cast upon the public streets for the purpose of attracting the attention of the public to any building, product, service, merchandise or political candidate, or allowing such use or operation, except as authorized by the city council. (4) Yelling, shouting, etc. Yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling or singing on the public streets, particularly, between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. or at any time or place so as to annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort or repose of persons in any office, or in any dwelling, hotel or other type of residence, or of any persons in the vicinity. (5) Animals, birds, etc. The keeping of any animal or bird which by causing frequent or long continued noise shall disturb the comfort or repose of any persons in the vicinity. (6) Steam whistles. The blowing of any steam whistle attached to any stationary boiler except to give notice of the time to begin or stop work or as a warning of fire or danger, or upon request of proper city authorities. (7) Exhausts. The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of any steam engine, stationary internal combustion engine or motor vehicle except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud or explosive noises therefrom. (8) Defect in vehicle or load. The use of any automobile, motorcycle or other vehicle so out of repair, so loaded or in such manner as to create loud and unnecessary grating, grinding, rattling or other noises. (9) Loading, unloading and opening boxes, etc. The creation of a loud and excessive noise in connection with the loading or unloading of any vehicle, or the opening and destruction of bales, boxes, creates and containers on Sundays, Christmas, New Year's or Thanksgiving or before 7:00 a.m. or after 11:00 p.m.; provided, however, that under emergency conditions the city manager may, in such officer's discretion, grant exceptions thereto. (10) Adjacent to schools, courts, churches, hospitals, etc. The creation of any excessive noise on any street adjacent to any school, institution of learning, church or court while the same is in use, or adjacent to any hospital, which unreasonably interferes with the workings of such institutions, or which disturbs or unduly annoys patients in the hospital; provided conspicuous signs are displayed in such street indicating that the same is a school, hospital, church or court street. (11) Hawkers, peddlers, etc. The shouting and crying of peddlers, hawkers and vendors which disturb the peace and quiet of the neighborhood. (12) Drums, etc. The use of any drum or other instrument or device for the purpose of attracting attention by creation of noise. (13) Firearms and fireworks. The explosion of firecrackers, skyrockets, Roman candles, pinwheels or any other form of fireworks or the unnecessary shooting of any firearms, except as specifically authorized by law or the proper official. (14) Transportation of metal rails, pillars and columns. The transportation of rails, pillars or columns of iron, steel or other material, over and along the streets and other public places upon carts, drays, cars, trucks or in any other manner so loaded as to cause loud noises or as to disturb the peace and quiet on such streets or other public places. (15) Operation of public transportation buses. The causing, permitting or continuing any excessive, unnecessary and avoidable noise in the operation of a public transportation bus. (16) Pile drivers, hammers, etc. The operation of any pile driver, steam shovel, pneumatic hammer, derrick, steam or electric hoist or other appliance, the use of which is attended by loud or unusual noise, except on written permission of the city manager prescribing the locality where and the hours during which such operation is permissible. (17) Blowers. The operation of any noise-creating blower or power fan, or any internal combustion engine, the operation of which causes noise due to the explosion of operating gases or fluids, unless the noise from such blower or fan is muffled and such engine is equipped with a muffler device sufficient to deaden such noise. (18) Air conditioning units. Self-contained, one-room air conditioning units, up to one-ton capacity attached to the outside walls or windows of buildings, and operated for the comfort of the occupants of such buildings, shall not be deemed in violation of this article where proof is established that such units are maintained in good mechanical condition. Air conditioning units of more than one-ton capacity may not be operated except where remote compressors are housed in soundproof rooms, or where attached or immediately adjoining compressors are sound treated or baffled, and cooling coil and condensation water is disposed of, as prescribed by the city manager. (19) Refrigerated trucks or motor vehicles. The operation of refrigeration units on trucks or motor vehicles which creates or causes noise that disturbs the peace and quiet of the neighborhood shall not be allowed within the city limits. (Code 1969, § 9-23; Code 1981, § 12-23; Ord. No. 1987-2, 8-3-1987) Sec. 50-6. - Same—Not to prevent operation of automobiles, etc. The requirements of section 50-5 shall not be construed to prevent the operation of automobiles or light delivery vehicles at any time; provided, however, that such motor vehicles shall at all times be properly muffled and shall be so operated as to create the least possible noise or nuisance. (Code 1969, § 9-24; Code 1981, § 12-24) Sec. 50-7. - Same—City manager may waive requirements. The city manager shall have the right to waive any or all of the requirements of section 50-5, in cases of emergency where the welfare of persons or property may be jeopardized by strict enforcement. (Code 1969, § 9-25; Code 1981, § 12-25) Secs. 50-8—50-58. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - LITTER
FOOTNOTE(S): --- (2) --- State Law reference— Littering prohibited on public and private property, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-42 et seq. Sec. 50-59. - Definitions. For the purpose of this article the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meaning given in this section: Aircraft means any contrivance now known or hereafter invented, used or designed for navigation or for flight in the air. The word aircraft shall include helicopters and lighter-than-air dirigibles and balloons. Authorized private receptacle means a container of watertight construction with a tightfitting lid or cover capable of preventing the escape of contents within. Such receptacles shall have handles or other means for safe and convenient handling and be of such size or sufficient capacity to hold all litter generated between collected periods. Construction site means any private or public property upon which repairs or additions to existing buildings, construction of new buildings, or demolition of existing structures is taking place. Handbill means any printed or written matter, any sample or device, leaflet, pamphlet or any other printed matter of literature which is not delivered by United States mail, including but not limited to material which: (1) Advertises for sale or distribution any merchandise, product, food item or thing; (2) Directs attention to any business, church, recreational activity or commercial establishment, or other activity, for the purpose of either directly or indirectly promoting the interest thereof; or (3) Directs attention to or advertises any meeting, festival, auction, athletic contest, performance, exhibition or event of any kind. Litter means garbage, refuse, and rubbish and all other waste, trash, dead animals, sand, gravel, slag, brick bats or discarded material which, if thrown or deposited as herein prohibited is unsightly or tends to create a danger to public health, safety and welfare. Loading and unloading docks means any dock space or area used by any moving vehicle for the purpose of receiving, shipping and transporting goods, wares, commodities and persons located on or adjacent to any roadway, airport, waterway or land. Private premises means all property including, but not limited to, vacant land or any land, building or other structure designed or used for residential, commercial, business, industrial, institutional or religious purposes, together with any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, fence, porch, steps, vestibule, mailbox and other structure appurtenant thereto. Public place means any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys or other public ways, lakes, rivers, watercourses or fountains and any and all public parks, squares, spaces, grounds, athletic fields, buildings and structures. Public receptacles means any receptacles provided by or authorized by the city. Vehicle means every device in, upon or by, which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon land or water, including devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. (Code 1981, § 11-18; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 50-60. - Penalty. Any person, business, organization, club, or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be punished in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 16-7-43 or as provided in article IV of this chapter. (Code 1981, § 11-33; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 50-61. - Littering prohibited. No person shall deposit any litter within the city except in public receptacles, in authorized private receptacles for collection or in any duly licensed disposal facility. (Code 1981, § 11-19; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 50-62. - Prevention of scattering. Persons placing litter in public receptacles or in authorized private receptacles shall do so in such a manner as to prevent litter from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any public place or private premises. (Code 1981, § 11-20; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 50-63. - Upsetting or tampering with receptacles. No person shall upset or tamper with a public or private receptacle designed or used for the deposit of litter or cause or permit its contents to be deposited or strewn in or upon any public place or private premises. (Code 1981, § 11-21; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 50-64. - Sidewalks and alleys, to be kept free from litter. Persons owning, occupying or in control of any public place or private premises shall keep the sidewalks and alleys adjacent thereto free of litter, and shall maintain such receptacles as may be required by the regulations approved by the city manager. (Code 1981, § 11-22; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 50-65. - Owner to maintain private premises. (a) The owner or person in control of any private premises shall at all times maintain the premises free of litter. (b) The owner or person in control of private premises, shall, if public receptacles are unavailable, maintain authorized private receptacles for collection in such a manner that litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any public place or private premises. (Code 1981, § 11-23; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 50-66. - Littering from vehicles. (a) No person, while the operator of or passenger in a vehicle, shall deposit or throw out litter upon any public place or private premises except into a proper receptacle. (b) No person shall drive or move any truck or other vehicle within the city unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent any load, contents or litter from being blown out or deposited upon any public place or private premises. Nor shall any person drive or move any vehicle or truck within the city, the wheels or tires of which carry onto or deposit in any public place or private premises, mud, dirt, sticky substances, litter or foreign matter of any kind. (Code 1981, § 11-24; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 50-67. - Littering from aircraft. No person in an aircraft shall throw out, drop or deposit within the city any litter. (Code 1981, § 11-25; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 50-68. - Handbills. (a) Public places. No person shall deposit or unlawfully sell any handbill in or upon any public place; provided, however, that it shall not be unlawful on any public place for any person to hand out or distribute without charge, directly to the receiver, any handbill to any person willing to accept it. (b) Private premises. No person shall deposit or unlawfully distribute any handbill in or upon private premises, except by handing or transmitting any such handbill directly to the occupant of such private business. However, a handbill may be securely placed on a private premises, which is not posted against the receiving of handbills or similar material, and such handbill is placed in such a manner as to prevent such handbill from being redeposited by the elements upon any public place or private premises, unless requested by anyone upon such premises not do so. (c) Mailboxes. Mailboxes may not be used when prohibited by federal post office law or regulations. (d) Exemption for newspaper. The provisions of this section shall not apply to the distribution upon private premises only, of newspapers; except that newspapers shall be placed in such a manner as to prevent their being carried or deposited by the elements upon any public place or private premises. (e) Placing handbills on vehicles. No person shall deposit any handbill in or upon any vehicle unless the occupant of a vehicle is present and willing to accept it. (f) Cleanup. It shall be the responsibility of any person distributing handbills to maintain the area which they are utilizing free of any litter caused by or related to such handbill distribution. (Code 1981, § 11-27; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 50-69. - Posting notices prohibited. No person shall post, place or affix any notice, sign, poster, or other paper or device, on public property or in public places, except as may be authorized or required by law. Posting of notices, signs or posters on private premises, is allowed only with prior permission of owner and tenant and in compliance with all other ordinances regulating signs or notices. (Code 1981, § 11-28; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 50-70. - Construction sites. (a) Each contractor shall be responsible for the job site in such a manner that litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any public place or private premises. (b) Litter or other debris, including dirt and mud, deposited as the result of normal construction process upon any public place or private premises, shall be removed by the contractor. It shall be unlawful for such contractor to allow littering to occur and refuse to remove or cleanup. (Code 1981, § 11-29; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 50-71. - Loading and unloading docks. The person owning, operating or in control of a loading or unloading dock shall maintain authorized private receptacles for collection of litter, and shall at all times maintain the dock area free of litter in such a manner that litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any public place or private premises. (Code 1981, § 11-30; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 50-72. - Parking lots. (a) Litter receptacles required. Any public place or private premises containing any provision for parking vehicles shall be equipped with litter receptacles in compliance with this section and the regulations promulgated by the city manager. Such premises shall include but not be limited to such places as grocery stores, shopping centers, outdoor theaters, drive-in restaurants, gasoline service stations, apartment developments, parking lots, and any other place where provisions are made for vehicles to stop or park in a designated area for any purpose. In lieu of compliance with the receptacle requirements, the city manager may approve a plan for litter control through an authorized sweeping program or other means. (b) Number of receptacles. All premises having parking lots shall provide in an easily accessible location, a minimum of two refuse containers for up to 25 spaces and at least one additional refuse container for every 50 additional parking spaces. (c) Specifications. Litter receptacles shall have tightfitting lids or tops and shall be weighted or attached to the ground or other fixed structures as necessary to prevent spillage. A minimum size litter container of 20 gallons shall be used with all containers being an easily identifiable color with proper markings indicating them as litter receptacles. (d) Cleanliness. Premises used for the purposes designated herein shall be kept in a litter-free condition, and all litter shall be removed periodically from the receptacles. (e) Obligation to use receptacles. It shall be the duty and obligation of all persons using the parking areas described in subsection (a) of this section to use such litter receptacles as herein provided for the deposit of any litter upon any such parking lot. (Code 1981, § 11-31; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 50-73. - Litter, declaration of nuisance. To deposit other than in proper receptacles, to scatter, to throw out, to accumulate or to permit to accumulate or scatter litter in other than proper receptacles or waste disposal sites is declared to be a nuisance subject to action by the city for removal and abatement. (Code 1981, § 11-32; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Secs. 50-74—50-91. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - JUNK; TRASH; MOTOR VEHICLES; CARCASSES; UNSAFE BUILDINGS
FOOTNOTE(S): --- (3) --- State Law reference— Abatement of nuisances generally, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-1 et seq. Sec. 50-92. - Declaration of nuisance. It shall be unlawful for any person or business, owner or lessee, tenant, or other, having possession, ownership or control of private property: (1) To deposit, collect, store, maintain, scatter upon, or permit to be deposited, collected, stored, or to remain upon private property any junk, trash, refuse, abandoned property, or vehicle, which is unsightly, unhealthy or hazardous; (2) To permit a condition or use of premises or of a building exterior which is detrimental to the property or health of others or which causes or tends to cause more than slight diminution in the value of other property in the neighborhood in which such premises is located or which will be considered unsightly, unhealthy and/or hazardous. This includes, but is not limited to, the depositing on, scattering over, or keeping up on the premises any of the following: a. Unsheltered storage of lumber, pipes, junk, windows, wire, tires, refuse, trash, unstacked bricks or blocks; b. Unsheltered storage of abandoned, discarded or unused appliances, machinery, equipment, furniture, motor vehicles, cans or containers; c. Any compost pile which is of such nature as to spread or harbor disease, emit unpleasant odors or harmful gases, or attract rodents, or other obnoxious animals or insects, provided, that the presence of earthworms in a compost pile shall not constitute a nuisance; d. Unsanitary items, deleterious septic or disease producing materials, gases, or fluids, unless such material is contained in containers or vessels which prevent leakage and escape, and which deny access to humans, flies, insects, rodents, and animals, and such material is kept in compliance with all federal, state and local laws and regulations concerning it; e. Toxic or poisonous materials, gases, or fluids, unless such material is contained in containers or vessels which prevent leakage and escape, and which deny access to humans, flies, insects, rodents, and animals, and such material is kept in compliance with all federal, state and local laws and regulations concerning it; f. Piles of dirt, gravel, sand, brick, concrete, concrete block, roofing, metal or other similar items, substances or byproducts. (Code 1981, § 11-34; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 50-93. - Duty of maintenance on private property; declaration of nuisance. No person or business owning, leasing, occupying, or having charge of any premises, vacant lots, buildings, structures, or other private property shall maintain an unsafe building or keep such property in an unhealthful or hazardous manner or an unsightly manner causing more than slight diminution in the value of other property, both private and public, in the neighborhood in which such private property is located. The keeping or maintaining of private property in an unsightly, unhealthful or hazardous condition is declared to be a nuisance and is subject to abatement as provided in article IV of this chapter. (Code 1981, § 11-35; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 50-94. - Recycling not a defense. The fact that any junk, or trash or abandoned property is being held for recycling or for further processing of the component parts shall not be a defense to any criminal prosecution or action of abatement under this chapter. It shall not be unlawful for any person or business to possess and store paper products, glass and aluminum cans and containers, if such paper, glass, and aluminum products are to be held for recycling or reprocessing; provided further, that all such storage and possession and any other activity associated with recycling or reprocessing shall be located and carried on solely within a building, except for purposes for loading or unloading such paper, glass or aluminum cans. (Code 1981, § 11-36; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 50-95. - Unsheltered storage of nonoperating vehicles, machinery, and equipment. It shall be unlawful for any person or business, owner, lessee, tenant, or other person having possession or control of private property, to deposit, collect, store, maintain or permit to be deposited, collected, stored, or allowed to remain upon such private property any abandoned vehicle, salvage vehicle, scrap vehicle, other motor vehicles not in good and safe operating condition, and any other vehicles, machinery, implements, or equipment, or any personal property of any kind which is no longer safely usable for the purposes for which it was manufactured. No person or business shall engage in the business of being a dealer in junk or metals, and dismantler, a rebuilder or salvage dealer, as those terms are defined in section 50-1, except that a place of business may be maintained for the purposes of a business office only, provided that all activities associated with the physical dismantling, rebuilding, or salvaging, shall be carried on outside the city limits. Any licensed car dealer or licensed auto repair shop operator shall be allowed to collect and store on the premises wherein such business is carried on, abandoned vehicles, salvage vehicles, and scrap vehicles; provided that such vehicles are properly screened from the view of the general public traveling on any street or thoroughfare within the city. Such screening shall consist of what is commonly referred to as a chainlink fence which is a minimum of six feet in height and constructed of at least 12-gauge galvanized fabric with the mesh on said fabric not exceeding 2¼-inch mesh. Metal filler strips shall be inserted in the mesh on said chainlink fence. All abandoned, salvage or scrap vehicles maintained and stored by such dealer or operator shall be stored within the enclosed screened area and shall be maintained in a way that none of such vehicles are stacked one on top of the other. Any licensed automobile dealer or other repair shop operator shall have 45 days from the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived, in which to comply with the screen requirements described in this section. (Code 1981, § 11-37; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 50-96. - Storage of nonoperating motor vehicles, declaration of nuisance. No person or business owning, leasing, occupying, or having charge of any private property shall allow the unsheltered storage of nonoperating motor vehicles, machinery and equipment, and any condition hereinabove described which is maintained or allowed to be maintained for a period of 30 days or more, by any person or business (except in licensed junkyards, car dealers or auto repair shops in compliance with the screening requirements) within the corporate limits of the city will be declared a nuisance and dangerous to the public safety and health and will be subject to abatement as provided in article IV of this chapter. (Code 1981, § 11-38; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 50-97. - Animal carcasses—Prohibitions on placing. It shall be unlawful for any person or business to place or bury the carcass of any animal in any stream, road, alley or other public place, or to place or bury any such carcass upon the premises of another, or place or keep a carcass on one's own premises, without burying such carcass so deep as to prevent all stench therefrom. (Code 1981, § 11-39; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 50-98. - Same—Burial or processing required. It shall be unlawful for the owner of a domestic animal or domestic fowl which has died within the city limits of the city to refuse or fail to bury such carcass deep enough to prevent stench therefrom, within three hours after the death of animal or fowl; provided any qualified plant or processor shall be allowed to process or dispose of such carcass in accordance with law. The keeping or maintaining of any carcass beyond three hours after death without burying such carcass or providing for disposal by a qualified plant or processor will be deemed an unhealthful and hazardous condition and is declared a nuisance and is subject to abatement as provided in article IV of this chapter. (Code 1981, § 11-40; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Secs. 50-99—50-124. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - NOTICE, ABATEMENT AND PENALTIES
FOOTNOTE(S): --- (4) --- State Law reference— Nuisance abatement and lien procedures described under O.C.G.A. § 41-2-9 do not impair or limit in the power of the municipality to define and declare nuisances and cause their removal or abatement by summary proceedings or otherwise, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-9(f). Sec. 50-125. - Appointment of official. The city council may appoint, or designate that the city manager appoint a city official to exercise the powers prescribed by this article. Sec. 50-126. - Notice to remedy condition; emergency situations. (a) Prior to an action for abatement, whenever the existence of any nuisance defined in this chapter, except those sections dealing with animal carcasses or emergency situations, on any lots or parcels of real estate, buildings or structures situated within this city, shall come to the knowledge of a code enforcement officer or chief of police, it shall be the code enforcement officer's duty to make an investigation or inspection of the specific dwelling, building, structure or property. If the officer's investigation or inspection identifies the existence of any nuisance defined in this chapter, except those sections dealing with animal carcasses or emergency situations, upon that specific dwelling, building, structure or property, then the city official may issue a complaint in rem against the lot, tract or parcel of real property on which such dwelling, building, or structure is situated or where such public health hazard or general nuisance exists and shall cause summons and a copy of the complaint to be served on the interested parties for such dwelling, building or structure. The summons shall notify the interested parties that a hearing will be held before the municipal court, at a date and time not less than 15 days nor more than 45 days after the filing of said complaint. (b) The notice requirement and time period for correction do not apply when dealing with animal carcasses or other emergency situations where the public health, welfare or property are placed in immediate danger by an existing or potentially hazardous, toxic, disease producing or fire producing substance or dilemma. In such situations the city, by and through its elected officials and employees, shall act to protect the citizenry of large from harm. (Code 1981, § 11-41; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 50-127. - Abatement by the city. (a) If, after such notice and hearing, the court determines that a nuisance condition, as provided in articles I through IV of this chapter, exists on the dwelling, building, structure, or property, then the court shall state in writing findings of fact in support of such determination and shall issue and cause to be served upon the interested parties that have answered the complaint or appeared at the hearing an order: (1) If the repair, alteration or improvement of the said dwelling, building or structure can be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the present value of the dwelling, building, or structure, requiring the owner, within the time specified in the order, to repair, alter or improve such dwelling, building or structure, so as to bring it into full compliance with the applicable codes relevant to the cited violation and, if applicable, to secure the structure so that it cannot be used in connection with the commission of drug crimes; or (2) If the repair, alteration, or improvement of the said dwelling, building or structure in order to bring it into full compliance with applicable codes relevant to the cited violations cannot be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the present value of the dwelling, building or structure, requiring the owner, within the time specified in the order, to demolish and remove such dwelling, building or structure, and all debris from the property. (b) If the owner fails to comply with the court's order to repair or demolish the dwelling, building, or structure, the city official may cause such dwelling, building, or structure to be repaired, altered, or improved or to be vacated and closed or demolished. Such abatement action shall commence within 270 days after the expiration of time specified in the order for abatement by the owner. The city official shall cause to be posted on the main entrance of the building, dwelling, or structure a placard with the following words: "This building is unfit for human habitation or commercial, industrial or business use and does not comply with the applicable codes or has been ordered secured to prevent its use in connection with drug crimes or constitutes an endangerment to public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions. The use or occupation of this building is prohibited and unlawful." (c) If the city official has the structure demolished, reasonable effort shall be made to salvage reusable materials for credit against the cost of demolition. The proceeds of any moneys received from the sale of salvaged materials shall be used or applied against the cost of the demolition and removal of the structure, and proper records shall be kept showing application of sales proceeds. Any such sale of salvaged materials may be made without the necessity of public advertisement and bid. The city official and governing authority are relieved of any and all liability resulting from or occasioned by the sale of any such salvaged materials, including, without limitation, defects in such salvaged materials. (Code 1981, § 11-42; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 50-128. - Lien. (a) The amount of the cost of demolition, including all court costs, appraisal fees, administrative costs incurred by the county tax commissioner or municipal tax collector or city revenue officer, and all other costs necessarily associated with the abatement action, including restoration to grade of the real property after demolition, shall be a lien against the real property upon which such cost was incurred. (b) Lien to attach to real property; procedure for collection. (1) The lien shall attach to the real property upon the filing of a certified copy of the order requiring repair, closure or demolition in the office of the clerk of superior court in the county where the real property is located and shall relate back to the date of the filing of the lis pendens notice required under O.C.G.A. § 41-2-12(c). The clerk of superior court shall record and index such certified copy of the order in the deed records of the county and enter the lien on the general execution docket. The lien shall be superior to all other liens on the property, except liens for taxes, to which the lien shall be inferior, and shall continue in force until paid. (2) Upon final determination of costs, fees and expenses incurred in accordance with this chapter, the city official responsible for enforcement actions in accordance with this chapter shall transmit to the appropriate county tax commissioner or municipal tax collector or city revenue officer a statement of the total amount due and secured by said lien, together with copies of all notices provided to interested parties. The statement of the city official shall be transmitted within 90 days of completion of the repairs, demolition, or closure. It shall be the duty of the appropriate county tax commissioner or municipal tax collector or city revenue officer, who is responsible or whose duties include the collection of municipal taxes, to collect the amount of the lien using all methods available for collecting real property ad valorem taxes; provided, however, that the limitation of O.C.G.A. § 48-4-78 which requires 12 months of delinquency before commencing a tax foreclosure shall not apply. A county tax commissioner shall collect and enforce municipal liens imposed pursuant to this chapter in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-5-359.1. The county tax commissioner or municipal tax collector or city revenue officer shall remit the amount collected to the governing authority of the county or municipality whose lien is being collected. (Code 1981, § 11-43; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 50-129. - Foreclosure of lien. (a) Enforcement of liens pursuant to this section may be initiated at any time following receipt by the county tax commissioner or municipal tax collector or city revenue officer of the final determination of costs in accordance with this chapter. The unpaid lien amount shall bear interest and penalties from and after the date of final determination of costs in the same amount as applicable to interest and penalties on unpaid real property ad valorem taxes. An enforcement proceeding pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-4-78 for delinquent ad valorem taxes may include all amounts due under this chapter. (b) The redemption amount in any enforcement proceeding pursuant to this article shall be the full amount of the costs as finally determined in accordance with this article together with interest, penalties, and costs incurred by the city council, county tax commissioner, municipal tax collector, or city revenue officer in the enforcement of such lien. Redemption of property from the lien may be made in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 48-4-80 and 48-4-81. (c) The city council may waive and release any such lien imposed on property upon the owner of such property entering into a contract with the city agreeing to a timetable for rehabilitation of the real property or the dwelling, building or structure on the property and demonstrating the financial means to accomplish such rehabilitation. (Code 1981, § 11-44; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 50-130. - Enforcement of chapter. Enforcement of this chapter may be accomplished by the city in any manner authorized by law or combination thereof, and in addition, any person who by reason of another's violation of any provision of this chapter, who suffers special damage to himself/herself, his/her property or livelihood may bring an action for abatement as allowed in O.C.G.A. § 41-2-1 et seq. (Code 1981, § 11-45; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 50-131. - Penalties and fines. Violations of this chapter, or any provision herein shall be punished in accordance with the penalties allowed under state law and the general penalties described in section 1-8. Conviction of ordinance violations shall be admissible in the trial or hearing of any abatement proceeding involving the same material facts, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-48. (Code 1981, § 11-46; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 50-132. - No notice required prior to citation. (a) The notice and time period for correction required in section 50-126 prior to an abatement proceeding do not apply to the issuance of citations or criminal prosecution. Citations for criminal violations under this chapter may be issued without prior notice. Prior warnings, if any, shall be admissible in the prosecution of any criminal violation under this chapter. (b) In addition to the procedures and remedies in this article, the city official may issue citations for violations of state minimum standard codes, optional building, fire, life safety and other technical codes adopted by this Code, and conditions creating a public health hazard or general nuisance, and seek to enforce such citations in a court of competent jurisdiction prior to issuing a complaint in rem as provided in this article. (Code 1981, § 11-47; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987)

div.head: Chapter 54 - OCCUPATIONAL LICENSES, TAXES AND REGULATIONS
div.p:
FOOTNOTE(S): --- (1) --- State Law reference— Limitation on expanding the power of municipal regulation over any business activity regulated by the public service commission, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6(a)(5); business and occupation taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-5 et seq. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 54-1. - Tax levied. The specific and occupation taxes set forth in this chapter are hereby levied and shall be collected in the amount hereinafter specified upon each and every person engaged in the business, trade or profession, or doing acts named or described herein within the corporate limits of the city during each year. (Code 1981, § 14-1; Ord. of 12-15-1980, § 1) Sec. 54-2. - Registration of business required. No person shall be engaged in, prosecute or carry on any business, trade or profession, either in whole or in part within the corporate limits of the city by maintaining an office, or engage in any business in any manner without having registered the name of said business with the city clerk and paid occupational tax as hereafter provided. (Code 1981, § 14-2; Ord. of 12-15-1980, § 2) Sec. 54-3. - Deadline for payment. Each such occupational tax shall be for each calendar year. Said occupational tax shall be due and payable January 1 of each calendar year and shall be delinquent if not paid by March 15 of each calendar year. (Code 1981, § 14-3; Ord. of 12-15-1980, § 3) Sec. 54-4. - Tax based upon gross receipts. (a) The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Gross receipts means the total revenue of the business or practitioner for the period, including without being limited to the following: (1) Total income without deduction for the cost of goods or expenses incurred; (2) Gain from trading in stocks, bonds, capital assets or instruments of indebtedness; (3) Proceeds from commissions on the sale of property, goods or services; (4) Proceeds from rent, interest, royalty or divided income. Location or office includes any structure or vehicle where a business profession or occupation is conducted, but shall not include a temporary or construction work site which serves a single customer or project, or a vehicle used for sales or delivery by a business or practitioner of a profession. (b) Each person with a location or office in the business, trade, profession, or occupation in the city shall pay an occupation tax based upon gross receipts in exhibits A and B attached to the ordinance from which this section is derived, which are available for public examination on file in the city business license clerk's office. (1) Gross receipts shall not include the following: a. Sales, use or excise tax; b. Sales returns, allowances and discounts; c. Interorganizational sales and transfers between or among the units of a parent-subsidiary controlled group of corporations as defined by 26 USC 1563(a)(1), or between or among the units of a brother-sister controlled group of corporations as defined by 26 USC 1563(a)(2), or between or among the wholly owned partnership or other wholly owned entities; d. Payments made to a subcontractor or an independent agent for services which contributed to the gross receipts in issue; e. Governmental and foundation grants, charitable contributions, or the interest income derived from such funds received by a nonprofit organization which employs salaried practitioners otherwise covered by this chapter, if such funds constitute 80 percent or more of the organization's receipts; and f. Proceeds from sales of goods or services which are delivered to or received by customers who are outside the state at the time of delivery or receipt. (2) The minimum tax based on gross receipts shall be $25.00 and nonrefundable. (Code 1981, § 14-4; Ord. of 12-15-80, § 4; Ord. No. 1995-2, § 1, 3-6-1995) Sec. 54-5. - Filing estimated gross receipts tax return. All taxes levied on the basis of gross receipts under section 54-12 are levied on accounts of business to be transacted during each calendar year. However, for convenience of both the city and the taxpayer, and to eliminate the necessity of making numerous returns, those businesses subject to the tax levied under section 54-12 shall, on or before the times hereinafter set forth, file with the business license clerk the return or application hereinafter specifically provided for showing the gross receipts of that business during the calendar year immediately preceding the year for which the tax is due. This return or application shall be used as an estimate for making payment of the gross receipts tax for the year which it is filed, the actual and final amount of tax levied for business transacted in said year to be paid in accordance with a final return to be made after the termination of said year in accordance with the procedure hereinafter set forth. (Code 1981, § 14-5; Ord. of 12-15-1980, § 5) Sec. 54-6. - Information required on tax return. Every person subject to the occupational tax under section 54-12 for each calendar year shall at the end of the preceding year for which tax was due, and on or before March 15 of said year, make a return in writing to the city clerk, on a form supplied by said clerk for the purpose, setting forth under oath the following information: (1) Style name of the person, firm, company or corporation. (2) Location at which the trade, business or profession is to be conducted. (3) Exact nature of the trade, business or profession for which license is requested. (4) The correct brackets are set forth in the gross brackets classification schedules, that were provided as exhibit B, in the ordinance from which this provision was derived, that includes the full and true amount of the gross sales, receipts, premiums, commissions or other form of measurable returns from the trade, business, or profession during the preceding calendar year. As herein required, the report of gross sales, receipts, premiums, etc., shall include all business done within the state. All the information herein required shall be given under oath by the owner, or a member of the firm, or an officer of a corporation or by an authorized employee having exact knowledge of actual business done. (5) Where business is solicited, sales are made and goods delivered or transactions are completed and occupational tax paid on same in an incorporated town or city other than the city, this amount shall be deducted from the total receipts and such information shall be furnished with the application. (Code 1981, § 14-6; Ord. of 12-15-1980, § 6; Ord. No. 1995-2, § 2, 3-6-1995) Sec. 54-7. - Pro rata remittance when business conducted less than full year. Where a business subject to the gross receipts tax for a particular calendar year has been conducted for only a part of said year, amount of gross receipts for such a part shall be set forth in said return. The return shall also show a figure putting the receipts for such a part of a year on an annual basis, which figure shall bear a reasonable ratio to the amount of gross receipts for such year as the full year bears to such part. The figure shall be used as the estimate of the gross receipts of the business for the next calendar year. (Code 1981, § 14-7; Ord. of 12-15-1980, § 7) Sec. 54-8. - Tax levied under section 54-12; dates payable, delinquent. The amount of tax levied under section 54-12 based on the estimates as set forth in section 54-7, shall be payable to said city at the offices of the city clerk, on January 1 of each year, and delinquent if not paid on or before March 15 of each year. (Code 1981, § 14-8; Ord. of 12-15-1980, § 8) Sec. 54-9. - Adjustment of estimated return. After the end of each year, and on or before March 15 of each year, the owner, proprietor, manager or executive officer of the business liable for said gross receipts tax levied for the preceding year shall file with the business license clerk of said city a signed and sworn return setting forth the actual amount of correct bracket, are set forth in the gross brackets classification schedules, that were provided as exhibit B, in the ordinance from which this provision was derived, of the gross receipts of said business during the preceding calendar year. (1) If the amount of the gross receipts tax for the preceding year, based on the return provided for in this section and on the rate of said tax provided for in this chapter exceeds the amount of gross receipts tax theretofore paid by said business based on the estimate filed pursuant to section 54-5, the difference in said amount shall be due and payable by the taxpayer to the city on or before March 15 of the year in which the return is filed, and shall be delinquent if not paid on or before said date. (2) If the amount of the gross tax for the preceding year, based on the return provided for in this section and on the rate of tax provided for in this chapter, is less than the amount of the gross receipts tax theretofore paid by such business based on the estimate filed pursuant to section 54-5, the difference in said amount shall be refunded by the city to the taxpayer provided application is made therefor by the business within 30 days of its discontinuance; or, if said business continues to be conducted in said city during the year in which said return is filed, such difference in amounts may be credited by the city on the amount of business license tax to be paid to the city by said business for the year in which said return is filed. (Code 1981, § 14-9; Ord. of 12-15-1980, § 9) Sec. 54-10. - Determination of license fee for new business. If a business is begun for the first time on or before January 1 of any calendar year that this chapter is in effect, then the license fee herein assessed against such business shall be determined as follows: The city clerk, upon registration and application for license for such business shall issue a business license for the year in which said registration and application is made, and the estimated fee for such license shall be computed according to the estimate by the business of its taxable gross revenue for one calendar year. The annual estimated fee, as so determined, shall be divided by 12, in order to arrive at a monthly fee amount. Such monthly fee shall then be multiplied by the actual number of months remaining in said first year of which the business can operate; the product being the estimated license fee for the first year's business operation. The transaction of business during any month, or portion thereof, for the purpose of this provision, shall be deemed to have been the transaction of business for the entire month. (Code 1981, § 14-10; Ord. of 12-15-1980, § 10) Sec. 54-11. - Businesses not listed. Should any person, firm or corporation be in a business or commence a business not listed in this chapter, then the city clerk of said city shall set the special or license tax on such business. Any person, firm or corporation being dissatisfied with the decision of the said city clerk shall have the right of appeal to the city council, provided said person, firm or corporation makes such appeal in writing to said city council within 30 days of the disputed decision of said city clerk. (Code 1981, § 14-11; Ord. of 12-15-1980, § 11) Sec. 54-12. - Gross receipts tax levy and classifications. (a) For the purpose of this chapter, every person, firm, company or corporation engaged in trade, business, or profession requiring licenses are classified in accordance to their main line of business as defined in the Standard Industrial Classification Manual, Executive Office of the President, Office of Management and Budget, and profitability classes are assigned in accordance with Statistics of Income, Business Income Tax Returns, U.S. Treasury Department, Internal Revenue Service. In the case where a person, firm, company or corporation is engaged in more than one line of business, taxes will be levied on the basis of the dominant business activity of the licensee. (b) The six separate classifications of class 1 through class 6, that were provided as exhibit A in the ordinance from which this provision was derived, so as to provide for the determination of the occupational tax to be levied as a fixed sum and measured by taxable gross revenue, the purpose of which is to recognize the ability of businesses to pay as determined by nationwide averages. All separate businesses, engaged in more than one business activity, shall be classified on the basis of their dominant business activity, except that persons whose dominant business activity is legally exempted or otherwise limited by city ordinances or by state law from the tax, shall be classified according to his/her principal subsidiary business, if any, which is subject to the levy and assessment of an occupational tax. The subclassification of all businesses within each classification as to fixed units of taxation, that is, bracket ranges of taxable gross revenue against which there are applied fixed rates, are set forth in the gross brackets classification schedules, that were provided as exhibit B, in the ordinance from which this provision was derived. (c) Determination of license fee herein levied and assessed shall be determined in accordance with the following formula: (1) Determination of the taxable gross revenue as defined by this chapter and the rules and regulations promulgated in connection therewith. (2) Classification of the subject business by referring to exhibit A, the classification schedule in the ordinance from which this provision was derived. (3) Determination of the license fee on volume of gross revenue that was provided as exhibit B, in the ordinance from which this provision was derived, gross brackets classification schedule, using the information as a result of the determination in subsections (c)(1) and (2) of this section. (Code 1981, § 14-12; Ord. of 12-15-1980, § 12) Sec. 54-13. - Specific occupation, privilege, telephone service and insurance premium taxes. (a) Certain businesses, occupations, professions, trades, performances and events are hereby declared not subject to the schedules of taxation imposed by section 54-12, and are hereby taxed, for the year, payable March 15, if not otherwise indicated, or a prorated part of a year, in the amounts as established by the city council from time to time. (b) Businesses paying the privilege license fee for alcoholic beverages shall apply for renewal of their licenses and pay said fee by January 1 of each year, or cease sales of alcoholic beverages. The gross volume of alcoholic beverage sales may be deducted from total gross receipts of the business. Such businesses shall pay an additional occupational tax based on their dominant line of business if other than alcoholic beverages. (c) Each company shall pay, in addition to any license fee imposed in subsection (a) of this section, an amount equal to two percent of the gross direct premiums received during the preceding calendar year from policies of fire and casualty insurance issued upon property and business located within the corporate limits of the city. The term "gross direct premiums," as used in this subsection, means gross direct premiums as that term is used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4 of the insurance code of the state. The term "fire and casualty insurance," as used in this subsection, means insurance coverage as that term is defined in sections O.C.G.A. §§ 33-7-3, 33-7-5 and 33-7-6 of the insurance code of the state. (d) Public utilities. The percent of gross receipts is as per special ordinances, contracts, or franchise agreement. (e) Taxation of professionals. Practitioners of professions are: (1) Physicians licensed under O.C.G.A. tit. 43, ch. 34; (2) Osteopaths licensed under O.C.G.A. tit. 43, ch. 34; (3) Chiropractors; (4) Podiatrists; (5) Dentists; (6) Optometrists; (7) Psychologists; (8) Veterinarians; (9) Landscape architects; (10) Land surveyors; (11) Practitioners of physiotherapy; (12) Public accountants; (13) Embalmers; (14) Funeral directors; (15) Civil, mechanical, hydraulic or electrical engineers; (16) Architects; and (17) Marriage and family therapists, social workers and professional counselors. Such term shall not include a practitioner who is an employee of a business, if the business pays an occupation tax. (f) Practitioners of professions, as defined in subsection (e) of this section, shall elect for their occupation tax to be either: (1) The occupation tax as set forth in this chapter; or (2) A tax of $175.00 for each practitioner who is licensed to provide the service, such tax to be paid as at the practitioner's office or location. Such election shall be made prior to payment of occupation tax. Such election shall be changed for subsequent calendar years only by a written request filed by the professional on or before February 1 of the year in which the election is to be changed. (g) Out-of-state businesses. Persons or businesses from out of state with no office or location in the state subject to an occupation tax under this section shall be required to pay an occupation tax to only one local municipal government in the state. Such local government shall be the government of the municipal corporation or county in which the largest dollar volume of business is done or services are performed by the person. Such persons submitting documentation to the city showing payment of a local business or occupation tax to another local government in the state shall be exempt from the occupation tax levied by this section. Out-of-state businesses with no location in the state shall be assessed occupation taxes based on the gross receipts of the business as defined in O.C.G.A. § 14-13-7 which are reasonably attributed to sales or services in the state. (h) Real estate brokers are as follows: (1) They shall be subject to the occupation tax under the tax imposed by this article only if they maintain a principal or branch office in the city; (2) If their offices are located outside the city and they sell property inside the city they shall be subject to the occupation tax based upon the gross receipts from sales of property located within the city. (Code 1981, § 14-13; Ord. of 12-15-1980, § 13; Ord. No. 1985-1, 3-4-1985; Ord. No. 1985-5, 9-9-1985; Ord. No. 1995-2, § 3, 3-6-1995) Sec. 54-14. - Delinquency penalty. All licenses under this chapter which are not paid for 90 days from the due date of the tax or at time of commencement of business if later, will bear penalty at the rate of ten percent of the amount due and unpaid or $25.00, whichever is greater. (Code 1981, § 14-14; Ord. of 12-15-1980, § 14; Ord. No. 1990-2, 3-19-1990) Sec. 54-15. - Penalty for failure to register. Any person or other entity exercising or carrying on any trade, business, profession or operating any establishment within the city, for which a license or payment of an occupation tax is required by this chapter, without first having registered as provided in section 54-2 and paying the appropriate license or occupation fee, shall be liable for a fine not exceeding $200.00. For the purpose of this section, each day for which said license or occupation fee is not paid shall be deemed a new violation and subject to the same penalty. (Code 1981, § 14-15; Ord. of 12-15-1980, § 15; Ord. No. 1989-3, § 1, 4-17-1989) Sec. 54-16. - Locations of businesses. Occupational license granted under this chapter shall not authorize the holder to exercise or carry on the trade, business, or profession named herein at any other place than that mentioned in said license. (Code 1981, § 14-16; Ord. of 12-15-1980, § 16) Sec. 54-17. - License or occupational tax receipt to be displayed. All persons shall exhibit and display the license or occupational tax receipt issued to them in a conspicuous place in their business establishment if any in the city. Any transient or nonresident person, firm or corporation doing business within the city shall carry such license or occupational tax receipt either upon his/her person or in any vehicle or other conveyance which is used in such business and such person shall exhibit the same to any authorized enforcement officer of the city when so requested. (Code 1981, § 14-17; Ord. of 12-15-1980, § 17) Sec. 54-18. - Change of address. Any person moving from one location to another shall notify the city clerk of such move and the new address in writing on a form provided by the city clerk no later than the day of moving. The same license or receipt for occupational tax will be valid at the new location if said new location conforms to the zoning regulations of the city, as set forth in exhibit A to this Code. (Code 1981, § 14-18; Ord. of 12-15-1980, § 18) Sec. 54-19. - Licenses or occupational tax receipts not transferable. Business licenses or occupational tax receipts shall not be transferable and a transfer of ownership shall be considered in the same light as the termination of such business and the establishment of a new business. Therefore, a new occupational license tax shall be required for the new owner of the business. (Code 1981, § 14-19; Ord. of 12-15-1980, § 19) Sec. 54-20. - Separate businesses. Where a business is conducted at more than one location or place, each location or place shall be considered a separate business under the terms of this chapter and a separate occupational license tax shall be levied and paid. (Code 1981, § 14-20; Ord. of 12-15-1980, § 20) Sec. 54-21. - Duration of license, or occupational tax period. Such license, referred to in this chapter, shall automatically expire on December 31 of the year of its issuance. (Code 1981, § 14-21; Ord. of 12-15-1980, § 21) Sec. 54-22. - Casual and isolated activity. Nothing herein contained shall be interpreted so as to require any person who may engage in casual or isolated activity and commercial transactions, where such involve personal assets and are not the principal occupation of the individual, to obtain a business license or pay occupational tax therefor. (Code 1981, § 14-22; Ord. of 12-15-1980, § 22) Sec. 54-23. - Responsible persons. Whenever in this chapter, the term "dealer" or "person" is used, as principal, but in his, her or their absence any agent, clerk, or employee shall be subject to the penalties herein imposed, should the said business be carried on without registering and paying the required occupational license tax in the same manner as if he, she or they were the proprietors of said business. (Code 1981, § 14-23; Ord. of 12-15-1980, § 23) Sec. 54-24. - Issue of execution shall be made for failure to pay license or occupational tax. In addition to any other penalties provided hereinbefore for violation of this chapter, in the event any person shall fail to pay the tax provided herein as and when the same has become due, the clerk of the city shall issue an execution against the said person, firm, or corporation so delinquent, and his/her or its property, for the amount of license tax prescribed by this chapter for the carrying-on of said business. (Code 1981, § 14-24; Ord. of 12-15-1980, § 24) Sec. 54-25. - Veteran's license. Persons who can qualify for a state veteran's free license must secure such license from the state and present same to the city clerk, who will honor the same and issue a city license. (Code 1981, § 14-25; Ord. of 12-15-1980, § 25) Sec. 54-26. - Exemptions. No occupation tax shall be levied upon the following: (1) Any practitioner whose office is maintained by and who is employed in practice exclusively by: a. The United States; b. The state; c. A municipality or county of the state; or d. Instrumentality of the United States or the state or a municipality or county of the state; (2) Those businesses regulated by the state public service commission; (3) Those electrical service businesses organized under O.C.G.A. tit. 46 ch. 3; (4) Any farm operation for the production from or on the land of agricultural products, but not including any agriculture business; (5) Nonprofit agricultural product cooperative marketing associations pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 2-10-105; (6) Motor common carriers pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 46-7-15; (7) Persons purchasing guano, meats, meal, flour, bran, cotton seed or cotton seed meal or hulls in carload lots for distribution among the purchasers for use and not sale pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-5-355; (8) Persons selling or introducing into the city agricultural products or livestock, including animal products, raised in the state when the sale and introduction are made by the producer of the product and the sale is made within 90 days of the introduction of the product into the city (see note 1 at the end of this section); (9) Persons who qualify for a state veteran's free license must secure such license from the state and present same to the city clerk, who will honor same and issue a city license; (10) State and local authority or nonprofit organization pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-13(5); (11) Depository institutions pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93 (see note 2 at the end of this section); or (12) Any business where the levy of such occupation tax is prohibited by the laws of the state or the United States (see note 3 at the end of this section). Note. 1. See O.C.G.A. § 48-5-356. 2. See this statute regarding the collection on occupation tax from banks and other financial institutions. 3. The city may wish to provide an exemption from the occupation tax, administrative fee and/or regulatory fee for charitable organizations. If so, the chapter provisions providing an exemption should recite that the exemption is part of a plan by the city to encourage such business, pursuant to state law, and should be narrowly defined to allow only true charitable organizations to take advantage of the provision. (Code 1981, § 14-26; Ord. of 12-15-1980, § 26) Sec. 54-27. - Administration of chapter. The city clerk shall administer and enforce the provisions of this chapter for levy, assessment and collection of license fees and penalties imposed herein. (Code 1981, § 14-27; Ord. of 12-15-1980, § 27) Sec. 54-28. - Rules and regulations. The city clerk shall have the power and authority to make and publish reasonable rules and regulations not inconsistent with this chapter or other laws of the city and the state, or the constitution of the state or the United States, for the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this chapter and the collection of the license or occupational tax hereunder. (Code 1981, § 14-28; Ord. of 12-15-1980, § 28) Sec. 54-29. - Regulatory fee. (a) An annual regulatory fee shall be imposed on persons engaged in the following businesses: Every person subject to payment or regulatory fee levied by this chapter shall display a current regulatory fee certificate in a conspicuous place at the location for which such certificate was issued. If a tax payer does not have a permanent location within the city, the regulatory fee certificate shall be shown to any police officer (or any other person charged with enforcing this chapter) upon request. (b) The amount of the regulatory fee shall be as established by the city council from time to time. (Code 1981, § 14-29; Ord. No. 1995-2, § 5, 3-6-1995) Secs. 54-30—54-46. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC DANCE PERMITS
Sec. 54-47. - Required; definition. (a) It shall be unlawful to operate or conduct a public dance in the city without having first obtained a permit therefor as is herein required. (b) For the purposes hereof, a public dance is defined as a gathering of people at a public place for the purpose of dancing, irrespective of whether admission is charged or irrespective of whether said dance is open to the general public or by invitation only. (Code 1981, § 14-30; Ord. of 1-6-1975, § 1) Sec. 54-48. - Application for permit. (a) Application for a permit for a public dance shall be made to the chief of police or the chief's delegate and shall contain the following information: (1) The full true name and any other names used by the applicant, as well as the name of the person or organization/business entity sponsoring the public dance. a. If the application is made on behalf of a corporation, partnership, limited liability company, other business entity or civic organization, the name of the corporation, partnership, limited liability company, other business entity or civic organization shall be set forth exactly as shown in its articles of incorporation or charter, together with the place and date of incorporation, place and date of registration, and the names and addresses of each of its current officers and directors. The corporation, partnership, limited liability company, other business entity or civic organization applying for a permit shall attach to the application a copy of its articles of incorporation or bylaws. The corporation, partnership, limited liability company, other business entity or civic organization applying for a permit shall designate one of its officers to act as its responsible managing officer. Such designated person shall complete and sign all application forms required of an individual applicant under this section, but only one application fee shall be charged. b. If the person, corporation, partnership, limited liability company, other business entity or civic organization on whose behalf the permit is being filed is doing business under a trade name, the applicant shall attach a copy of the registration statement, verified by affidavit, filed with the city clerk. (2) The present address and telephone number of the applicant and person or organization/business entity sponsoring the public dance. (3) Date of birth and social security number for the applicant and/or designated managing officer of the organization/business entity sponsoring the public dance. (4) Acceptable written proof that the applicant and/or designated managing officer of the organization/business entity sponsoring the public dance is at least 18 years of age. (5) Address of the premises where the public dance will be held, conducted or carried on. (6) The name and address of the owner and/or lessor of the real property upon which the public dance is to be held, conducted or carried on and a copy of the lease or rental agreement. (7) The true names and addresses of two responsible persons over the age of 21 who, on the date of the public dance for which a permit is requested, will remain on the premises of the location where the public dance will be held, conducted, or carried on, from the commencement of the public dance until its end thereafter. (b) Application must be made 30 days prior to the date of the proposed dance and shall be made on forms prepared by the city for that purpose. (Code 1981, § 14-31; Ord. of 1-6-1975, § 2) Sec. 54-49. - Investigation of applicant. It shall be the duty of the chief of police to make or cause to be made an investigation into each application. In conducting the investigation, the chief of police may consider the following qualification standards: (1) The application meets all the requirements contained in this article; (2) The applicant has not made a material misrepresentation in the application; (3) The applicant, officers, directors or members of the organization/business entity sponsoring the public dance have been convicted of, pled guilty to or entered a plea of nolo contendre for acts involving moral turpitude where the underlying conduct relates to the applicant's fitness to operate or conduct a public dance involving a gathering of people at a public place; (4) The building or structure where the proposed public dance is to be held complies with all applicable ordinances and/or laws including, but not limited to, health, zoning, distance, fire and safety requirements and standards; (5) Whether a previous permit or license issued to the applicant, officers, directors or members of the organization/business entity sponsoring the public dance by any state or subdivision thereof or by the federal government has been revoked or suspended and the reasons therefor; and/or (6) The applicant, officers, directors or members of the organization/business entity sponsoring the public dance are, in the judgment and discretion of the city council, unfit to have a permit because the manner in which he/she or they have conducted prior or current business dealings has warranted unusual police observation and inspection in order to prevent the violation of any law or regulation relating to such business. (Code 1981, § 14-32; Ord. of 1-6-1975, § 3) Sec. 54-50. - Denial. (a) If, as a result of the investigation authorized by this article, the applicant's qualifications or business responsibility are found to be unsatisfactory, the police chief shall write on the application the reasons for such disapproval. Within 14 business days after the date upon which the application was filed, the police chief shall mail to the applicant a notice of denial stating the reasons for denial of the permit. The notice shall be deemed complete when mailed. (b) The chief of police, in denying an application for a permit, shall be empowered to authorize the conduct of the public dance on a date, at a time, or in a location, different from that named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall, within five days after notice of the action of the chief of police, file a written notice of acceptance with the chief of police. An alternate permit shall conform to the requirements of and shall have the effect of a permit issued under this article. (c) No application for a permit will be considered for any applicant who has submitted a prior application which has been denied, withdrawn or otherwise disposed of within the past 30 days. Sec. 54-51. - Issuance. Upon approval of the chief of police, the city clerk or chief of police shall be authorized to issue a permit for said dance to the person or persons requesting same. There shall be no charge for the issuance of said permit; however, no such permit shall be issued to a person who is not a person of good moral character, nor to a corporation or organization which is not represented by a person of good moral character. (Code 1981, § 14-33; Ord. of 1-6-1975, § 4) Sec. 54-52. - Revocation or suspension. The city manager or the chief of police shall have the authority to revoke or suspend a permit issued under this article upon application of the standards for issuance as set forth in this article. Sec. 54-53. - Appeal. (a) Any person aggrieved by an adverse permit decision of the chief of police may appeal to the city manager. Notification of appeal to the city manager must be in writing and must be submitted to the city clerk within ten days after notice of the denial was sent to the applicant. The city manager shall act upon the appeal within 14 days after the notification of appeal has been received. (b) Any person aggrieved by an adverse appeal decision of the city manager may appeal to the city council. Notification of appeal to the city council must be in writing and must be submitted to the city clerk within ten days after the adverse appeal decision of the city manager. The city council shall act upon the appeal within 30 days after the notification of appeal has been received. Sec. 54-54. - Premises. It shall be unlawful to conduct a public dance in any hall or place which is not equipped with sufficient and adequate exits of three feet or more in width; no hall or building which is not provided with at least two exits of three feet or more in width shall be used for such purposes. (Code 1981, § 14-34; Ord. of 1-6-1975, § 5) Sec. 54-55. - Auxiliary police. Each such public dance shall be attended by at least two police officers, auxiliary or regular, whose duty it shall be to supervise and patrol at said dance. The person or organization sponsoring said dance shall be responsible for all expenses incurred in the hiring of said police officers. (Code 1981, § 14-35; Ord. of 1-6-1975, § 6) Secs. 54-56—54-83. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - FINANCIAL INSTITUTION LICENSES
Sec. 54-84. - Business license tax. (a) Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93, there is hereby levied for each calendar year, an annual business license tax upon state and national banking associations, federal savings and loan associations and state building and loan associations a business license tax at the rate of 0.25 percent of the gross receipts of said institutions. The term "gross receipts" means gross receipts as that term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this section, the minimum amount of business license tax due from any depository financial institution pursuant to this section shall be $1,000.00 per year. The tax levied pursuant to this section shall be assessed and collected based upon the information provided in said term. (c) The due date of taxes levied by this section shall be April 1 of each calendar year. (Code 1981, § 14-39; Ord. No. 1983-7, § 2, 11-7-1983) Secs. 54-85—54-111. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - INSURANCE LICENSES

Const. art. IX, § IV, ¶ I(c); powers of municipal corporations to impose license fees on life insurance companies, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8; local tax on life insurance companies, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1; local tax on other than life insurance companies, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2. No. 1994-2, § 1, 11-21-1994) Sec. 54-113. - Fee for insurers insuring certain risks at additional business locations. No. 1994-2, § 2, 11-21-1994) Sec. 54-114. - Agency license fees; independent agencies, brokers, etc., not otherwise licensed. (Code 1981, § 14-42; Ord. No. 1983-4, § 3, 9-19-1983; Ord. No. 1984-3, § 3, 5-21-1984; Ord. No. 1994-2, § 3, 11-21-1994) Sec. 54-115. - Gross premiums tax—Imposed on life insurers. There is hereby levied for teach calendar year an annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums upon each insurer writing life, accident and sickness insurance within the city in an amount equal to one percent of the gross direct premiums received during the preceding calendar year in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1. The term "gross direct premiums," as used in this section, means gross direct premiums as that term is used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4.
