No. 1994-2, § 4, 11-21-1994) Sec. 54-116. - Same—Imposed upon all other insurers. The term "gross direct premiums," as used in this section, means gross direct premiums as that term is used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2(a). No. 1994-2, § 5, 11-21-1994) Sec. 54-117. - Due date for license fees. License fees imposed in sections 54-112 through 54-114 shall be due and payable on the January 1 of each calendar year. ARTICLE V. - PAWNBROKERS AND DEALERS IN PRECIOUS METALS
FOOTNOTE(S): --- (3) --- State Law reference— Pawnbrokers generally, O.C.G.A. § 44-12-130 et seq.; municipal authorities may license pawnbrokers, define their powers and privileges by ordinance, impose taxes upon them, revoke their licenses, and exercise such general supervision, O.C.G.A. § 44-12-136. Sec. 54-148. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Dealer in precious metals and gems. (1) The term "dealer in precious metals and gems" means a person, whether known as a redemption center, gold and silver dealer, pawnshop, or any other name, either owner or manager whose business involves receiving by buying or trading jewelry, gems, or precious or semiprecious stones. (2) The term "dealer in precious metals and gems" does not include purchases from licensed wholesalers in the normal course of business, or pawnbrokers who only take precious metals or gems on pawn or pledge. Employee. (1) The term "employee" means any person employed or allowed to perform duties, whether or not such person receives a salary, wages or compensation or consideration. (2) The term "employee" does not include the person covered on the license or renewal application. Goods, whenever used in this article, shall carry its normal meaning, and further, it should be construed in the broadest sense allowable and includes all forms of personal property. Owner means any person or partner or stockholder owning 25 percent or more of a business. Pawnbroker means any person, who shall in any manner lend or advance money or other things for profit on the pledge or possession of personal property, or other valuable things other than securities or written evidences of indebtedness or who deals in the purchasing of personal property or other valuable things on condition of selling the same back to the seller at a stipulated price. (Code 1981, § 14-61; Ord. No. 1984-4, § 1-1, 6-4-1984) Sec. 54-149. - Violations; penalties. Any person licensed hereunder who shall: (1) Fail to make any entry of any required item in this permanent record book; (2) Make any false entry therein; (3) Falsify, obliterate, record so that information is illegible, destroy or remove from his/her place of business, such permanent record book; (4) Refuse to allow any duly authorized law enforcement officer to inspect such permanent record book, or any goods in his/her possession, during the ordinary hours of business or any reasonable time, or refuse to allow any member of the general public to inspect goods in his/her possession being held under pawn or purchase within the seven-day purchase and 30-day pawn dates, pursuant to section 54-163 during ordinary hours of business; (5) Fail to maintain a record of each pawn or purchase transaction for at least four years; (6) Violate any other provisions of this article; shall be guilty of a misdemeanor as defined by state law, and operation of any business hereunder in violation of any provision of this article shall constitute a separate offense for each day of operation. (Code 1981, § 14-85; Ord. No. 1984-4, § 1-25, 6-4-1984) Sec. 54-150. - Licenses required. Every person doing business in the city, as a pawnbroker or dealer in precious metals or gems as defined in section 54-148, prior to commencing business shall make proper application for and receive the appropriate business license as set forth in section 54-151. (Code 1981, § 14-62; Ord. No. 1984-4, § 1-2, 6-4-1984) Sec. 54-151. - Application for license and permit. (a) Applicants for license or permit shall file a written, sworn application on a form provided by the city clerk, signed by the applicant if an individual, by the partner making application if a partnership, and by the president if a corporation, with the city clerk showing: (1) The name or address of the principals, agents and employees of the applicant's business during the time that it is proposed that it will be carried on in the city, the local address or addresses of such person or persons; capacity in which such person or persons will act (as proprietor, agent, employee or otherwise); the name and the address of the person, firm or corporation for whose account the business will be carried on, if any; and if a corporation, under the laws of what state it is incorporated; (2) The fingerprints of the principals, agents or employees of the applicant's business and other evidence which establishes to the satisfaction of the city clerk of the city subject to the approval of the mayor and council of the city the good character of such persons to carry on the business; (3) The place or places in the city where it is proposed to carry on the applicant's business, the zoning district at said place or places, and the length of time during which it is proposed that said business shall be conducted; (4) The place, other than the permanent place of business of the applicant, where the applicant within the six months next preceding the date of said application conducted any other type of business, stating the nature thereof and giving the post office and street address or office in which such business was conducted; (5) A brief statement of the nature and the character of the advertising done or proposed to be done in order to attract customers; (6) Whether or not the person having the management or supervision of the applicant's business have been convicted of a crime or violations of any municipal ordinance, the nature of such offense and the punishment assessed therefor; (7) Credentials from the person for which the applicant proposes to do business, authorizing the applicant to act as such representative; and (8) Such other information as to the identity or character of the person having the management or supervision of the applicant's business or the method or plan of doing such business as the city clerk of the city may deem proper to fulfill the purpose of this article in the protection of the public good. (b) The application shall state thereon that, "It is unlawful for any person to make a false statement on this application." Any false statement made on the application form will be cause to revoke the license issued thereunder and also shall constitute a violation of state law. (Code 1981, § 14-63; Ord. No. 1984-4, § 1-3, 6-4-1984) Sec. 54-152. - Exclusions; exceptions. Businesses which limit the purchase of used valuables to the acceptance of trade-ins for credit for new goods or the dispensing of refunds in regard to valuables previously purchased from said business, shall not be required to be licensed as prescribed by this article nor to be covered under the provisions of this article. (Code 1981, § 14-64; Ord. No. 1984-4, § 1-4, 6-4-1984) Sec. 54-153. - Employee permit. Each person authorized or allowed to conduct any place of business covered under this article shall be considered an employee and must have an approved license or an employee permit, and this permit must be displayed along with the business license in accordance with license display requirements. (Code 1981, § 14-65; Ord. No. 1984-4, § 1-5, 6-4-1984) Sec. 54-154. - Business license fee. (a) All businesses licensed hereunder, shall pay an annual license fee. The amount of the pawnshop license fee and initial registration shall be as established by the city council from time to time. (b) Any co-owner, agent, employee or any other persons authorized to transact business, other than the licensee, shall be required to have employee permits for each license under which he/she operates or transacts business. There shall be no proration or refund of any license fee. Licenses and permits issued hereunder shall be a personal privilege and shall not be transferable, except that employee permits may be transferred from one licensed business to another. (Code 1981, § 14-66; Ord. No. 1984-4, § 1-6, 6-4-1984) Sec. 54-155. - Character qualifications. No license or employee permit shall be issued to or renewed for any person who conducts or is employed in a business in which such owner or employee has, within five years of issuance or renewal, been convicted of, or pled guilty or nolo contendere to, any felony involving any federal or state offense or any federal or state misdemeanor involving theft-related offenses; and the licensee will submit the identity of all owners and employees to the city clerk of the city, on a continuing basis as changes occur. This information is to be forwarded to the city police department for the purpose of allowing a complete check in order that these character qualifications be fulfilled prior to the issuance or renewal of any license or permit issued hereunder. (Code 1981, § 14-67; Ord. No. 1984-4, § 1-7, 6-4-1984) Sec. 54-156. - Location of businesses. All businesses licensed hereunder shall be located in strict compliance with the city zoning ordinance, as set forth in chapter 94, and at a location with an identifiable street address, which shall be stated on the license or renewal application along with other required information; and no business licensed hereunder shall change its address without giving advance notice to the city clerk, the city building inspector and the city police department, and receiving approval of the change, said approval being granted if the new location complies with this article and the city zoning ordinance. (Code 1981, § 14-68; Ord. No. 1984-4, § 1-8, 6-4-1984) Sec. 54-157. - Records to be kept. (a) All pawnbrokers and dealers in precious metals and gems, in addition to other records, shall keep books wherein shall be entered an accurate description of all property received by or pledged or sold to them. (1) Such description shall include: a. The brand name of the article; b. Any identifying mark; c. Number; d. Initial; e. Social security number; or f. Name of any person or company and a statement of the kind of material of which it is made. (2) In such books there shall be entered also: a. The name, age, address, signature and identification number from a driver's license or similar identification of the person by who same was delivered, deposited or sold; b. The name of the broker, agent or employee receiving the item; c. The time when such transaction occurred; d. The price paid for the goods purchased; and e. The check number issued, if applicable. (b) A permanent bound set of the pawn tickets shall constitute the book required by this article. All books and records required by this article and items pledged or sold hereunder shall at all times be subject to inspection and examination by any law enforcement officer of the city or any federal law enforcement officer. Any person engaged in any business licensed hereunder, who shall fail or refuse to keep the records as provided in this article, or who shall make false entries concerning the transaction or who shall fail or refuse to permit an inspection by any of the aforementioned law enforcement officers of said records and of the property deposited with or sold to such person shall be guilty of a violation of this article. (Code 1981, § 14-69; Ord. No. 1984-4, § 1-9, 6-4-1984) Sec. 54-158. - Standard forms required. All businesses licensed hereunder shall use a standard form for pawn and a standard form for purchase, and no ticket may be used for a dual purpose. Standard forms may differ only by the name of the business and business address. The design of this form shall be provided by the city police department and the forms shall be numbered and chronologically used and sent to the city police department. Each number missing from the chronological sequence shall be considered a separate violation of this article. (Code 1981, § 14-70; Ord. No. 1984-4, § 1-10, 6-4-1984) Sec. 54-159. - Weekly report to city police. Every business licensed hereunder shall make a weekly report in writing to the city police department of all items pledged or purchased during the preceding weekly period ending on Saturday night at 10:00 p.m. Such report shall be due in the office of the chief of police of the city by 11:00 a.m. Monday following the week covered by the report. Such reports shall be legibly written or typed in English and shall show: (1) The name and address of the business; (2) The times of transactions; (3) The serial number of the pawn or purchase tickets; (4) The amount paid or advanced; (5) A full description of articles, including kind, style, material, color, design kind and number of stones in jewelry and all identifying names, marks, numbers, initials or social security numbers; and (6) A description of the person selling or pawning said item including name, address, color, weight and height. (Code 1981, § 14-71; Ord. No. 1984-4, § 1-11, 6-4-1984) Sec. 54-160. - Identification required. All businesses licensed hereunder shall, when receiving in pawn or purchasing goods, require a proper identification, driver's license or military identification (ID) card or state-approved ID card or company employee ID card containing a picture showing positive identification of the person who is pawning, selling or bartering and verify the identification. (Code 1981, § 14-72; Ord. No. 1984-4, § 1-12, 6-4-1984) Sec. 54-161. - Purchased articles not to be disposed of for seven days after acquisition. Every business licensed hereunder shall hold on the premises designated in the license for doing business every item required to be listed under section 54-157 for at least seven working days before disposing of same by sale, transfer or shipment. The provisions of this section shall not apply to items purchased from licensed wholesalers in the normal course of business. (Code 1981, § 14-73; Ord. No. 1984-4, § 1-13, 6-4-1984) Sec. 54-162. - Pawned articles not to be disposed of for 30 days after acquisition. Every business licensed hereunder which takes goods on pawn shall hold such goods for at least 30 days, unless redeemed by the owner or on authority of the owner, before disposing of same by sale, transfer, shipment or otherwise. (Code 1981, § 14-74; Ord. No. 1984-4, § 1-14, 6-4-1984) Sec. 54-163. - Display of goods pledged or purchased. For a period of seven working days from the date of purchase and 30 days from the date of pledge, unless redeemed by or by authority of the person who pledged the goods, all goods purchased or pawned and required to be listed under section 54-157 shall be kept on the premises designated in the license for doing business, shall have attached to it either a copy of the form required in section 54-157 or the number of such form. Any person desiring to examine any merchandise shall first file with the city police department an incident report or stolen property report and upon giving notice, in writing, to the owner or employee, which notice shall include: (1) A full description of the stolen items, including all identifying characteristics; (2) The person's name, address and identification; and (3) The person's signature; such individual shall be allowed to examine any merchandise of the type described in said request on the premises. Such written information shall be kept in sequential, dated order in a permanent file or book. This record shall be kept in addition to all other records required herein. (Code 1981, § 14-75; Ord. No. 1984-4, § 1-15, 6-4-1984; Ord. No. 1986-2, § 1, 2-3-1986) Sec. 54-164. - Alteration. Any items required to be kept or displayed under the provisions of sections 54-161 through 54-163 shall be kept in their original form as they existed when first purchased, and their physical characteristics shall not be altered in any numerical or material manner. (Code 1981, § 14-76; Ord. No. 1984-4, § 1-16, 6-4-1984) Sec. 54-165. - Erasures or obliterations or write-overs or type-overs are not allowed. No persons licensed hereunder shall erase, obliterate, type over, write over or in any way cause the original entry on the records required by this article to become illegible. All pawn or purchase tickets filled out in error shall be sent to the city police department in their numbered order along with the weekly reports and shall have the word "Void" typed or written across the front. Such entry shall not be used to cause the original entry to be illegible. If an error is made, and the ticket is still to be used, then a single line shall be drawn through the incorrect entry. This line shall not cause the original entry to be illegible, and the correct information entry shall be made on the next available area. (Code 1981, § 14-77; Ord. No. 1984-4, § 1-17, 6-4-1984) Sec. 54-166. - Records maintained for four years. The record for each pawn or purchase transaction regulated by this article shall be maintained for a period of not less than four years from date of this transaction. (Code 1981, § 14-78; Ord. No. 1984-4, § 1-18, 6-4-1984) Sec. 54-167. - Dealing with minors. It shall be unlawful for any person licensed hereunder to receive in pawn or in purchase any goods of any character or of any description from any person who has not attained the age of 17 years. (Code 1981, § 14-79; Ord. No. 1984-4, § 1-19, 6-4-1984) Sec. 54-168. - Hours of operation. All businesses licensed hereunder shall close their establishments and cease transacting any business no later than 11:00 p.m. each day and begin their operation and commence transacting business at no time before 7:00 a.m. each day. (Code 1981, § 14-80; Ord. No. 1984-4, § 1-20, 6-4-1984) Sec. 54-169. - Business transactions conducted outside the building normally used for business transaction, parking lots or rear lot area, etc. (a) The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Business transaction means any part of business including inspection or appraisal of any goods when it is possible for such goods to be taken outside the building where transactions are normally made (the term "possible" is used herein in the broadest sense); and no person other than those possessing a license or employee permit shall be allowed to conduct any form of business transaction either inside the establishment or on any part of outside land area covered under address of the license. (b) No business transactions by any business licensed hereunder shall be conducted outside the building designated as the normal place to conduct transactions unless said business does not have a building. (Code 1981, § 14-81; Ord. No. 1984-4, § 1-21, 6-4-1984) Sec. 54-170. - Articles that have had serial numbers removed or altered or obliterated shall not be accepted. No business licensed hereunder shall accept any article which has had the serial number altered, obliterated or removed from such article or which the person who is making the business transaction knows should have a serial number on it. Licensees shall immediately report any attempted business transaction of this nature to the city police department. (Code 1981, § 14-82; Ord. No. 1984-4, § 1-22, 6-4-1984) Sec. 54-171. - No article will be accepted unless the provisions of sections 54-157 and 54-158 are followed. No business licensed hereunder shall take any item in pawn or purchase or take full possession or title thereto, without entering such transaction of such goods on his/her books and on the standard forms as provided for in sections 54-157 and 54-158. (Code 1981, § 14-83; Ord. No. 1984-4, § 1-23, 6-4-1984) Sec. 54-172. - Ownership of other pawn business in other town or same town. Any owner of a business licensed hereunder shall not transfer goods from one business, where he/she has a minority or majority ownership, to another business without said goods meeting all regulations of the ordinances of the city regarding pawnbrokers and dealers in precious metals. (Code 1981, § 14-84; Ord. No. 1984-4, § 1-24, 6-4-1984) Sec. 54-173. - Inspection. As a condition of the granting of the license hereunder, every licensee agrees to allow any duly authorized law enforcement officer, pursuant to his/her official duties, to be and remain about the licensed premises without the formality of a warrant, provided said officer does not interfere in the licensee's operation. (Code 1981, § 14-86; Ord. No. 1984-4, § 1-26, 6-4-1984) Sec. 54-174. - Nonformed precious metals. It shall be unlawful for any person licensed hereunder to purchase precious metals in a melted, smelted or nonformed state unless the purchase is from a registered dealer in precious metals. (Code 1981, § 14-87; Ord. No. 1984-4, § 1-27, 6-4-1984) Sec. 54-175. - Stolen items. Every person licensed hereunder shall, immediately, upon request, turn over to the city police department every item believed by the city police department to be a stolen item. The police department shall furnish a property receipt including the case number to the dealer surrendering such item, and such item shall be returned to the dealer only after it has been determined that such item is not stolen. If it is determined such item is stolen it shall be returned to its lawful owner. (Code 1981, § 14-88; Ord. No. 1984-4, § 1-28, 6-4-1984; Ord. No. 1986-2, § 2, 2-3-1986) Sec. 54-176. - State law. This article is to be construed as consistent with state law. However, these provisions of this article are to be applied in lieu of state law and state fee and registration requirements, whenever possible. It is the intent of this article that all duties delegated to the chief law enforcement officer of the city shall be exercised as provided herein. (Code 1981, § 14-89; Ord. No. 1984-4, § 1-29, 6-4-1984) Secs. 54-177—54-205. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - YARD SALES
Sec. 54-206. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Neighborhood yard sale means a yard sale which is conducted by two or more persons living in the same general vicinity of each other where such persons have joined together to offer household goods for sale at the property of one of the participants in the yard sale. Yard sale means the sale or trading of clothing, furniture, household items, dishes, antiques or similar goods or merchandise, other than in the normal course of business, or the sale or trading of such goods, as outlined in this definition, by a person not regularly engaged in such business. Such goods or merchandise do not need to be attended for a sale to be deemed to be in existence. The term "yard sale" shall include garage sales, carport sales and similar types of sales or events. (Code 1981, § 14-90; Ord. No. 2009-03, 5-4-2009) Sec. 54-207. - Location and manner of yard sale. (a) Every yard sale shall be held at a location and in a manner so as not to block the free flow of vehicular traffic and so as not to create or cause a dangerous or hazardous condition for vehicular traffic or for pedestrians. (b) The person or persons who conduct a yard sale shall be responsible for compliance with subsection (a) of this section. (Code 1981, § 14-91; Ord. No. 2009-03, 5-4-2009) Sec. 54-208. - Permit required. (a) Any person desiring to hold a yard sale shall obtain a complimentary permit from the administrative secretary. The application for the permit shall set forth the name and address of the person who will be conducting the yard sale, the address where the same is to be located, and the date upon which the yard sale will be conducted. The administrative secretary shall furnish such person with a copy of this article at the time of obtaining the yard sale permit. (b) In the case of a neighborhood yard sale, one of the persons who will participate in the neighborhood yard sale shall make application for the complimentary permit and shall set forth: (1) The name and address of the applicant; (2) The address where the sale is to be held; (3) The date or dates on which the neighborhood yard sale is to be held; and (4) The names and addresses of all other persons who plan to participate in the sale. (c) The permit shall be obtained at least two business days prior to the commencement date of the yard sale. Applicant shall specify an alternate date (rain date) for such yard sale in the event the proposed sale cannot be held on the first selected date because of inclement weather. (d) A resident who wishes to hold a yard/garage sale at his or her own residential property will not be required to obtain a permit. (Code 1981, § 14-92; Ord. No. 2009-03, 5-4-2009) Sec. 54-209. - Number and duration. Yard sales shall be allowed not more than eight times in any calendar year for any premises. No sale may run more than two consecutive days. (Code 1981, § 14-93; Ord. No. 2009-03, 5-4-2009) Sec. 54-210. - Display area. All displays of yard sale merchandise shall be limited to that portion of the front yard (or property) area which is at least five feet back from the property line on all sides, and at least ten feet back from any curb or road edge. (Code 1981, § 14-94; Ord. No. 2009-03, 5-4-2009) Sec. 54-211. - Religious and charitable organizations. Religious or charitable organizations exempt from federal taxation pursuant to section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code may conduct an unlimited number of yard sales on the property of the organization or at other locations in areas zoned for commercial uses within the city with the express written consent of the owner of the premises where the yard sale is being conducted. (Code 1981, § 14-95; Ord. No. 2009-03, 5-4-2009) Sec. 54-212. - Duties of administrative secretary and code enforcement officer. The administrative secretary shall maintain application forms and complimentary permits to be issued for yard sales. The administrative secretary shall furnish to the police department a copy of all yard sale permits as and when the permits are issued. The administrative secretary shall maintain a record of all permits issued which record of permits issued for yard sale shall be maintained for the space of at least 18 months and the administrative secretary shall, before issuing any yard sale permit, check the listing record of previous permits issued to be certain that a requested permit is not being requested more frequently than permitted under the terms of this article and if such requested permit is for a date or time by the same applicant or at an address where a previous yard sale has been held less than ninety (30) days prior to the date of the proposed sale, the code enforcement officer shall have the authority to refuse to issue the permit. (Code 1981, § 14-96; Ord. No. 2009-03, 5-4-2009) Sec. 54-213. - Display of permit. The permit issued to any applicant for a yard sale shall be publicly displayed by the applicant during the time that the yard sale is being held or shall be available for inspection by a police officer upon demand. (Code 1981, § 14-97; Ord. No. 2009-03, 5-4-2009) Sec. 54-214. - Temporary signs. Any person holding a yard sale may erect not more than three temporary directional signs during the time that the yard sale is being held, which directional signs may not be affixed to any public utility pole or street sign but each such sign shall be erected on its own stake or small post. Such directional sign may not be larger than one foot by two feet. Such temporary sign shall be removed promptly prior to the expiration of the permit for the yard sale. (Code 1981, § 14-98; Ord. No. 2009-03, 5-4-2009) Sec. 54-215. - Termination of sales without permit. The mayor and city council hereby grants authority to the chief of police and police officers to order the immediate termination of any yard sale being conducted without a valid permit being issued pursuant to the terms of this article. Any person who refuses to obey the order of the chief of police or other lawful officer of the city and immediately cease and terminate said yard sale and remove the public display of goods from their yard shall be subject to arrest for the charge of failing to obey a lawful order of a police officer and be subject to all the penalties for the violation of this article. The charge provided for in this section is in addition to any other charges that may be brought against such individual conducting a yard sale in violation of the terms of this article. (Code 1981, § 14-99; Ord. No. 2009-03, 5-4-2009) Sec. 54-216. - Prohibited acts. (a) No individual, firm, corporation or other partnership shall be permitted to engage in the business of promoting or conducting yard sales for others for a fee or other consideration. No merchandise shall be purchased in anticipation of resale at a yard sale. (b) No yard sale shall be held on premises other than the premises of a least one of the persons conducting the yard sale except with the express written consent of the owner of the premises where the yard sale is being conducted. (Code 1981, § 14-100; Ord. No. 2009-03, 5-4-2009) Secs. 54-217—54-240. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - TRANSIENT MERCHANTS, PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS
FOOTNOTE(S): --- (4) --- State Law reference— Peddlers and itinerant traders, O.C.G.A. § 43-32-1 et seq.; transient merchants, O.C.G.A. § 43-46-1 et seq. Sec. 54-241. - Short title. This article shall be known and may be recited as the "Transient Merchant, Peddler and Solicitor Ordinance of 2009." (Code 1981, § 14-101; Ord. No. 2009-04, 5-4-2009) Sec. 54-242. - Definitions. The following words and phrases shall have the meanings set forth in this section unless the use of any such word or phrase in context clearly indicates otherwise: Booth, stand means any table, shelf, counter, cart or other facility, whether mobile or fixed, which is placed on a street or other public place within the city for the purpose of selling or offering to sell any goods or service to the public, or for soliciting for any purpose. City means the mayor and councilmembers of the city, a municipal corporation, and the jurisdictional authority of that municipal corporation. License means the right or privilege granted by the city to engage in business as a transient merchant or peddler within the corporate limits of the city. Evidence that such right or privilege has been granted shall be in the form of a license document issued by the city treasurer, which document shall be kept at the merchant's place of business within the city or on the peddler's person or within the peddler's vehicle. Local peddler means any person who is a resident of the city, who has no regular fixed place of business within the city, and who engages in the business of selling or offering to sell goods or services by going from place to place within the city, except a person selling agricultural products and holding a letter from a county agent certifying that the products were produced by that person. Permit means the authorization granted by the city to solicit for charitable or religious purposes, or to solicit subscriptions as defined by this chapter there being no fee nor charge for such permit. Evidence that such authorization has been granted shall be in the form of a permit document issued by the city treasurer. Solicitor for charitable or religious purposes means any person who solicits contributions from the public, either on the streets of the city or from door to door, for any charitable or religious organization, and who does not sell or offer to sell any single item with a cost to the purchaser in excess of $10.00, shall be defined as a "solicitor for charitable or religious purposes." No qualification as a charitable or religious organization shall exist unless the applicant: (1) Is able to demonstrate a current exemption certificate from the Internal Revenue Service pursuant to section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1954; or (2) Has maintained in the county a continuous existence as a charitable or religious organization for a period of three years prior to the date of its application pursuant to this chapter. Solicitor for subscriptions means any person who solicits subscriptions by going from place to place within the city, and who offers for sale subscriptions to magazines or other materials protected by the provisions of the First Amendment to the Constitution of the United States of America, shall be defined as a "solicitor for subscriptions." Street means and includes any street, alley, lane, avenue, court, sidewalk, public right-of-way, or any other public place within the city. Transient merchant means any person, firm, or corporation, whether resident or nonresident of the city, who has no permanent, regular place of business within the city and who engages in the business of selling or offering to sell goods or services from a temporary fixed place of business located within the city, such temporary places of business to include any room or space in a hotel or motel, boardinghouse, public or private building, or any other fixed place of business within the city; however, no merchant shall be considered a transient merchant under this article if such merchant: (1) Is a bona fide commercial traveler selling goods at wholesale by samples; (2) Has already paid a license to the city for the privilege of conducting permanent business; (3) Is a peddler otherwise licensed by the city to sell goods from place to place; or (4) Is a civic club, service club or school who, from time to time, engages in the selling of merchandise to the public as a club or school project. Transient peddler means any person who is a nonresident of the city, who has no permanent, regular place of business within the city, and who engages in the business of selling or offering to sell goods or services by going from place to place within the city, except a person selling agricultural products and holding a letter from a county agent certifying that the products were produced by that person. (Code 1981, § 14-102; Ord. No. 2009-04, 5-4-2009) Sec. 54-243. - License or permit required. (a) No person shall operate a business as a transient merchant or peddler within the city unless a license for such business has first been granted by the city through the business license clerk; and no solicitor for charitable or religious purposes or solicitor for subscriptions as defined by this chapter shall solicit within the city unless a permit has been granted by the city in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. Such license or permit shall be effective only for the period stated in the document unless suspended or revoked prior to expiration. Application for a license or permit shall be made on forms provided by the administrative secretary and shall provide such information as is required by this article and such additional information as may be necessary to define completely the activities to be conducted within the city. (b) At the time of filing any application for a permit or license under this chapter, the applicant shall present with the application to the city a current valid driver's license showing a picture identification reasonably acceptable to the administrative secretary containing the picture of the applicant thereon. (Code 1981, § 14-103; Ord. No. 2009-04, 5-4-2009) Sec. 54-244. - Application for transient merchant's license, transient peddler's license. An application containing the following information shall be completed and filed with the administrative secretary by each applicant for a license to do business within the city as a transient merchant or transient peddler: (1) Name of the applicant; (2) Permanent address and telephone number of the applicant; (3) Local address and telephone number of the applicant; (4) The applicant's date of birth and age, if an individual; (5) The applicant's social security number, or federal employer identification number; (6) If the applicant is a partnership or corporation, the name and home address of each partner, principal, or corporate officer; (7) If the applicant is a corporation, the state and date of incorporation; (8) If the applicant is a partnership or corporation, the name, home address, date of birth, age and social security number of the principal representative in the city; (9) Name and home address of all employees to work in the city; (10) Name of the business represented by the applicant, if different from the applicant; (11) Permanent address of the business represented by the applicant; (12) Name of agent conducting sale, if any; (13) Local address and telephone number of sales agent, if any; (14) Type of merchandise or service to be offered for sale; (15) Place where business is to be conducted; (16) Date to be in business, and total number of days to be in business; (17) Hours during which business will be conducted; (18) Manner in which business is to be conducted; (19) State sales tax number of authorization; (20) State business license number, if required; (21) State and license tag number of each vehicle to be used in the business; (22) List of all cities where business has been conducted by the applicant within the 12-month period immediately preceding the application. The application and license shall be signed under oath by the applicant; (23) List of any and all felony criminal convictions and convictions of any crime involving moral turpitude of the applicant within five years prior to the date of the application; (24) A signed letter of approval from property owner (with dates of the sale and the address) where the peddler to conduct business. (Code 1981, § 14-104; Ord. No. 2009-04, 5-4-2009) Sec. 54-245. - Registered agent required; transient merchant. (a) Any transient merchant shall submit evidence with his/her license application showing that such transient merchant has filed with the city clerk the name and permanent address of the transient merchant's registered agent. Such agent shall be a local property owner and a resident of the county for the previous 12 months. It shall be the responsibility of this individual to act as agent of such transient merchant upon whom any process, notice, or demand required or permitted by law to be served upon the transient merchant may be served in the same manner provided by law for the service of a summons or complaint. The registered agent shall agree in writing to act as such agent, and a copy of the agreement shall be filed with the license application. (b) Any such registered agent shall act in the same capacity and have the same duties and responsibilities, and be subject to the same actions of the superior court, as would any agent registered as required by O.C.G.A. § 43-46-5 (H.B. 1568) of the general assembly of the state adopted in 1980 and known as the "Transient Merchant Act of Georgia." (c) In addition, all registered agents shall also complete an application containing the following information and file such with the administrative secretary before any license shall be issued to a transient merchant: (1) Name of the registered agent; (2) Permanent address and phone number of the registered agent; (3) The registered agent's social security number; (4) Length of time that the registered agent has been a resident of the county; (5) Location of property owned by this individual which would qualify one to act as a registered agent. (d) Such application shall be signed under oath by the registered agent. (Code 1981, § 14-105; Ord. No. 2009-04, 5-4-2009) Sec. 54-246. - Basis for disapproval or revocation of license. No license shall be approved and any license previously issued may be revoked if an investigation determines that: (1) Any false statement, material omission, or untrue or misleading information is contained in or left out of the application; (2) The applicant or any principal participant in the business has been convicted within the past five years of a felony, or of any crime involving moral turpitude, whether in connection with operation of the business or not; or (3) Said business is operated, or is proposed to be operated, in violation of any law of the United States or the state, or in violation of any ordinance of the city. (Code 1981, § 14-106; Ord. No. 2009-04, 5-4-2009) Sec. 54-247. - Building official approval required. No transient merchant, transient peddler, local peddler or solicitor shall set up a booth or stand, to conduct business or operation within the city until the building official of the city has reviewed the application to ensure compliance with zoning, building and safety code requirements of the city before issuing the license. (Code 1981, § 14-107; Ord. No. 2009-04, 5-4-2009) Sec. 54-248. - Permit and fee for transient merchant. A transient merchant, as defined in section 54-242, shall pay a base regulatory fee that shall not be prorated. Said regulatory fee shall expire at 12:00 midnight on the 14th consecutive day after the effective day of the transient merchant permit, or at 12:00 midnight on December 31 of the year issued. The amount of the base regulatory fee shall be as established by the city council from time to time. After the 14th consecutive day from the effective date of the transient merchant permit for the calendar year in which the regulatory fee or any portion thereof during which the transient merchant conducts business within the city, the transient merchant shall pay an additional fee, for each day the transient merchant conducts business in the city. The amount of the additional fee shall be as established by the city council from time to time, and are available for public examination in the office of the city business license clerk. In the event that a higher regulatory fee is required of a transient merchant pursuant to another ordinance, statute or regulation, such higher regulatory fee shall apply. The maximum amount of regulatory fees to be paid by any transient merchant to the city in any calendar year pursuant to this section shall not exceed the sum of $600.00. (Code 1981, § 14-108; Ord. No. 2009-04, 5-4-2009) Sec. 54-249. - Bond requirement for transient merchant. Before any license or permit shall be issued to a transient merchant pursuant to this chapter, the transient merchant shall file with the administrative secretary a bond binding the applicant to the city in the full sum of $1,000.00, executed by the applicant as principal and by a surety approved by the city clerk, conditioned that the applicant shall fully comply with the ordinances of the city and the statutes of the state governing the conduct of such business and will pay all judgments rendered against the applicant for any violation of such ordinances or statutes and all judgments that may be recovered against the applicant and by any person or persons for damages growing out of any misrepresentation, deception, or breach of warranty in the conduct of such business. It is further required that this bond be held, maintained, and in force for a period of not less than 12 months immediately following the last day of business in the city of the transient merchant. (Code 1981, § 14-109; Ord. No. 2009-04, 5-4-2009) Sec. 54-250. - License fee for transient peddler. Before conducting any business regulated by this chapter, the applicant for a permit for a transient peddler as defined in this chapter shall pay the city a regulatory fee, that shall not to be prorated. The amount of the regulatory fee shall be as established by the city council from time to time. Said regulatory fee shall expire on the earlier of midnight on the 14th consecutive day after the effective day thereof, or at midnight on December 31 of the year issued. After the 14th consecutive day from the effective date of the transient peddler permit, the transient peddler shall pay to the city an additional regulatory fee for each day the transient peddler conducts business in the city. The amount of the additional fee shall be as established by the city council from time to time. In the event that a higher regulatory fee is required of a transient peddler pursuant to another ordinance, statute or regulation, such higher regulatory fee shall apply. The maximum amount of regulatory fees to be paid by any transient peddler in any one calendar year pursuant to this section to the city shall not exceed the sum of $600.00. (Code 1981, § 14-110; Ord. No. 2009-04, 5-4-2009) Sec. 54-251. - License fee for local peddler. Any local peddler, as defined in section 54-242, shall be licensed in the same manner and in the same amount as is required of any other local merchant as provided by the various laws and ordinances of the city. (Code 1981, § 14-111; Ord. No. 2009-04, 5-4-2009) Sec. 54-252. - Application for a permit; solicitor. Any application for a permit to solicit funds for a charitable or religious organization, and any applicant for a permit to solicit for subscriptions, shall make application to the city treasurer. Such applicant shall provide the name and address of the applicant, the name and address of the business or organization represented, the dates during which activities will be conducted within the city, the identity of all persons to solicit within the city, and such other information that the administrative secretary may find necessary to identify the solicitors and define the activities to be conducted. Any such applicant who has not resided in the county for the preceding six months shall register at the city police department and shall be subject to police investigation of any and all solicitors listed in the application. Any solicitor's permit may be denied or revoked under any circumstances as shown in section 54-246. (Code 1981, § 14-112; Ord. No. 2009-04, 5-4-2009) Sec. 54-253. - Issuance of license or permit. After all provisions of this chapter have been met by an applicant for a transient merchant's license, peddler's license or a solicitor's permit, the occupational license clerk shall be authorized to issue a license or permit. (Code 1981, § 14-113; Ord. No. 2009-04, 5-4-2009) Sec. 54-254. - Transient merchant, peddler and solicitor regulations. The following regulations shall apply to any transient merchant, local peddler, or transient peddler doing business within the city, and to any solicitor for a charitable or religious organization or for subscriptions who is required to obtain a license or permit: (1) No peddler, solicitor or transient merchant shall be permitted to set up and operate a booth or stand on any public street or sidewalk, or in any other public area within the city, except with the written permission of the city manager. (2) No peddler, solicitor or transient merchant shall stand or sit in or near the entrance to any house or place of business, and no peddler or solicitor shall stand or sit in any place which may disrupt or impede pedestrian or vehicular traffic. (3) No peddler, solicitor or transient merchant shall offer to sell goods or services or solicit in vehicular traffic lanes of the city, and no such peddler or solicitor shall operate a road block directed towards vehicular traffic. (4) If any officer of the city police department or the revenue department should determine that pedestrian or vehicular traffic congestion is such that a public hazard or inconvenience would result from peddling, soliciting or selling in a congested area, such officer shall have authority to require any peddler or solicitor to move from the area. (5) No peddler, solicitor or transient merchant shall enter a private residence, place of business, public building, or other premises within the city under false pretenses for the purpose of peddling goods or services, soliciting orders for the sale of goods or services, soliciting subscriptions, or soliciting contributions; no peddler, solicitor, or transient merchant shall remain in or on such premises after the owner, occupant, or other person in charge has requested the peddler, solicitor or transient merchant to leave; and no peddler, solicitor, or transient merchant shall go in or on such premises when the owner, occupant, or other person in charge has displayed a "No Soliciting" sign or other similar sign on the premises. (6) Any stand or booth operated by or used by a transient merchant, transient peddler, local peddler or solicitor which is located on private property shall be located thereon with the expressed written permission of the property owner, and shall satisfy all zoning regulations of the city (as set forth in chapter 94), health, safety and building code requirements and regulations of the city, and of applicable state law. Upon request by the building official, the designee of the building official, or any law enforcement officer, the transient merchant, and transient, local peddler or solicitor shall present said written permission from the landowner. In addition to all other requirements of this chapter, and of applicable law the transient merchant, transient peddler, local peddler or solicitor shall notify the police department of the city of the location of the stand or booth wherein such business is to be conducted. (7) No peddler, solicitor or transient merchant shall harass or intimidate the public in any manner. (8) Each transient merchant, peddler or solicitor for subscriptions, and each solicitor for a charitable or religious organization shall be required to display a valid license or permit issued by the city, or a copy thereof, in a manner which can be clearly observed by any person being solicited for a sale, subscriptions, or contribution; however, each member or representative of a charitable or religious organization which has been issued a permit to solicit contributions within the city may, in lieu of displaying a copy of the permit, display an identification badge or insignia of the organization if such insignia has been established a statutory service or trademark, in a manner which can be clearly observed by any person being solicited. (9) When any officer of the city police department or any other authorized city officer, deems that a peddler, solicitor or transient merchant is in violation of any provision of this chapter, such officer shall have authority to direct the peddler, solicitor or transient merchant to correct the violation immediately, and such peddler, solicitor or transient merchant shall comply with the directive or be subject to the penalties prescribed by this article. (10) No transient merchant, transient peddler, or local peddler or solicitor shall operate or conduct business within the city at any time in violation of state law, rules or regulations, or at any time in violation of any other ordinance or regulation or special order of the city commission, or on any day prior to 8:00 a.m. or later than one-half hour before sunset, or at any time on Sunday, except by specific appointment with or by invitation of the prospective customer. (11) No transient merchant, transient peddler, local peddler or solicitor shall conduct business or set up a sales booth or stand with the city except with the expressed written permission of the owner of the property where business is being conducted. (Code 1981, § 14-114; Ord. No. 2009-04, 5-4-2009) Sec. 54-255. - Compliance required; penalty for violation. Any person doing business within the city as a transient merchant, transient peddler, local peddler, solicitor or in any other manner covered by this article who violates any provision of this article, or any merchant, peddler, or solicitor who makes any false statement in any application for a business license or permit shall be subject to revocation of any license or permit according to the procedures established by ordinance and shall, upon conviction before the recorder of the city, be fined in an amount not to exceed $200.00, or imprisoned not exceeding 90 days, either or both, in the discretion of the recorder. Any such person, firm or corporation shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day or a portion thereof during which such violation of any of the provisions of this article is committed or continued. (Code 1981, § 14-115; Ord. No. 2009-04, 5-4-2009) Sec. 54-256. - Exceptions. The provisions of this article shall not apply to the following: (1) Sales made to dealers or permanent merchants by commercial travelers selling in the ordinary course of business; (2) Sheriffs, constables, bona fide assignees, receivers or trustees in bankruptcy or other public officers selling goods, wares, and merchandise according to law; (3) Bona fide residents of the state selling fruits, vegetables, dressed meats, fowl or farm products which were produced on land within the state, owned or controlled by such vendor. (Code 1981, § 14-116; Ord. No. 2009-04, 5-4-2009) Secs. 54-257—54-275. - Reserved. ARTICLE VIII. - ADULT GAME ROOMS AND BILLIARDS ROOMS
Sec. 54-276. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Billiards means any of the several games played on a table surrounded by an elastic ledge or cushions with balls which are impelled by a cue and includes all forms of the game known as pool, except that form of pool known as skill pool heretofore defined as one of the several types of pinball games. Billiards room means any public place wherein the game of billiards is permitted to be played and where there are two or more tables for such use. Game room means any place of business that operates two or more mechanical games or pay devices or tables for which charge is made either directly or indirectly. (Code 1981, § 14-151; Ord. No. 2008-8, § 28.01, 3-1-2004) Sec. 54-277. - Penalty. Any person operating premises in violation of the provisions of section 54-281 or 54-282 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Two or more violations within a calendar year period shall constitute valid ground for revocation of license. In addition to fines set by the municipal judge of the municipal court of city. (Code 1981, § 14-158; Ord. No. 2008-8, § 28.08, 3-1-2004) Sec. 54-278. - License. (a) Every operator of a game room shall apply for and obtain a license from the city council to operate a game room. Application for such a license shall be made upon forms provided by the city clerk. (b) It shall be unlawful to operate a game room or billiard rooms within the city without a license as required by this section. (Code 1981, § 14-152; Ord. No. 2008-8, § 28.02, 3-1-2004) Sec. 54-279. - Fee. An application fee shall be paid to and collected by the city clerk when the application is submitted to cover the cost of administration of this article. (Code 1981, § 14-153; Ord. No. 2008-8, § 28.03, 3-1-2004) Sec. 54-280. - Restrictions. The city council shall not issue a license to any applicant who: (1) Has been convicted of unlawfully selling intoxicating liquors or narcotic drugs; (2) Is a habitual user of alcoholic beverages or narcotic drugs; (3) Has been convicted of any felony crimes. (Code 1981, § 14-154; Ord. No. 2008-8, § 28.04, 3-1-2004) Sec. 54-281. - Prohibited conduct. Licensees under this article shall not, and neither shall their employees: (1) Suffer or permit any gambling on the licensed premises at any time, nor the sale or use of any racing, football, or other parlay cards or gambling boards or devices; (2) Suffer or permit the licensed premises to become disorderly or permit any profane, obscene or indecent language thereon; (3) Continue to employ any person who has been convicted of unlawfully selling alcoholic beverages or narcotic drugs during the time in which such person been employed with the business. (Code 1981, § 14-155; Ord. No. 2008-8, § 28.05, 3-1-2004) Sec. 54-282. - Rules for operation of game rooms. The following rules shall be observed by all operators of game rooms within the city: (1) All game rooms shall observe the hours of operation as set by the city council and shall be subject to changes in hours of operation as set by city council. The current hours of operation are Eastern Standard Time and as follows: a. Opening time: 7:30 a.m. (7:00 p.m. on Sunday); b. Closing time: 12:00 a.m. Monday through Saturday. (2) No play on any game shall be allowed during the times when game rooms are required by this section to remain closed. (3) All buildings shall conform to the state and city building code, and the operator shall acquire a certificate of compliance before operation shall begin. (4) No loud offensive noises shall be allowed to emanate beyond the licensed premises. (5) There must be an adult 18 years of age or older managing the business during hours of operation. (6) No alcoholic beverages including beer and wine shall be consumed on the premises of a game room or billiards room. (7) No person under the age of 18 years is permitted on premises of a game room or billiards room before 4:00 p.m. on any day the public or private school's are in session, unless such person is accompanied by his or her parent or legal guardian. (8) No license or owner of any game room or billiards room or any servant, agent, or employee of such a licensee or owner, shall permit upon the premises housing a mechanical amusement device arcade any of the following: a. Disorderly persons or minors; b. Intoxicated people or minors to loiter on the premises; c. Loitering signs must be posted outside premises and security lights must be on at dusk to closing time. (9) No licensee shall allow the licensed premises to become overcrowded so as to constitute a hazard to the health or safety of persons therein or to be in violation of any of the city's or state's fire, health or sanitation codes. (10) No game room or billiard room shall be operated so as to constitute a public nuisance. (Code 1981, § 14-156; Ord. No. 2008-8, § 28.06, 3-1-2004) Sec. 54-283. - Revocation of license. (a) After giving the operator or owner of a game room adequate notice and an opportunity to be heard, as provided in this section, the city council may revoke the license of any game room or billiard room operator who: (1) Violates the provisions of sections 54-281 or 54-282; (2) Is convicted of unlawfully selling alcoholic beverages or narcotic drugs; or (3) Is convicted of a felony crime. (b) Adequate notice shall mean the mailing of a certified letter, return receipt requested, no less than 15 days before the hearing date, or personal service upon such operator at the place of business or residence no less than 12 days before the hearing. The hearing shall be at any regular or special meeting of the city council. (Code 1981, § 14-157; Ord. No. 2008-8, § 28.07, 3-1-2004)

div.head: Chapter 58 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS
div.p:
FOOTNOTE(S): --- (1) --- State Law reference— Limitation on home rule powers of municipal corporations with respect to duplication of state criminal offenses, Ga. Const. art. III, § VI, ¶ IV, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6(a)(2); Criminal Code of Georgia, O.C.G.A. § 16-1-1 et seq.; nuisances, O.C.G.A. § 41-1-1 et seq.; jurisdiction of municipal court or magistrate court to abate nuisance, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-5; abandoned motor vehicles generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-1 et seq. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 58-1. - Obstructing city officer in the discharge of duties. It shall be unlawful for any person to hinder, delay, obstruct or prevent any city official or employee of the city, or any person acting for or under the direction of such city official or employee, from performing any act which by reason of such office or position, may devolve upon such officer or person acting as aforesaid. (Code 1969, § 11-6; Code 1981, § 15-1) Sec. 58-2. - Damaging or defacing property. It shall be unlawful to deface, mar or damage, or, without proper authority to write, carve, paste or paint any marks, letters or pictures on any public property or private property of another in the city. (Code 1969, § 11-1; Code 1981, § 15-2) Sec. 58-3. - Disorderly conduct. Any person who shall within the city conduct such person's self in a tumultuous or riotous manner or who shall commit any act against good order, public safety, morality or common decency shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (Code 1969, § 11-2; Code 1981, § 15-3) State Law reference— Fighting in a public place, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-32; use of "fighting words," obscene and vulgar or profane language, etc., O.C.G.A. § 16-11-39. Sec. 58-4. - Drunkenness in public. It shall be unlawful for any person to be or appear in a drunken condition in any public place in the city. (Code 1969, § 11-4; Code 1981, § 15-4) State Law reference— Public drunkenness, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-41. Sec. 58-5. - Possession or consumption of intoxicating beverages in public places. (a) The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Public place means any public street, sidewalk, alley, park, playground, athletic field, recreation center, or public school campus, or any public building owned by the city, within the corporate limits of the city, except any such place for which the city issued a retail license for the sale or consumption of alcoholic, vinous or malt beverages. The term "public place" also means and includes any parking lot open to the general public, whether or not privately owned, and any portion of premises of a retail licensee for the sale or consumption of alcoholic, vinous or malt beverages lying outside the building for which such license was issued. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to consume or drink any beer, wine, alcoholic liquor or other intoxicating beverages in an open container in or upon any public place within the corporate limits of the city whether or not in a motor vehicle in or upon such public place. (c) It shall be unlawful for any person, to have in his/her possession any beer, wine, alcoholic liquor or other intoxicating beverages in an open container in or upon any public place within the corporate limits of the city whether or not in a motor vehicle in or upon such public place. (Code 1981, § 15-4.1; Ord. No. 1990-6, §§ 1—5, 9-17-1990; Ord. No. 2008-11, 8-2-2004) Sec. 58-6. - Throwing stones, etc. It shall be unlawful for any person to cast, throw or fling any stone, brickbat or any other such thing of whatever nature on the streets, lanes or alleys, or in any other public place in the city, or out of any premises in the city. (Code 1969, § 11-8; Code 1981, § 15-5) Sec. 58-7. - Shoplifting prohibited; penalty. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person within the city limits to commit theft by taking when in any mercantile establishment within the city limits in which merchandise is displayed for sale in such a manner as to be readily accessible to the person shopping therein, if he/she: (1) Removes any such merchandise from the immediate place of display; (2) Conceals any such merchandise; (3) Alters any label or marking on such merchandise; (4) Interchanges the label or price tag from one item of merchandise with a label or price tag from another item of merchandise; or (5) Transfers any such merchandise from a container in which it may be displayed to any other container, with the intent to appropriate such merchandise to his/her own use, or to deprive the owner of possession thereof or of the value thereof, in whole or part. The crime of theft by taking under the circumstances of this subsection shall also be known as shoplifting. (b) The penalty for a violation of this section shall not exceed $500.00, or imprisonment in the city jail for not more than 60 days, for each offense of shoplifting of merchandise that does not exceed $300.00 in value. Under this section, the penalty for violation of subsection (a) of this section shall in no way affect the authority of a sentencing judge to provide for a sentence to be served on weekends or during nonworking hours of the defendant as relative to the punishment for misdemeanors. (Code 1981, § 15-6; Ord. No. 1985-6, § 2, 9-9-1985) Sec. 58-8. - Discharge of certain chemical compounds from aircraft. It shall be unlawful for any person to cause to be discharged from any aircraft any defoliant, pesticide, herbicide or any other related chemical compound within the city limits. Likewise, it shall be unlawful for any person to discharge from any aircraft any defoliant, pesticide, herbicide or any other related chemical compound outside the city limits of the city when prevailing weather conditions may cause said chemical compound to fall within the city limits. (Code 1981, § 15-7; Ord. No. 1985-7, § 1, 12-16-1985) Sec. 58-9. - Loitering or prowling. (a) A person commits the offense of loitering or prowling when he/she is in a place at a time or in a manner not usual for law-abiding individuals under circumstances that warrant a justifiable and reasonable alarm or immediate concern for the safety of persons or property in the vicinity. (b) Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether alarm is warranted is the fact that the person takes flight upon the appearance of a law enforcement officer, refuses to identify himself/herself, or manifestly endeavors to conceal himself/herself or any object. Unless flight by the person or other circumstances make it impracticable, a law enforcement officer shall, prior to any arrest for an offense under this section, afford the person an opportunity to dispel any alarm or immediate concern which would otherwise be warranted by requesting the person to identify himself/herself and explain his/her presence and conduct. No person shall be convicted of an offense under this section if the law enforcement officer failed to comply with the procedure set forth in this subsection or if it appears at trial that the explanation given by the person was true and would have dispelled the alarm or immediate concern. (c) A person committing the offense of loitering or prowling shall be subject to imprisonment in the city jail for a period not exceeding six months or a fine not exceeding $1,000.00 or both such fine and imprisonment. (Code 1981, § 15-8; Ord. No. 1990-5, §§ 1—3, 9-17-1990) State Law reference— Loitering or prowling, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-36. Secs. 58-10—58-36. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PARADES, DEMONSTRATIONS, AND RIOTS
Sec. 58-37. - Permit required. It shall be unlawful for any person or any congregation or association of individuals to publicly march, parade or otherwise congregate in a body upon the streets of the city without first obtaining a permit so to do from the mayor. (Code 1969, § 11-20; Code 1981, § 15-20) Sec. 58-38. - Entry upon public or private premises restricted. It shall be unlawful for any person or any congregation or association of individuals to enter into or upon the premises of another, whether said premises shall be public or private, or owned or leased. (Code 1969, § 11-21; Code 1981, § 15-21) State Law reference— Criminal trespass, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-21. Sec. 58-39. - Congregating, assembling around place of business restricted. It shall be unlawful for any person or any congregation or association of individuals to gather or congregate around or adjacent to any public or private business in the city without the express permission of the owner or occupant of said premises. (Code 1969, § 11-22; Code 1981, § 15-22) Sec. 58-40. - Duty to move when requested to do so. It shall be considered disorderly conduct for any person or any congregation or association of individuals to fail to move from the streets and sidewalks or from the premises of another when requested to do so by the police of the city or by the owner or occupant of said premises, respectively. (Code 1969, § 11-23; Code 1981, § 15-23) Sec. 58-41. - Remaining uninvited on private property. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to leave private property when requested to do so by the owner, proprietor or manager thereof. For the purpose of this section, the term "private property" means real property other than property owned by the federal government, the state, county, city or any other body politic. (Code 1969, § 11-24; Code 1981, § 15-24) Sec. 58-42. - Issuance standards; authority of police. No permit shall be issued by the mayor unless: (1) Such activity will not unreasonably interfere with the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route; (2) The conduct of the parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers to properly police the line of movement and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection; (3) The conduct of such parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of ambulances as to prevent normal ambulance service to portions of the city other than that to be occupied by the proposed line of march and areas contiguous thereto; (4) The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at assembly points of the parade will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of, or ambulance service to, areas contiguous to such assembly areas; (5) The conduct of such parade will not interfere with the movement of firefighting equipment en route to fire; (6) The conduct of the parade is not reasonably likely to cause injury to persons or property, to provoke disorderly conduct or create a disturbance; (7) The parade is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays en route; and (8) The activity representative agrees to see to the immediate cleaning up of all litter which is left on the streets as a result of the activity. It shall be unlawful for any person obtaining such a permit to fail to carry out his/her agreement to immediately clean up the resulting litter. (Code 1969, § 11-25; Code 1981, § 15-25) Sec. 58-43. - Issuance or denial of permit. Within 15 days of receipt of the permit application, the mayor shall issue the permit unless it is denied for one or more of the standards stated in section 58-42. The denial of a permit will be in the form of a written statement containing the reasons for denial. The activity representative will be given a copy of the written denial statement by hand delivery or by certified mailing, return receipt requested, to the address on the permit application on or before the 30th business day after the city's receipt of the completed application. Within ten days after the statement of denial is received by the activity representative, he/she may request a review of the permit denial by the city council at the next scheduled council meeting. In reviewing the reasons for denial, the city council may specify further terms or conditions it deems in the best interest of the city as a condition of granting the permit or uphold the determination to deny the permit. Sec. 58-44. - Authority of police in dispersing assemblage in interest of health. The police of the city under the direction of the mayor or city council shall have authority to disperse any assemblage of persons where such action will aid in preventing the spread of contagious or infectious disease. (Code 1969, § 11-26; Code 1981, § 15-26) Sec. 58-45. - Riots and civil disobedience—Mayor's authority. Whenever riots, general civil disobedience or the threat of same occurs in the city, and it is deemed necessary in order to suppress the riot or act of civil disobedience, the mayor, or mayor pro tempore in the absence of the mayor, shall have the power to do the following: (1) To declare hours of curfew for all persons, and during said hours of curfew, all persons shall be at their homes and shall not be on the streets, alleys or other public areas of the city. The curfew shall be declared in a proclamation of the mayor, or mayor pro tempore in the absence of the mayor, which proclamation shall be delivered to the chief of police, who shall then see that said proclamation is delivered to all general news media within the city and who shall also use public address systems throughout the city and immediately notify the public of said proclamation and curfew and warn the public that any violation of the curfew shall be deemed a misdemeanor and violators will be arrested. (2) To require all or any business establishment to be closed and remain closed until further order. After such notice, refusing to close and remain closed shall be deemed a misdemeanor. The mayor, or the mayor pro tempore in the absence of the mayor, shall issue a proclamation which shall be delivered to the chief of police, who shall inform said businesses of said proclamation. (Code 1969, § 11-27; Code 1981, § 15-27) Sec. 58-46. - Same—Police chief's authority. In situations mentioned in section 58-45, the chief of police shall have authority to temporarily close any or all streets, alleys and other public ways in the city to the public, whether, in the opinion of the chief of police, it is necessary in order to maintain the peace of the community. (Code 1969, § 11-28; Code 1981, § 15-28) Sec. 58-47. - Same—Failure to disperse. Every person remaining present at the place of any riot or unlawful assembly after the same has been ordered to disperse by the police or any other lawful authority, except those public officers and persons assisting them in attempting to disperse the same, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. (Code 1969, § 11-29; Code 1981, § 15-29) Secs. 58-48—58-68. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - UNFAIR HOUSING PRACTICES
Sec. 58-69. - Definitions. (a) The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Financial institution includes any person, as that term is defined in section 1-2, regularly engaged in the business of lending money or guaranteeing loans on real property. Person selling real property includes a person who: (1) Sells real property. (2) Leases or rents real property in a single building consisting of one or more housing units. (3) As agent for another, or any corporation, association, partnership or trusteeship that performs any of the functions set forth in this definition. Purchaser includes any occupant, prospective occupant, lessee, prospective lessee, buyer or prospective buyer. (b) The definitions set forth in O.C.G.A. § 8-3-201, Fair Housing—Definitions, shall be effective as definitions of the words, terms and phrases used in this chapter. All words, terms and phrases used herein, other than those specifically defined elsewhere in this chapter, shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them in O.C.G.A. § 8-3-201, and shall have the same scope and effect that the same words, terms and phrases have where used in O.C.G.A. § 8-3-201. (Code 1969, § 5-70; Code 1981, § 15-50; Ord. of 5-1-1978, § 7) Sec. 58-70. - Unlawful practices in selling or renting dwellings; exceptions. (a) Except as exempted by subsection (b) or (d) of this section, it shall be unlawful: (1) To refuse to sell or rent after the making of a bona fide offer, or to refuse to negotiate for the sale or rental of, or otherwise make unavailable or deny, a dwelling to any person because of race, color, religion, sex, disability, familial status or national origin; (2) To discriminate against any person in the terms, conditions, or privileges of sale or rental of a dwelling, or in the provision of services or facilities in connection therewith, because of race, color, religion, sex, disability, familial status or national origin; (3) To make, print or publish, or cause to be made, printed or published any notice, statement or advertisement, with respect to the sale or rental of a dwelling, that indicates any preference, limitation or discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, disability, familial status or national origin or an intention to make any such preference, limitations or discrimination; (4) To represent to any person because of race, color, religion, sex, disability, familial status or national origin that any dwelling is not available for inspection, sale or rental when such dwelling is in fact so available; (5) For profit, to induce or attempt to induce any person to sell or rent any dwelling by representations regarding the entry or prospective entry into the neighborhood of a person of a particular race, color, religion, sex, familial status or national origin or with a disability; (6) To discriminate in the sale or rental, or to otherwise make unavailable or deny, a dwelling to any buyer or renter because of a disability of: a. That buyer or renter; b. A person residing in or intending to reside in that dwelling after it is sold, rented, or made available; c. Any person associated with that buyer or renter; or (7) Discriminate in terms of sale or rental of a dwelling. a. To discriminate against any person in the terms, conditions or privileges of sale or rental of a dwelling, or in the provision of services or facilities in connections with such dwelling, because of a disability of: 1. The person; 2. A person residing in or intending to reside in that dwelling after it is sold, rented or made available; 3. Any person associated with that person; or b. For purposes of this subsection (a), the term "discrimination" includes: 1. A refusal to permit, at the expense of the person with disabilities, reasonable modifications of existing premises occupied or to be occupied by such person if such modifications may be necessary to afford such person full enjoyment of the premises, expect that, in the case of a rental, the landlord may where it is reasonable to do so condition permission for a modification on the renter's agreeing to restore the interior of the premises to the condition that existed before the modifications, reasonable wear and tear excepted; 2. A refusal to make reasonable accommodations in rules, policies, practices, or services when such accommodations may be necessary to afford such person equal opportunity to use and enjoy a dwelling; or 3. In connection with the design and construction of covered multifamily dwellings for first occupancy after March 13, 1991, a failure to design and construct those dwellings in such a manner that: (i) The public use and common use portions of such dwellings are readily accessible to and usable by persons with disabilities; (ii) All the doors are designed to allow passage into and within all premises within such dwellings are sufficiently wide to allow passage by persons with disabilities in wheelchairs; and (iii) All premises within such dwellings contain the following features of adaptive design: A. An accessible route into and through the dwelling; B. Light switches, electrical outlets, thermostats and other environment controls in accessible locations; C. Reinforcements in bathroom walls to allow later installation of grab bars; and D. Usable kitchens and bathrooms such that an individual in a wheelchair can maneuver about the space. c. Compliance with the appropriate requirements of the American National Standard for buildings and facilities providing accessibility and usableness for physically disabled people (commonly cited as "ANSI A117.1") suffices to satisfy requirements of subsection (a)(7)b.3(iii) of this section. d.
