In regard to persons with disabilities, discrimination includes, in connection with the design and construction of covered multifamily dwellings for first occupancy after March 13, 1991, a failure to design and construct dwellings in such manner that the dwellings have at least one building entrance on an accessible route, unless it is impractical to do so because of the terrain or unusual characteristics of the site. (b) Applicability. (1) Nothing in this section, other than subsection (a)(3) of this section, shall apply to: a. Any single-family dwellings sold or rented by an owner, if: 1. Such private individual owner does not own more than three such single-family dwellings at any one time; 2. Such bona fide private individual owner does not own any interest in, nor is there owned or reserved on his/her behalf, under any express or voluntary agreement, title to or any right to all or a portion of the proceeds from the sale or rental of more than three single-family dwellings at any one time; 3. Such dwelling is sold or rented: (i) Without the use in any manner of the sales or rental facilities or the sales or rental services of any real estate broker, agent or salesman, or of such facilities or services of any person in the business of selling or renting dwellings, or of any employees or agent of any such broker, agent, salesman or person; and (ii) Without the publication, posting, or mailing, after notice, of any advertisement or written notice in violation of subsection (c) of this section; but nothing in this subsection shall prohibit the use of attorneys, escrow agents, abstractors, title companies and other such professional assistance as necessary to perfect or transfer the title; or b. Rooms or units in dwellings containing living quarters occupied or intended to be occupied by no more than four families living independently of each other, if the owner actually maintains and occupies one of such living quarters as his/her residence. (2) In the case of the sale of any such single-family dwelling by a private individual owner not residing in such dwelling at the time of such sale or who was not the most recent resident of such dwelling prior to such sale, the exemption granted by this subsection shall apply only with respect to one such sale within any 24-month period. (c) For the purposes of subsection (b) of this section, a person shall be deemed to be in the business of selling or renting dwellings if he/she: (1) Has, within the preceding 12 months, participated as principal in three or more transactions involving the sale or rental of any dwelling or any interest therein; (2) Has, within the preceding 12 months, participated as agent, other than in the sale of his/her own personal residence, in providing sales or rental facilities or sales or rental services in two or more transactions involving the sale or rental of any dwelling or any interest therein; or (3) Is the owner of any dwelling designed or intended for occupancy by, or occupied by, five or more families. (d) Nothing contained in this section shall require that a dwelling be made available for rental or lease to an individual whose tenancy would constitute a direct threat to the health or safety of other individuals or whose tenancy would result in substantial physical damage to the property of others. Sec. 58-71. - Discrimination in residential real estate-related transactions; appraisals. (a) As used in this section, the term "residential real estate-related transaction" means any of the following: (1) The making or purchasing of loans or providing other financial assistance: a. For purchasing, constructing, improving, repairing or maintaining a dwelling; b. Secured by residential real estate; or (2) The selling, brokerage, or appraising of residential real property. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person or other entity whose business includes engaging in residential real estate-related transactions to discriminate against any person in making available such a transaction or in the terms or conditions of such a transaction because of race, color, religion, sex, disability, familial status or national origin. (c) Nothing in this article shall be construed to prohibit a person engaged in the business of furnishing appraisals of real property from taking into consideration factors other than race, color, religion, national origin, sex, disability or familial status. Sec. 58-72. - Permissible limitations in sale, rental, or occupancy of dwellings by religious organizations or private clubs; housing for older persons. (a) Nothing in this article shall prohibit a religious organization, association, or society, or any nonprofit institution or organization operated, supervised, or controlled by or in conjunction with a religious organization, association or society, from limiting the sale, rental or occupancy of dwellings which it owns or operates for other than a commercial purpose to persons of the same religion or from giving preferences to such persons unless membership in such religion is restricted on account of race, color, sex, disability, familial status or national origin. Nothing in this article shall prohibit a private club not in fact open to the public, which as an incident to its primary purposes provides lodgings which it owns or operates for other than commercial purpose, from limiting the rental or occupancy of such lodgings to its members or from giving preference to its members. (b) Housing for older persons. (1) As used in this subsection, the term "housing for older persons" means housing: a. Provided under any state or federal program that the director determines is specifically designed and operated to assist elderly persons as defined in the state or federal program; b. Intended for, and solely occupied by persons 62 years of age or older; or c. Intended and operated for occupancy by at least one person 55 years of age or older per unit. In determining whether housing qualifies as housing for older persons under this subsection (b), the director shall develop regulations which require at least the following factors: 1. The existence of significant facilities and services specifically designed to meet the physical or social needs of older persons, or, if the provision of such facilities and services is not practicable, that such housing is necessary to provide important housing opportunities for older persons; 2. That at least 80 percent of the units are occupied by at least one person 55 years of age or older per unit; and 3. The publication of and adherence to policies and procedures which demonstrate an intent by the owner or manager to provide housing for persons 55 years of age or older. (2) Nothing in this article limits the applicability of any reasonable local, state or federal restrictions regarding the maximum number of occupants permitted to occupy a dwelling. The provisions in this article regarding familial status shall not apply with respect to housing for older persons. (3) Housing shall not fail to meet the requirements for housing for older persons by reason of: a. Persons residing in such housing as of March 12, 1989, who do not meet the age requirements of subsection (b)(1)b or c of this section; provided, however, that new occupants of such housing meet the age requirements of subsection (b)(1)b or c of this section; or b. Unoccupied units; provided, however, that such units are reserved for occupancy by persons who meet the age requirements of subsection (b)(1)b or c of this section. (4) Nothing in this article prohibits conduct against a person because such person has been convicted by any court of competent jurisdiction of the illegal manufacture or distribution of a controlled substance. Sec. 58-73. - Coercion, intimidation, threats or interference. It shall be unlawful to coerce, intimidate, threaten or interfere with any person in the exercise or enjoyment of, or on account of such persons having exercise or enjoyed, or an account of such persons having aided or encouraged any other person in the exercise or enjoyment of any right granted or protected by this article. Sec. 58-74. - Violations; complaint. A complaint of alleged discriminatory housing practices prohibited by this article shall be in writing, signed by the complainant, and filed in the office of the fair housing panel. Upon receipt of a complaint, the secretary of the fair housing panel shall make an investigation thereof. Upon completion of the investigation, the complaint, along with the results of the investigation and any records, papers or statements pertaining thereto, shall be transmitted to the city council or board of commissioners for its consideration with recommendation, unless otherwise requested by the council or board of commissioners. (Code 1969, § 5-73(a); Code 1981, § 15-54; Ord. of 5-1-1978, § 1) Sec. 58-75. - Compliance with the federal law. Compliance with the provisions of the Fair Housing Amendments Act of 1988 (PL 100-430) shall be deemed compliance with the provisions of this article. In addition, should any provision of this article relating to the treatment of persons with disabilities be in conflict with any provision of the Fair Housing Amendment Act of 1988, then the provisions of the latter shall prevail.

div.head: Chapter 62 - PARKS AND RECREATION
div.p:
FOOTNOTE(S): --- (1) --- State Law reference— Power to provide parks, recreation areas, programs and facilities, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(5); authority of municipality to construct and operate parks, swimming pools, golf courses, recreation grounds and buildings used for sports, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-3; establishment of recreation systems authorized, O.C.G.A. § 36-64-1 et seq. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 62-1. - Purpose. The purpose of this section and sections 62-2 through 62-15 is to provide rules and regulations for the use of and conduct in the parks and recreation areas of the city. (Code 1981, § 16-1; Ord. No. 1992-3, 11-16-1992) Sec. 62-2. - Penalty. Any person violating any provision of section 62-1, this section and sections 62-3 through 62-14 shall be subject to a fine of not less than $5.00 nor more than $500.00 for each offense, and imprisonment in the city jail for a period of 12 months, or both such fine and imprisonment. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Code 1981, § 16-15; Ord. No. 1992-3, 11-16-1992) Sec. 62-3. - Applicability. This section, and sections 62-1, 62-2 and 62-4 through 62-15 shall apply in all parks and recreation areas under the jurisdiction of the city, unless expressly exempted. For the issuance of permits, temporary designations, authorizations, granting of approval and other actions the approving governing agency shall be the mayor and city council. (Code 1981, § 16-2; Ord. No. 1992-3, 11-16-1992) Sec. 62-4. - Construction. In the interpretation of this and all succeeding park and recreation area ordinances, the provisions shall be construed as follows: (1) Any term in the singular shall include the plural. (2) Any term in the masculine shall include the feminine and neuter. (3) Any requirement or prohibitions of any act, shall respectively extend to and include the causing and procuring, directly or indirectly, of such act. (4) No provision hereof shall make unlawful any act necessarily performed by any officer or employee of the commission or city in line of duty or work as such, or by any person, his/her agent or employees, in the proper and necessary execution of the terms of any agreement with the commission or city. (5) Any act otherwise prohibited by law or local ordinance shall be lawful if performed, under, by virtue of, and strictly within the provisions of a permit so to do, and to the extent authorized thereby hereby. (Code 1981, § 16-3; Ord. No. 1992-3, 11-16-1992) Sec. 62-5. - Structure, plants, trees, earth, rubbish. It shall be unlawful for any person in a public park or recreation area to: (1) Mark, deface, disfigure, injure, tamper with or displace or remove any buildings, bridges, tables, benches, fireplaces, railings, pavings or paving materials, water lines or other public utilities or parts or appurtenances thereof, signs, notices or placards, whether temporary or permanent, monuments, stakes, posts, or other boundary markers, or other structures or equipment, facilities or park property or appurtenances whatsoever, either real or personal. (2) Dig or remove any soil, rock, sand, stone, trees, shrubs or plants or other wood or materials, or make any excavation by tool, equipment, blasting or other means or agency. (3) Construct or erect any building or structure of whatever kind, whether permanent or temporary, or run or string any public service utility into, upon or across such lands, except on special written permit issued hereunder. (4) Damage, cut, carve, mark, transplant or remove any plant, or injure the bark, or pick flowers or seed of any tree or plant, dig in or otherwise disturb grass areas, or in any other way injure the natural beauty or usefulness of any area. (5) Throw, discharge, or otherwise place or cause to be placed in the waters of any fountains, pond, lake, stream or other body of water in or adjacent to any park or any tributary stream, storm sewer, or drain flowing into such water, any substance, matter or thing, liquid or solid, which will or may result in the pollution of said waters. (6) Take into, carry through, or put into any park any rubbish, refuse, garbage or other material. Such refuse and rubbish shall be deposited in receptacles so provided. Where receptacles are not provided, all such rubbish or waste shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence, and properly disposed of elsewhere. (Code 1981, § 16-4; Ord. No. 1992-3, 11-16-1992) Sec. 62-6. - Vehicles. It shall be unlawful for any person in a public park or recreation area to: (1) Drive any vehicle on any area except the paved park roads of parking areas, or such areas as may on occasion be specifically designated as temporary areas. (2) Park a vehicle anywhere except on a designated parking area. (3) Leave a vehicle standing or parked in established parking areas or elsewhere in the park and recreation areas during hours when the park and recreation area is closed. During a snowstorm and for three days thereafter, established parking areas in parks and recreation areas may be utilized for parking, but not by trailers of any kind. (4) Leave a bicycle in a place other than a bicycle rack when such is provided and there is space available. (5) Ride a bicycle without reasonable regard for the safety of others. (6) Leave a bicycle lying on the ground or paving or set against trees, or in any place or position where other persons may trip over or be injured by them. (7) Wash any vehicle. (8) Drive or operate within the parks, any bus or vehicle adapted for more than 12 passengers; any hearse, truck or tractor, or vehicle used for advertising provided that taxis, buses, and trucks may be used to carry visitors to the parks and recreation areas. (9) Use the parks, park drives, parking places or parkways for the purpose of demonstrating any vehicles, or for the purpose of instructing another to drive or operate any vehicle, nor shall any person use any park area, including parking places, for the repairing or cleaning of any vehicle, except in an emergency. (10) Cause or permit a vehicle in tow of another vehicle to enter the parks or proceed therein, except that in case of a breakdown a disabled vehicle may be towed to the nearest exit; or operate or drive a vehicle containing any person or object projecting or hanging outside of or beyond the side or the rear thereof. (Code 1981, § 16-5; Ord. No. 1992-3, 11-16-1992) Sec. 62-7. - Firearms, weapons, tools. It shall be unlawful for any person to bring into or have in his/her possession in any park or recreation area: (1) Any pistol or revolver or objects upon which loaded or blank cartridges may be used. Official starters, at authorized track and field events, are exempted from this restriction. (2) Any burglar tools. (3) Any rifle, shotgun, BB gun, air gun, spring gun, slingshot, bow or other weapon in which the propelling force is gunpowder, a spring or air. (Code 1981, § 16-6; Ord. No. 1992-3, 11-16-1992) Sec. 62-8. - Explosives and fireworks. It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his/her possession or set off any fireworks. Permits may be given for conducting properly supervised fireworks in designated park areas. (Code 1981, § 16-7; Ord. No. 1992-3, 11-16-1992) Sec. 62-9. - Advertising, assemblages, entertainment. No person shall post, paint, affix, distribute, deliver, place, cast or leave about, any bill, billboard, placard, ticket, handbill, circular or advertisement. (Code 1981, § 16-8; Ord. No. 1992-3, 11-16-1992) Sec. 62-10. - Merchandise, sale prohibited. No person shall expose or offer for sale any article in any park or recreation area, without a license as a concessionaire. (Code 1981, § 16-9; Ord. No. 1992-3, 11-16-1992) Sec. 62-11. - Ignitable and combustible materials. No person shall kindle, build, maintain or use a fire except in places provided for such purposes. Any fire shall be continuously under the care and direction of a competent person from the time it is kindled until it is extinguished. No person shall throw away or discard any lighted match, cigar, cigarette, tobacco, paper or other material within or against any building, boat or vehicle, or under any tree or in underbrush. (Code 1981, § 16-10; Ord. No. 1992-3, 11-16-1992) Sec. 62-12. - Alcoholic beverages, controlled dangerous substances, alms, gambling. While in a public park or recreation area, all persons shall conduct themselves in a proper and orderly manner, and in particular, no person shall: (1) Bring alcoholic beverages, or controlled dangerous substances, drink or use the same at any time; nor shall any person be under the influence of intoxicating liquor or a controlled dangerous substance in a park or recreation area. (2) Solicit alms or contributions for any purpose, whether public or private. (3) Play any game of chance or have possession of any instrument or device of gambling. (4) Play, engage or take part in any game or competitive sport for money, or other valuable thing, without a written permit. (Code 1981, § 16-11; Ord. No. 1992-3, 11-16-1992) Sec. 62-13. - Miscellaneous conduct. It shall be unlawful for any person in a park or recreation area to: (1) Camp or stay overnight anywhere except in areas designated for camping or staying overnight in vehicles or trailers. (2) Roller skate or use skateboards except in those areas specifically designed for such pastimes. (3) Enter an area posted as "closed to the public." (4) Engage in threatening, abusive, insulting or indecent language or engage in any disorderly conduct or behavior tending to breach the public peace. (5) Disturb or interfere unreasonably with any person or party occupying any area or participating in any activity under the authority of a permit. (6) Erect or occupy any tent, stand or other structure in any park or playground, or sell or give away from any such tent, stand or other structure any food, drink or other thing without a permit. (Code 1981, § 16-12; Ord. No. 1992-3, 11-16-1992) Sec. 62-14. - Closing hours. All city parks are closed from 11:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m.; provided, however, that anyone in the city parks between such time shall be asked by a police officer to leave the park and upon their refusal to leave said person shall be guilty of a violation of this article. (Code 1981, § 16-13; Ord. No. 1992-3, 11-16-1992) Sec. 62-15. - Enforcement. (a) The city police department, in connection with their duties imposed by law, diligently enforce the provisions of this article. (b) The city police department shall have the authority to order any person or persons acting in violation of this article to leave the park or recreation area. (Code 1981, § 16-14; Ord. No. 1992-3, 11-16-1992) Secs. 62-16—62-33. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - RECREATION COMMISSION
FOOTNOTE(S): --- (2) --- State Law reference— Park and recreation board, O.C.G.A. § 36-64-5. Sec. 62-34. - Established; composition; compensation; appointment of members; terms of office; vacancies. Under the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 36-64-5, there is hereby established a recreation commission. This commission shall consist of five persons serving without pay, who shall be appointed as follows: Three members shall be appointed by the mayor and two members by the chairperson of the county board of commissioners. All terms of office shall be five years or until their successors are appointed and qualified. Vacancies in such commission occurring otherwise than by expiration of term shall be filled by another appointment for the unexpired term. (Code 1969, § 11¼-16; Code 1981, § 16-20) Sec. 62-35. - Organizational meeting; election of president and other officers; power to adopt bylaws, rules and regulations. Immediately after their appointment, members of the recreation commission shall meet and organize by electing one of their members president and such other officers as may be necessary. The commission shall have power to adopt bylaws, rules and regulations for the proper conduct of recreation for the county and city. (Code 1969, § 11¼-17; Code 1981, § 16-21) Sec. 62-36. - General powers. The recreation commission shall provide, conduct and supervise public playgrounds, playfields, indoor recreation centers, and other recreation facilities owned or controlled by the county and city. It shall have the power to conduct any form of recreation or cultural activity that will employ the leisure time of the people in a wholesale or constructive manner. It may conduct such activities on properties under its own control, on public properties with the consent of the authorities thereof, and on private properties with the consent of the owner. (Code 1969, § 11¼-18; Code 1981, § 16-22) Sec. 62-37. - Superintendent or director and other personnel. The recreation commission shall have the power to appoint or designate someone to act as superintendent or director who is trained or properly qualified for the work, and such other personnel as the commission deems proper. (Code 1969, § 11¼-19; Code 1981, § 16-23) Sec. 62-38. - Budget; solicitation or receipt of gifts, etc. Annually, the recreation commission shall submit a budget to the city council for approval, the commission may also solicit or receive any gifts or bequests of money or other personal property or any donation to be applied, principal or income, for either temporary or permanent use for playgrounds or other recreational purposes. (Code 1969, § 11¼-20; Code 1981, § 16-24) Sec. 62-39. - Reports. The recreation commission shall make an annual report to the city council and such other reports as from time to time may be requested. (Code 1969, § 11¼-21; Code 1981, § 16-25)

div.head: Chapter 66 - PERSONNEL
div.p:
FOOTNOTE(S): --- (1) --- State Law reference— Municipal authority to establish, maintain and modify merit systems, retirement systems and insurance plans for its employees, Ga. Const. 1983, art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(14), O.C.G.A. § 36-34-2(4); municipal authority to fix compensation and benefits for its employees and members of its governing authority, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-4; Georgia Municipal Employees Benefit System, O.C.G.A. § 47-5-1 et seq. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 66-1. - Purpose. The purpose of this chapter is to establish a system of personnel administration for the city consistent with the following principles: (1) Recruiting, selecting and advancing employees on the basis of their relative ability, knowledge, and skills, including open consideration of qualified applicants for initial appointment; (2) Establishing pay rates and schedules consistent with the principles of comparable pay for comparable worth; (3) Training employees, as needed, to ensure high quality performance; (4) Retaining employees on the basis of the competency of their job performance, correcting inadequate or inconsistent job performance and separating or where possible, reassigning employees whose inadequate or incompetent job performance cannot be corrected; (5) Establishing a uniform system of handling grievances and appeal rights based on the principles of due process; (6) Ensuring equal opportunity to applicants and employees, alike in all respects, without regard to race, sex, age, color, national origin, political, disability or religious affiliation; and (7) Ensuring that employees are protected against coercion for partisan political purposes and are prohibited from using their official authority for the purpose of interfering with or affecting the result of an election or a nomination for local municipal office. (Code 1981, § 17-1; Ord. No. 1987-4, 12-7-1987) Sec. 66-2. - Council to amend policies. The city council shall, from time to time, promulgate, adopt and amend, by resolution, such policies as it deems necessary to carry into effect the purposes of this article. Such adopted policies shall have the same force and effect as an ordinance. (Code 1981, § 17-2; Ord. No. 1987-4, 12-7-1987) Sec. 66-3. - City manager to administer personnel system; duties. (a) The city manager shall be responsible for the administration of the personnel system adopted herein and shall direct all of its administrative and technical activities. It shall be the city manager's duty to: (1) Draft or have drafted new or changed personnel policies for submission to the council; (2) Advise the council on work force needs and utilization; (3) Foster and develop programs for the improvement of employee effectiveness including training, safety, health, counseling and services; (4) Establish and maintain records of all employees in the city government service, in which there will be set forth as to each employee the class, title, pay status and other relevant data; (5) Apply and carry out this article and the policies, rules and regulations adopted and promulgated hereunder, and to perform any other lawful act which may be necessary or desirable to carry out the purposes and provisions of this article. (b) The city manager or the city manager's authorized agent, shall be responsible for certification of the payroll vouchers that the persons named therein have been appointed and employed in accordance with the provisions of this article and the policies adopted hereunder. No city disbursing and auditing officer shall make or approve, or take any part in making or approving, any payment for personal services to any persons holding a position in the city unless such payroll voucher or account of such pay bears the certification of the city manager or the city manager's authorized agent. (Code 1981, § 17-3; Ord. No. 1987-4, 12-7-1987) Sec. 66-4. - Applicability of system; exceptions. The provisions of this chapter shall be applicable to all employees and all tenured positions in the city now existing or hereafter established, except as follows: (1) The members of the council and other elected officials; (2) Members of boards and commissions, the city attorney, judges and city manager; (3) Persons employed to make or conduct a temporary or special inquiry, investigation or examination on behalf of the council, committee thereof, or the city manager; (4) Substitute, seasonal or otherwise temporary positions unless specifically covered by action of the council or city manager; (5) Positions which by their nature (confidential or key policy-making) cannot or should not appropriately be included in the classification system are also exempted. (Code 1981, § 17-4; Ord. No. 1987-4, 12-7-1987) Sec. 66-5. - Reciprocal agreements; intergovernmental cooperation. (a) The city is authorized and empowered to enter into reciprocal agreements upon such terms as may be agreed upon, for the use of equipment, materials, facilities and services with any public agency or body for purposes deemed of benefit to the public personnel system. (b) The city manager may cooperate with other governmental agencies charged with public administration in conducting personnel tests, recruiting personnel, training personnel, establishing lists from which eligibles shall be certified for appointment and for the interchange of personnel and their benefits. (Code 1981, § 17-5; Ord. No. 1987-4, 12-7-1987) Sec. 66-6. - Public records. All personnel records, except examinations, employee performance reports, personnel histories and such other as may be specified by the council or city manager as confidential, shall be public records and shall be open for public inspection during office hours and reasonable times in accordance with such procedures as the city manager may prescribe. (Code 1981, § 17-6; Ord. No. 1987-4, 12-7-1987) Secs. 66-7—66-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - RETIREMENT
FOOTNOTE(S): --- (2) --- Editor's note—The retirement plan, executed on October 30, 1973, and amendments, are on file in the office of the city clerk. Sec. 66-31. - Purpose; declaration of policy. It is declared to be the policy and purpose of the city to extend, under the agreement entered into by the state and the federal social security administration, to the employees and officials of the city and its instrumentalities, not excluded by law or by this article, the benefits of the system of old age and survivors' insurance as authorized by the Federal Social Security Act, and the state enabling act, and amendments thereto. In pursuance of said policy, and for that purpose, the city shall take such action as may be required by applicable state or federal laws and regulations. (Code 1969, § 2-46; Code 1981, § 17-40; Ord. of 5-16-1974, § 1) Sec. 66-32. - Authority and directive to execute agreements. The mayor or other chief executive officer of the city is authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and amendments thereto with the Employees' Retirement System of Georgia for coverage of said employees and officials as provided for in this article, to include any employees that are in positions covered by a public retirement system, in the manner by said law provided; said additional employees being namely the police and firefighters. (Code 1969, § 2-47; Code 1981, § 17-41; Ord. of 5-16-1974, § 2) Sec. 66-33. - Withholdings from compensation. Withholdings from salaries or wages of employees and officials for the purpose provided for in this article are authorized to be made in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state and federal laws and regulations, and shall be paid over to the state agency. (Code 1969, § 2-48; Code 1981, § 17-42; Ord. of 5-16-1974, § 3) Sec. 66-34. - Contributions by city. There shall be appropriated by the city from general funds such amounts at such times as may be required by applicable state and federal laws and regulations for employer's contributions, administrative expenses and a guaranty fund to ensure that the state will not incur any debt or loss as a result of the agreement referred to in this article. Such funds shall be paid over to the Employees' Retirement System of Georgia in accordance with regulations established by said agency. (Code 1969, § 2-49; Code 1981, § 17-43; Ord. of 5-16-1974, § 4) Sec. 66-35. - Records and reports. The city shall keep such records and make such reports under this article as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. (Code 1969, § 2-50; Code 1981, § 17-44; Ord. of 5-16-1974, § 5) Sec. 66-36. - Unauthorized employees excluded. There is excluded from this article any authority to make any agreement with respect to any position, or any employee or official not authorized to be covered by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. (Code 1969, § 2-51; Code 1981, § 17-45; Ord. of 5-16-1974, § 6)

div.head: Chapter 70 - SOLID WASTE
div.p:
FOOTNOTE(S): --- (1) --- State Law reference— Municipal authority to provide for garbage and solid waste collection and disposal, Ga. Const. 1983, art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(2); Georgia Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 70-1. - Definitions. As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Abandoned means an article of machinery, appliance, vehicle, equipment and other material, shall be deemed to have been abandoned or discarded when it has remained upon a property in an inoperable condition for more than ten days, or when it has become inoperable and the owner does not intend to repair it and place it back into operation. Abandoned vehicle means a vehicle that is in a state of disrepair and incapable of being moved under its own power. It shall be prima facie evidence that a vehicle has been abandoned if the owner or person in possession of such vehicle cannot furnish satisfactory evidence that the motor vehicle license fee required by O.C.G.A. § 48-10-2 has been paid and that the Georgia Motor Vehicle Accident Reparations Act (O.C.G.A. § 33-34-1) has been complied with as respect to such motor vehicle. Appliance means any type of machine or device used in and about the home or premises, and includes, but shall not be limited to, refrigerators, iceboxes, freezers, stoves, washing machines, clothes dryers, television sets, radio sets, lawn mowers and other devices of like nature. Automobile graveyard means any establishment which is maintained or used for storing, buying or selling wrecked, scrapped, ruined, dismantled, abandoned or discarded motor vehicles or for motor vehicle repairs. C and D waste means waste materials generated by construction, remodeling, repair or demolition of residential, commercial or other premises. Commercial solid waste. (1) The term "commercial solid waste" means all garbage, trash, refuse, rubbish and other acceptable waste generated by a commercial premises and C and D waste. (2) The term "commercial solid waste" does not include hazardous waste. Dealers in junk or metals means any person, partnership firm or corporation who owns, leases, operates or otherwise maintains facilities for processing junk or metals or who buys, sells or in any way deals in any used or discarded metal material or articles. Dismantler means any person, partnership, firm, or corporation engaged in the business of acquiring wrecked, abandoned or repairable motor vehicles and selling either the usable parts, the motor vehicle as a unit or the hulk of the motor vehicle after the usable parts have been removed. For the purposes of this chapter, a person, partnership, firm or corporation shall be presumed to be engaged in the business of auto dismantling if he/she or it possesses three or more inoperative motor vehicles for more than ten days. Garbage. (1) The term "garbage" means organic waste matter, both animal and vegetable, including but not limited to waste matter, from houses, kitchens, restaurants, hotels, hospitals and other such places, and it comprises chiefly waste food. (2) The term "garbage" does not include moisture that may be drained in the sewer or human body wastes. Junk means any: (1) Old or scrap copper, brass, rope, rags, battery, paper, trash, rubber, radiator, debris or waste; (2) Junked, dismantled or wrecked automobiles, or parts thereof; (3) Iron, steel, and any other scrap ferrous or nonferrous material; or (4) Abandoned or discarded machinery, appliance, vehicle, equipment or material of any description or kind whatsoever. Major component part means one of the following subassemblies of a motor vehicle: (1) Front clip assembly (fenders, grille and hood); (2) Rear clip assembly (quarter panels and floor panel assembly); (3) Engine and transmission; (4) Top assembly, with the exception of soft tops; (5) Frame or frame sections; or (6) Complete side (fenders, door and quarter panel). Motor vehicle means any vehicle which is self-propelled except trackless trolleys (which are classified as streetcars), motorcycles, motor-driven cycles, or go-carts. Nuisance means anything that causes hurt, inconvenience or damage to another, and the fact that the act done may otherwise be lawful shall not keep it from being a nuisance. The inconvenience complained of shall not be fanciful, or such as would affect only one of fastidious taste, but shall be such as would affect an ordinary, reasonable man. Part means any used motor vehicle part that has been installed as standard or optional equipment on a motor vehicle, has been removed from the motor vehicle on which it was originally attached or affixed, and is the subject of sale or resale as a part and not as scrap. Rebuilder means any person, partnership, firm, or corporation engaged in the business of buying more than three used, salvage, or wrecked motor vehicles per year for the purpose of restoring or rebuilding them with used or new motor vehicle parts, or both, to be sold as motor vehicles. Salvage dealer means any person, firm or corporation who purchases a salvage vehicle or parts of a salvage vehicle for the purposes of resale as parts only or as salvage. Salvage vehicle means any vehicle which either: (1) Has been damaged, crushed, or otherwise reduced to such a state that its restoration would require the replacement of two or more major component parts; (2) Has been acquired by an insurance company as a result of the vehicle's being damaged to the extent that its restoration to an operable condition would require the replacement of two or more major component parts or for which the insurance company has paid a total loss claim, excluding recovered total theft vehicles which do not require the replacement of two or more major component parts for restoration; or (3) Is an imported vehicle which has been damaged in shipment and disclaimed by the manufacturer as a result of the damage, has never been the subject of a retail sale to a consumer, and has never been issued a certificate of title. Scrap processor means any person, firm or corporation engaged in the business of buying or otherwise acquiring iron and metals including, but not limited to, old automobiles, aluminum, glass and parts thereof for the purpose of processing into raw materials for remelting or recycling. Scrap vehicle means any vehicle which has been wrecked, destroyed, or damaged to the extent that it cannot be economically repaired, rebuilt or made operable or road worthy. Solid waste means trash and or garbage as defined in this section. Trash means rubbish such as feathers, paper, cans, bottles, boxes, wood, glass, shrubs, yard clippings, tree trimmings and all similar matter. Unsafe building means any building or structure that has any of the following conditions, such that the life, health, property or safety of the general public or its occupant are endangered: (1) Whenever any means of egress or portion thereof is not of adequate size or is not arranged to provide a safe path of travel in case of fire or panic. (2) Whenever any means of egress of portion thereof, such as but not limited to, fire doors, closing devices, fire-resistive ratings, are in disrepair or in a dilapidated or nonworking condition such that the means of egress could be rendered unsafe in case of fire or panic. (3) Whenever the stress in any material, member or portion thereof, due to all imposed loads including dead load exceeds the working stresses allowed in the International Building Code (IBC) for new buildings. (4) Whenever a building, structure or portion thereof has been damaged by fire, flood, earthquake, wind or other cause to the extent that the structural integrity of the buildings or structures is less than it was prior to the damage and is less than the minimum requirement established by the International Building Code (IBC) for new buildings. (5) Whenever any exterior appendages or portion of a building or structure is not securely fastened, attached or anchored such that it is capable of resisting wind, seismic or similar loads as required by the International Building Code (IBC) for new buildings. (6) Whenever for any reason a building, structure or portion thereof is manifestly unsafe or unsanitary for the purpose for which it is being used. (7) Whenever any building, structure or portion thereof as a result of decay, deterioration or dilapidation is likely to fully or partially collapse. (8) Whenever any building, structure or portion thereof has been constructed or maintained in violation of a specific requirement of the standard codes or of a city, county or state law. (9) Whenever any building, structure or portion thereof is in such a condition as to constitute a public nuisance. (10) Whenever any building, structure or portion thereof is unsafe, unsanitary or not provided with adequate egress, or which constitutes a fire hazard, or is otherwise dangerous to human life, or, which in relation to existing use, constitutes a hazard to safety or health by reason of inadequate maintenance, dilapidation, obsolescence or abandonment. Weed means a plant considered undesirable, unattractive or troublesome, especially one growing where it is not wanted. (Code 1981, § 11-1; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987; Ord. of 6-29-2009) Sec. 70-2. - Sweeping trash; placing in gutters; burning, prohibited. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person or business to sweep or move garbage, trash, junk, refuse, or litter from any business, house, residence, or vacant area so as to intrude upon or interfere with any other business, residence, sidewalk, street, alleyway or passerby. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person or business to place garbage, trash, junk, refuse or litter in the gutters, storm sewers or drainage ditches of the city. (c) It shall be unlawful for any person or business to burn garbage, trash, junk, refuse or litter within the city limits, except under special permit given by the city. Such items and materials shall be placed in proper containers convenient for removal by the city. (Code 1981, § 11-2; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 70-3. - Approval of solid waste haulers. No person other than those under the direction of the city council shall haul away or remove any solid waste set out for collection except by written consent of the city council. (Code 1981, § 11-3) Sec. 70-4. - Receptacles—City to furnish; use required. For all households and businesses, there shall be provided by the city receptacles for all garbage for removal by the city. The public works director shall review the service requirements for households and businesses and specify receptacles of a sufficient size and number to hold the garbage accumulated between collections. The accumulation of garbage in open bins or other contrivances which endanger the health and safety of the general public is prohibited. (Code 1981, § 11-4; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987; Ord. No. 1988-2, pt. 1, 1-20-1988) Sec. 70-5. - Same—Accumulation and storage of garbage and refuse therein. All garbage shall be accumulated as specified in this chapter and placed in appropriate receptacles. Garbage only shall be placed in a garbage receptacle and refuse only shall be placed in a refuse receptacle. (Code 1981, § 11-5; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 70-6. - Same—Placement for collection. Receptacles provided for garbage collection shall be placed so as to be accessible to the collector in removing same, but not in such place as will be a detriment to the appearance of the streets and ways of the city. It shall be the responsibility of the public works department to designate receptacle locations to ensure compliance with the intent of this section. (Code 1981, § 11-6; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987; Ord. No. 1988-2, pt. 2, 1-20-1988) Sec. 70-7. - Same—Duty of owners, landlords, tenants and storekeepers. It shall be the duty of each owner, landlord, tenant or storekeeper to see that all garbage receptacles, and the contents as provided for in this chapter, are set out at such place and time as may be fixed by the city council. No employee of the city shall assist in the performance of the duty of the owner, landlord, tenant or storekeeper under this section; provided, however, that any person with a physical disability shall not be required to place their containers curbside. Persons with physical disabilities shall be required to obtain a doctor's excuse for special service. Such persons shall make application for special service using forms supplied by the city. (Code 1981, § 11-7; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987; Ord. No. 1988-2, pt. 3, 1-20-1988) Sec. 70-8. - Scavenging and interference prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to scavenge, sift through, carry away, take, pilfer or otherwise handle or deal in solid waste set out for removal by the city, other than that generated at the home or business of such person. It shall be unlawful for any person to molest or interfere with any garbage receptacle set out for removal by the city unless by written permission by the city. (Code 1981, § 11-8; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 70-9. - Solid waste collection fees—Schedule. There shall be imposed a solid waste fee on each business establishment and residence in the city. Such fee, when imposed, shall be payable monthly. The amounts of the fees shall be as established by the city council from time to time. (Code 1981, § 11-9; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987; Ord. No. 1988-2, pt. 4, 1-20-1988) Sec. 70-10. - Dumping materials on lots. No garbage, offensive materials or disease-producing materials shall be dumped on any lot or space within the city for the purpose of filling, storage or for any other purpose. (Code 1981, § 11-11; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) State Law reference— Littering, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-43. Sec. 70-11. - Commercial and C and D waste. No person other than those under the direction of the city council shall haul away or remove any commercial solid waste and/or C and D waste set out for collection except by written consent by the city council. (Code 1981, § 11-13; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987; Ord. of 6-29-2009) Secs. 70-12—70-42. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - LANDFILL OPERATIONS
FOOTNOTE(S): --- (2) --- State Law reference— Municipal authority to provide for garbage and solid waste collection and disposal, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(2); Georgia Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq. Sec. 70-43. - Definitions. For the purpose of this article, the following terms, phrases, and words shall have the meaning indicated herein, unless the context indicates otherwise: City landfill means any landfill or sanitary landfill which is owned, leased or operated by the city or any such landfill or sanitary landfill for which the city has been issued a solid waste handling permit pursuant to the Solid Waste Management Act of the state, whether such permit is held solely by the city or jointly with any other governmental body. Director means the director of the division of environmental protection of the department of natural resources. Disposal facility means any facility or location where any treatment, utilization, processing, or deposition of solid waste occurs. Disposal operation means the performance of solid waste disposal which includes administration, personnel, land, equipment, design and other elements necessary or used in the work of solid waste disposal. Disposal site means the location where the final deposition of solid waste occurs. Garbage means food waste including waste accumulations of animal or vegetable matter used or intended for use as food, or that attends the preparation, use, cooking, dealing in or storing of meat, fish, fruit or vegetables. Landfill means a disposal site where solid wastes, other than putrescible wastes or hazardous wastes, are disposed of using landfilling techniques. Landfilling means a method of disposing of solid wastes except putrescible wastes or hazardous wastes, on land, by placing an earth cover thereon. Sanitary landfill means a disposal site where solid wastes are disposed of using sanitary landfilling techniques. Sanitary landfilling means a method of disposing of putrescible wastes and/or hazardous wastes on land by placing an earth cover thereon. Scavenge means the uncontrolled picking from discarded solid waste materials. Solid waste handling means the storage, collection, transportation, treatment, utilization, processing or disposal of solid wastes, or any combination thereof. Solid waste handling permit means written authorization granted to a person by the director to engage in solid waste handling. Solid Waste Management Act or the Act, wherever referred to in these rules and regulations, means O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq. (Code 1981, § 12-30; Ord. No. 1985-3, § 1, 4-1-1985) Sec. 70-44. - Penalty. Any person found guilty of violating any section of this article shall be punished according to the general penalties described in section 1-8. (Code 1981, § 12-34; Ord. No. 1985-3, § 1, 4-1-1985) Sec. 70-45. - Permit for reclamation, recycling, etc. No permit shall be issued by the city to any person granting them permission to go upon the premises of any city landfill for the purpose of collecting any type of solid waste or other material located on said landfill for the purpose of reclamation, recycling or any other purpose. (Code 1981, § 12-31; Ord. No. 1985-3, § 1, 4-1-1985) Sec. 70-46. - Scavenging prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to go upon the premises for purposes of scavenging or removing any material from any city landfill except for employees of the city or of the county in their official capacity as employees and in furtherance of their employment and duties. (Code 1981, § 12-32; Ord. No. 1985-3, § 1, 4-1-1985) Sec. 70-47. - Hours of operation. The regular hours of operation of any city landfill shall be posted at said landfill site which shall be the hours in which any member of the general public may go onto the landfill site for the purpose of delivering garbage or solid waste to said landfill site. It shall be unlawful for any person to be upon the premises of any city landfill except during the regular hours as are posted at the city landfill site; provided, however, that the provisions of this section shall not apply to any employee of the city or of the county when said employee is engaged in his/her normal course of employment and duties. (Code 1981, § 12-33; Ord. No. 1985-3, § 1, 4-1-1985) Secs. 70-48—70-67. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - WEEDS, GRASS CLIPPINGS, TREE LIMBS
Sec. 70-68. - Unsightly, unhealthful and hazardous growth of weeds prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person or business to allow or permit weeds, grass, shrubs, trees, and other vegetation to grow and be upon such person's or business' premises uncut or untrimmed so as to render the premises unsightly, unhealthful, or hazardous from the growth and accumulation of such vegetation. Any growth of weeds, grass, shrubs, trees or other vegetation which presents a present or potential threat of fire, vermin, rodents, obnoxious insects, pestilence or disease shall be considered unsightly, unhealthful and hazardous. (Code 1981, § 11-14; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 70-69. - Weeds declared a nuisance. To permit the growth and accumulation of weeds, grass, shrubs, trees or other vegetation so as to render the premises unsightly, unhealthful or hazardous, if within 100 feet of any building or within 100 feet of any street or public ground, is declared to be a nuisance and will be subject to abatement as provided in chapter 50, article IV. (Code 1981, § 11-15; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Sec. 70-70. - Tree limbs, grass clippings, cuttings, etc., when picked up; length. Tree limbs, grass clippings, cuttings, shrubbery and other similar trash of no more than one-half load per week will be hauled; provided such limbs, cuttings, shrubbery and other such trash if cut three feet in length and placed in piles at the front corner of the owner's or tenant's property nearest to the street or public alley. Tree limbs, shrubbery and other similar trash will not be picked up by the city if the property owner or tenant has had the work performed by a licensed contractor. (Code 1981, § 11-16; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987; Ord. of 8-3-2009(2)) Sec. 70-71. - Trimmings not to be placed in gutters; declaration of nuisance. It shall be unlawful for any person or business to place tree limbs, grass clippings, cuttings, shrubbery and other similar trash in the gutter, storm sewers or drainage ditches of the city. To place or permit to be placed such trimmings in the gutter, storm sewer or drainage ditches of the city is declared to be a nuisance and will be subject to abatement as provided in chapter 50, article IV. (Code 1981, § 11-17; Ord. No. 1987-3, 11-16-1987) Secs. 70-72—70-100. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - WATER; SEWER AND SOLID WASTE
Sec. 70-101. - Services. The city is dedicated to providing our customers with professional service at a reasonable cost. All accounts are important and the city wishes to serve the public in a courteous, friendly and helpful manner. The following services are available without regard to race, color, sex, age, disability, religion or national origin: (1) Deposits. All new accounts (renters and owners) will be required to pay a deposit as follows when opening a new account: a. Residential service .....$ 75.00 b. Commercial service ..... 125.00 Deposits will be refunded upon the customer's notification to the city that services are no longer needed and a reading of the meter has been taken. Any unpaid balance will be deducted from the customer's deposit. If the amount due is more than the deposit the customer will be responsible for the remaining balance. It is the customer's responsibility to notify the city of the date that service is no longer required. The customer is ultimately responsible for any unpaid balance. (2) Meter readings. Water meters are read each month. Readings are divided into two books. The readings are done with the use of radio reads and some by hand. In the event of an unusual circumstance where a meter is unable to be read by any means, an average will be done as a last measure. (3) Late charges; cut offs. All payments are due and receivable by the city on or before the tenth day of each month. Weekends and city holidays are considered with penalties if a payment is made the next business date. A five percent late charge is added to the account when full payment is not received within the stated period of time. If the city does not receive full payment within 30 days from the due date, the account is placed in the cutoff status and water service is disconnected until payment is received. Once a meter has been cut off, full payment must be received and a reconnection fee of $20.00 is required to have the water services reinstated. Partial payments will be accepted but services will not be reinstated until full payment, plus any late charges and fees, are paid. Every customer's account must be paid by 4:00 p.m. on the date services are disconnected in order for services to be restored the same day. If payment is not received once the water is cut off, during the next billing cycle of the account, the account is placed in a final status and the deposit is used toward the bill. The customer is then required to pay a new deposit upon reconnection of services. Any bill that remains with an outstanding balance due and that is over 90 days past due will receive a letter notifying them that the account is subject to collections. Ten days after notification and if the account remains unpaid and all efforts to collect the account have been exhausted, the city is authorized to pursue the account in whatever action it deems appropriate, including but not limited to magistrate court and/or placement of liens on the subject's property. 1 month 10th penalty is placed on the customer's bill 2 month 10th cutoff of customer's services 3 month 10th finalized customer's bill/new deposit required, if services are desired again
(4) Fines. If water services have been cut off due to nonpayment and the city's meter is cut on illegally by anyone other than an authorized agent of the city, a fee of $50.00 will be applied to the customer's account by the water department and a citation written by the city police department for theft by taking is filed and the customer may appear in court where additional fines may be deemed payable also. (5) Water meter ownership. All water meters are the property of the city. Installation fees are for the cost incurred by the city for providing the connection and not the purchase of a meter by the customer. Water meter valves are not designed for or are they to be used for cutting off water flow to a home or business by anyone other than a city representative. A separate cut off valve should be installed by a licensed plumber at the owner's expense for the cutting of water on and off by the property owner. The property owner is responsible for all leaks and repairs from the connection at the meter on the property owner's side of the meter. (6) Installation of meters. Meters are installed only by the city. A request must be made by the property owner and an installation fee according to size of pipe requested and the corresponding published fees are paid in full. The director of public works will determine the feasibility of connections for all new requests according to location and economical cost. The city will install the meter in a timely manner after all requirements are met and payment received, provided however, reasonable conditions exist which would not prevent, interfere, or prolong installation of the meter. (7) Billing/rates. The immediate prior month's accounts are entered in the computer as each book of customers has been read and finalized. Billing statements are mailed at intervals corresponding with each book's monthly closure. Computerized statements are then printed for mailing. The statement includes the previous month's reading, current reading, total gallons consumed, amount of charges for water, sewer and garbage, due date and late fee, should it be incurred. Water
0—2,000 gallons $5.00
Next 3,000 gallons (this equals the first 5,000 gallons) $2.10—$6.30
5,000—10,000 gallons $2.25—$11.25
10,000—15,000 gallons $2.35—$11.75
Above 15,000 gallons $2.50 Sewer
0—2,000 gallons $5.00
Next 3,000 gallons (this equals the first 5,000 gallons) $2.10—$6.30
5,000—10,000 gallons $2.25—$11.25
10,000—15,000 gallons $2.35—$11.75
Above 15,000 gallons $2.50 Outside city limits (All rates for water and sewer) Doubled Garbage
Residential
First can $16.00
Second can $13.00
Commercial Total monthly minimum bill $26.00
Customers are responsible for payment of water/sewer/garbage/trash billing combined as one bill monthly. (8) Rate adjustments. A rate adjustment may be granted by the public works director or city manager for a customer who has had a sudden accidental leak and has had the leak repaired by a licensed plumber. An adjustment is eligible twice per year per customer. (See adjustment policy for eligibility). Any more than two per calendar year must be approved by the public works director and the city manager. (9) Write down/write offs. Please refer to article V of this chapter, pertaining to the city's write down/write off policy. (10) Request for services outside the city. All requests for water and/or sewer services must be made to the public works director in writing and containing details as to the applicant's name and address, exact location of the property, distance from applicant's property line to nearest service connection, size of line, type of customer, commercial, industrial, residential, etc., and other information deemed necessary by the city. The public works director or his/her designee shall make a determination as to the feasibility of the service extension outside the incorporated area and make such recommendation to the city manager and mayor. Should the recommendation be made to make the extension, the city shall follow the procedures as set forth and outlined in the city/county agreement dated August 1999. (11) Sewer stoppages. The property owner is responsible for any stoppage in the sewer pipe from the facility to the tie-in of the city's main line. Before the city responds to a customer's call for assistance, the customer must have called a licensed plumber to check for stoppages to the point of the main line. If the plumber cannot unstop the line, the plumber, not the resident, must call city hall giving all the details of the problem before the city can respond. Once the city has responded to a call and found the stoppage to be on the customer's line, a fee of $25.00 is charged to the customer. (12) Sewer line repair/replacement. The customer is responsible for the repair, maintenance, and replacement of sewer lines from the structure to the main line of the city. If the damaged line goes under a sidewalk or public paved area, the city will have the option, at its expense, to repair or replace the existing sewer line from the connection at the main line to the end of the city-owned right-of-way; or may determine the best and more feasible option to make a separate connection at another alternative location. (Ord. of 2-2-2009(01)) Secs. 70-102—70-130. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - WATER/SEWER AND SOLID WASTE DEPARTMENT WRITE DOWN/WRITE OFF
Sec. 70-131. - Purpose. The purpose of this article is to establish fair and opened procedures for write off or write down of bills for water, sewer and waste management services. (Ord. of 2-2-2009(02)) Sec. 70-132. - Narrative. There are numerous reasons why a water, sewer or waste management bill may need to be written down or written off completely. Some can be caused by the city such as faulty meters, bad meter readings, etc. Sometimes the blame may lie with the customer such as undetected leaks. And even sometimes the blame is unassigned such as the untimely death of a customer with no survivors. A write down or write off may be the result of a customer falling on financial hardship beyond their control. Whatever the facts and circumstances, the city would like to provide procedures that will deal with the situation in a fair and considerate manner for the customer while not violating the public trust. (Ord. of 2-2-2009(02)) Sec. 70-133. - Procedure. In order to ensure all write offs and write downs are done in an open manner, a log of each write down or write off will be maintained in the billing department. No biller or city personnel can cause a write down or write off without checking the log first to verify it has been recorded and approval has been secured under the following authorization levels. The following limits of approval for a write down or write off will be in force as of the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived: Managers (city manager and public works director) $1.00 to $500.00 Mayor $501.00 to $1,000.00 City council $1,001.00 and above
The managers' and mayor's authorizations can be evidenced by their signature on the appropriate log line. The city council's authorization will be supported by official minutes of city council meetings and signed off on by the city clerk on the appropriate log line. (Ord. of 2-2-2009(02))

div.head: Chapter 74 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC GROUNDS
div.p:
FOOTNOTE(S): --- (1) --- State Law reference— City has power to construct and maintain roads, including curbs, sidewalks, streetlights and devices to control the flow of traffic, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(4); municipal street systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-90 et seq.; powers with respect to municipal street system, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-92; regulation of maintenance and use of public roads generally, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-1 et seq.; municipal authority to regulate alleys, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-3. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 74-1. - Street names—Changing, etc. The council by resolution may change, rename or name an existing or newly established street within the city at any time upon recommendation of the planning commission. (Code 1981, § 20-1; Ord. of 6-16-1975, § 14) Sec. 74-2. - Same—Choosing name. (a) In the case of streets which bear no name, the city council shall be empowered to choose names which it feels are appropriate and which are suitable to the residents of said street. (b) In the case of streets which bear a name in common with another street or if the name is similar enough so as to cause confusion, the city council shall be empowered to rename one of the streets. (Code 1981, § 20-2; Ord. of 6-16-1975, § 12) Sec. 74-3. - Same—Directional prefixes. (a) All streets perpendicular to and crossing the east-west baseline shall be given a prefix of "north" for the section which lies to the north of the baseline and a prefix of "south" for the section which lies to the south of the baseline. (b) All streets perpendicular to and crossing the north-south baseline shall be given a prefix of "east" for the section which lies to the east of the baseline and a prefix of "west" for the section which lies to the west of the baseline. (Code 1981, § 20-3; Ord. of 6-16-1975, § 6) Sec. 74-4. - Access drives; furnishing by city. The city will assist property owners in establishing ingress and egress to and from their property from city-owned public roads as follows: (1) The city will provide at no charge the labor, equipment and material necessary to provide a 20-foot-wide access drive at a location designated by the property owner. This shall be limited to one access drive per contiguous parcel of land. Any additional access drive will be provided only when the property owner pays for the additional cost of labor, equipment and material. (2) The city manager or the city manager's designated staff shall first approve the location, width and material quality and size based upon the criteria of proper traffic flow, drainage and road construction. (3) If the property is located on state routes, then state regulations shall prevail. The city shall provide additional access drives only to the extent that the private property owner will reimburse the city for the costs of labor, equipment and material. (4) In the event of undue hardships or exigent circumstances and upon application, the mayor and council may determine that an additional access drive should be installed at particular locations and may provide for such additional access drive at no additional expense to the owner or upon such terms and conditions as may be set forth by the mayor and city council. (Code 1981, § 20-4; Ord. of 8-6-1973, § 1; Ord. No. 1986-4, 6-16-1986) Sec. 74-5. - Merchandise, etc., on sidewalks. It shall be unlawful for any person to display any goods, wares, merchandise or produce on the sidewalks of the city, or to place any shelf, stand, basket or other structure or receptacle for holding goods, wares, or merchandise or fruits, vegetables or other produce, upon the sidewalks of the city, when the same interferes with free flow of traffic. (Code 1969, § 12-2; Code 1981, § 20-5) Sec. 74-6. - Signs prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person, other than by government authority, to erect or place a sign, either temporary or permanent, on the right-of-way of any state or federal highway or on any street or sidewalk in the city. (Code 1969, § 12-1; Code 1981, § 20-6) Secs. 74-7—74-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - NUMBERING SYSTEM
Sec. 74-31. - Established; compliance. There is hereby established a uniform system for numbering buildings fronting on all streets, avenues and public ways in the city. All houses and other buildings shall be numbered in accordance with the provisions of this article. (Code 1981, § 20-20; Ord. of 6-16-1975, § 1) Sec. 74-32. - Baselines and quadrants designated. (a) The baseline for numbering properties along all streets running north and south shall hereinafter be referred to as the east-west baseline and shall be constituted as follows: Twelfth Street from the west city limits through its intersection with Pierce Street and eastward to its ending at Bead Street and from thence due east to its junction with Georgia State Route 32, on which the line shall continue eastward. (b) The baseline for numbering properties along all streets running east and west shall hereinafter be referred to as the north-south baseline and shall be constituted as follows: Pierce Street (U.S. 1) from the south city limits northward to its juncture with Twelfth Street and thence northward to Fourth Street. From this point the baseline shall leave Pierce Street and continue due north until the line rejoins U.S. 1 north. (c) Each building to the north of the east-west baseline and facing a street running in a northerly direction shall carry a number and address indicating its location north of said baseline. (d) Each building to the south of the east-west baseline and facing a street running in a southerly direction shall carry a number and address indicating its location south of said baseline. (e) Each building to the west of the north-south baseline and facing a street running in a westerly direction shall carry a number and address indicating its location west of said baseline. (f) Each building to the east of the north-south baseline and facing a street running in an easterly direction shall carry a number and address indicating its location east of said baseline. (g) All buildings on diagonal streets shall be numbered the same as buildings on northerly and southerly streets if the diagonal runs more north-south, and the same rule shall apply on easterly and westerly streets if the diagonal runs more east-west. All buildings on diagonal streets having a deviation of exactly 45 degrees shall be numbered the same as buildings on northerly and southerly streets. (Code 1981, § 20-21; Ord. of 6-16-1975, § 2) Sec. 74-33. - Sequence and intervals. (a) The numbering of buildings on each street shall begin at the baseline. All numbers shall be assigned on the basis of one number for each 50 feet, except those fronting on the following streets: (1) On Twelfth Street between Route 32 bypass and Pierce Street; (2) On Fourteenth Street between Route 32 bypass and Pierce Street; (3) On Fifteenth Street between Route 32 bypass and Pierce Street; (4) Dixon Street between Wall Street and Fifteenth Street; (5) Church Street between Wall Street and Fifteenth Street; (6) Thomas Street between Twelfth and Fifteenth Streets. (b) The streets named in subsection (a) of this section shall be assigned numbers on the basis of one number for each 25 feet of frontage. (Code 1981, § 20-22; Ord. of 6-16-1975, § 3) Sec. 74-34. - Odd-even sides; separate numbers per entrance. (a) All buildings on the right side of each street running from the baseline shall bear odd numbers. All buildings on the left side of each street running from the baseline shall bear even numbers. (b) Where any building has more than one entrance serving separate occupants, a separate number shall be assigned to each entrance serving a separate occupant. If the building is not located on a lot, parcel or tract which would permit the assignment of one number to each such entrance, letters shall be used, as set forth in section 74-37. (Code 1981, § 20-23; Ord. of 6-16-1975, § 4) Sec. 74-35. - Numbers on streets not extending to baseline. All buildings facing streets not extending through the baselines shall be assigned the same relative numbers as if said streets had extended to the baseline. (Code 1981, § 20-24; Ord. of 6-16-1975, § 5) Sec. 74-36. - Display of assigned numbers. (a) The assigned numbers shall be displayed at all times. (b) The numbers shall be conspicuously placed immediately above, on or at the side of the main entrance so that the number can be seen plainly from the street line. (c) Whenever any building is situated such that the main entrance is more than 50 feet from the street line or said entrance is obscured, then the numbers may be placed upon a gatepost, fence, tree, post or other appropriate place so as to be easily discernable from the street. (d) The numerals shall be no less than three inches in height and be made out of a durable and highly visible material. (Code 1981, § 20-25; Ord. of 6-16-1975, § 7) Sec. 74-37. - Use of letters of alphabet. Where only one number can be assigned to a building, the owner, occupant or agent of such building, who shall desire distinctive numbers for different parts of said building, shall use the suffix A, B, C, etc., as may be required. (Code 1981, § 20-26; Ord. of 6-16-1975, § 8) Sec. 74-38. - Street map. For the purpose of facilitating a correct numbering, a map of all streets, avenues and public ways within the city showing the proper numbers of all houses or other buildings fronting upon all streets, avenues or public ways shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk. This map shall be open to inspection of all persons during the office hours of the city clerk. (Code 1981, § 20-27; Ord. of 6-16-1975, § 9) Sec. 74-39. - Determining numbers. It shall be the duty of the code enforcement officer to inform any party applying therefor of the numbers belonging to or embraced within the limits of any said lot or property as provided in this article. In case of conflict as to the proper number to be assigned to any building, the building inspector shall determine the number of such building. (Code 1981, § 20-28; Ord. of 6-16-1975, § 10) Sec. 74-40. - New buildings. Whenever any house, building or structure shall hereafter be erected or located in the city, in order to preserve the continuity and uniformity of numbers of the houses, buildings and structures, it shall be the duty of the owner to procure the correct numbers as designated from the building inspector for the property and to immediately fasten said numbers so assigned upon said building as provided by this article. No building permit shall be issued for any house, building or structure until the owner has procured from the building inspector the official number of the premises. Final approval of any structure shall be withheld by the code enforcement officer until permanent and proper numbers have been affixed to said structure. (Code 1981, § 20-29; Ord. of 6-16-1975, § 11)

div.head: Chapter 78 - SUBDIVISIONS
div.p:
FOOTNOTE(S): --- (1) --- State Law reference— Recording of maps and plats, O.C.G.A. § 15-6-67 et seq.; subdivisions abutting state highways, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-150 et seq.; the Zoning Procedures Laws, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-1 et seq.; Georgia Land Sales Act, O.C.G.A. § 44-3-1 et seq. ARTICLE I. - AUTHORITY AND JURISDICTION
Sec. 78-1. - Authority. The provisions of this chapter are enacted in pursuance of the authority granted by the 1983 Constitution of Georgia, article IX, section II, paragraph IV. (Ord. of 10-30-1972(2), § 11) Sec. 78-2. - Jurisdiction. The provisions of this chapter shall govern all subdivision of land within the corporate limits. (Ord. of 10-30-1972(2), § 12) Secs. 78-3—78-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PURPOSE AND SHORT TITLE
Sec. 78-21. - Purpose. This chapter is enacted to encourage the development of an economically sound and stable community; to ensure the provision of required streets, utilities and other facilities and services to new land developments; to ensure the adequate provision of safe and convenient traffic access and circulation, both vehicular and pedestrian, in new land developments; to ensure the provision of needed public open spaces and building sites in new land developments to the dedication or reservation of land for recreational, educational and other public purposes; to ensure, in general, the wise development of areas in harmony with the master plan of the community; and to secure equitable handling of all subdivision plans by providing uniform procedures and standards for observance both of the subdivider and the planning commission. (Ord. of 10-30-1972(2), § 21) Sec. 78-22. - Short title. This chapter shall be known as and may be cited as the "Land Subdivision Regulations, City of Alma, Georgia." (Ord. of 10-30-1972(2), § 22) Secs. 78-23—78-40. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - TERMS USED IN CHAPTER
Sec. 78-41. - General definitions. (a) Except as specifically defined herein, all words used in this chapter shall carry their customary dictionary meanings. (b) The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Building. The word "building" includes the word "structure." City means the City of Alma, Georgia. Governing authority means the city council of the city. Lot. The word "lot" includes the word "plot" or "parcel." Number. Words used in the singular include the plural and words used in the plural include the singular. Person. The word "person" includes a firm, association, organization, partnership, trust, company or corporation as well as an individual. Shall. The word "shall" is always mandatory. Tense. Words used in the present tense include the future tense. Used, occupied. The word "used" or "occupied" as applied to any land or building shall be construed to include the words "intended, arranged or designed to be used or occupied." (Ord. of 10-30-1972(2), § 31) Sec. 78-42. - Special definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the special definitions ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Cul-de-sac. A dead-end street where there is room for a vehicle to turn at a circular end. Master plan. (Same as Comprehensive plan.) Any part or element of the overall plan for development adopted by the Planning Commission as provided by the 1983 Constitution of Georgia, article IX, section II, paragraph IV. Street. The term "street" means, relates to and includes streets and avenues, boulevards, roads, highways, expressways, lanes, alleys, and other ways. For the purpose of this chapter, streets are classified by function as follows: Collector street means those streets indicated as such on the zoning map which serve as feeders to a major street, as collectors of traffic from minor streets, and for circulation around a residential neighborhood. Major street means those indicated as such on the zoning map, which serve primarily as major trafficways for travel through and within the city. Minor street means those streets provided for the primary purpose of furnishing access to abutting properties. Subdivider means an individual, firm, association, syndicate, partnership, corporation, trust or any other legal entity (or agent therefor) that undertakes the activities covered by these regulations. Inasmuch as the subdivision plat is merely a necessary means to the end of ensuring a satisfactory development, the term "subdivider" is intended to include the terms "developer" and "builder" even though the persons involved in successive stages of the project may vary. Subdivision. A subdivision shall be construed to be a division of a tract or parcel of land into two or more lots, building sites, or divisions for the sale, legacy or building development, and includes all division of land involving a new street or a change in existing streets, and includes resubdivision, and where appropriate to the context relates to the process of subdividing or to the land or areas subdivided; provided, however, that the following are not included within this definition: (1) The combination or recombination of portions of previously platted lots where the total number of lots is not increased and the resultant lots are equal to the standards set forth in this chapter.
