(6) Failure to provide within 30 days after the due date, required reports such as baseline monitoring reports, reports on compliance with categorical pretreatment standard deadlines, periodic self-monitoring reports, and reports on compliance with compliance schedules; (7) Failure to accurately report noncompliance; or (8) Any other violations, which may include a violation of best management practices, which the director determines will adversely affect the operation or implementation of the local pretreatment program. Slug discharge means any discharge at a flow rate or concentration that could cause a violation of the prohibited discharge standards of the city. A slug discharge is any discharge of a nonroutine, episodic nature, including but not limited to an accidental spill or noncustomary batch discharge, which has reasonable potential to cause interference or pass through, or in any other way violate the POTW's regulations, local limits or permit conditions. Storm drain or storm sewer means a sewer which carries stormwater and surface water and drainage, but excludes wastewater and industrial wastes, other than unpolluted cooling waters. Total suspended solids or suspended solids means the total suspended matter that floats on the surface of, or is suspended in, water, wastewater, or other liquid, and that is removable by laboratory filtering. Toxic pollutant means any pollutant defined in section 307(a)(1) (33 USC 1317) of the Act and include metals and manmade organic compounds. User means any person who contributes, causes or permits the contribution of wastewater into the city POTW. Waste includes wastewater and any and all other waste substances, liquid, solid, gaseous or radioactive, associated with human habitation, or of human or animal origin, or from any producing, manufacturing or processing operations. Wastewater means waste and water, whether treated or untreated, discharged into or permitted to enter a POTW. Watercourse means a natural or artificial channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. Waters of the state means any water, surface or underground, within the boundaries of the state. (b) The following abbreviations shall have the following meanings: (1) BOD—Biochemical oxygen demand (five day). (2) C—Celsius. (3) CFR—Code of Federal Regulations. (4) CIU—Categorical Industrial User. (5) COD—Chemical oxygen demand. (6) EPA—U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. (7) EPD—Environmental Protection Division, Georgia Department of Natural Resources. (8) F—Fahrenheit. (9) mg/L—milligrams per liter. (10) NPDES—National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System. (11) pH—Logarithm of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion activity in moles per liter. (12) POTW—Publicly owned treatment works. (13) TSS—Total suspended solids. (14) USC—United States Code. (Code 1981, § 22-20; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. I, §§ 1—27) Sec. 86-36. - Enforcement—Entry on private property. The code enforcement officer and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing pertinent to discharge to the community system in accordance with the provisions of this article. (Code 1981, § 22-21; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. VII, § 1) Sec. 86-37. - Same—Entry on easements. The code enforcement officer and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all private properties through which the city holds a duly negotiated easement for the purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair and maintenance of any portion of the wastewater facilities lying within said easement. All entry and subsequent work, if any, on said easement, shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the duly negotiated easement pertaining to the private property involved. (Code 1981, § 22-22; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. VII, § 4) Sec. 86-38. - Same—Obtaining information. The code enforcement officer or other duly authorized employees are authorized to obtain information concerning industrial processes which have a direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the wastewater collection system. The industry may withhold information considered confidential; provided the industry must establish that the revelation to the public of the information in question might result in an advantage to competitors. (Code 1981, § 22-23; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. VII, § 2) Sec. 86-39. - Same—Liability for injury, etc. While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to in section 86-36, the code enforcement officer or duly authorized employees of the city shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises established by the company, and the company shall be held harmless for injury or death to the city employees, and the city shall indemnify the company against loss or damage to its property by city employees and against liability claims and demands for personal injury or property damage asserted against the company and growing out of the gauging and sampling operation, except as such may be caused by negligence or failure of the company to maintain safe conditions as required in section 86-62. (Code 1981, § 22-24; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. VII, § 3) Sec. 86-40. - Unsanitary depositing of waste. It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any human or animal excrement, garbage or objectionable waste. (Code 1981, § 22-25; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. II, § 1) Sec. 86-41. - Discharges to natural outlets requiring treatment. It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city any wastewater or other polluted waters. (Code 1981, § 22-26; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. II, § 2) Sec. 86-42. - Privies, etc., prohibited. Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool or other facility intended or used for the disposal of wastewater. (Code 1981, § 22-27; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. II, § 3) Sec. 86-43. - Required connection to public sewer. The owner of all houses, buildings or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes, situated within the city and abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is now located or may in the future be located a public sanitary or combined sewer of the city, is hereby required at the owner expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein, and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this article, within 90 days after date of official notice to do so, provided that said public sewer is within 200 feet (61 meters) of the property line. (Code 1981, § 22-28; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. II, § 4) Sec. 86-44. - Private wastewater disposal. (a) Where a public sanitary sewer is not available under the provisions of section 86-42, the building sewer shall be connected to a private wastewater disposal system complying with the provisions of this section. (b) Before commencement of construction of a private wastewater disposal system the owners shall first obtain a written permit signed by the county health inspector. The application for such permit shall be made on a form furnished by the city, which the applicant shall supplement by any plans, specifications and other information as are deemed necessary by the county health inspector. A permit and inspection fee shall be paid to the city at the time the application is filed. The amount of the permit and inspection fee shall be as established by the city council from time to time. (c) A permit for a private wastewater disposal system shall not become effective until the installation is completed to the satisfaction of the county health inspector. The county health inspector shall be allowed to inspect the work at any stage of construction, and, in any event, the applicant for the permit shall notify the code enforcement officer when the work is ready for final inspection, and before any underground portions are covered. The inspection shall be made within 24 hours of receipt of the notice. (d) The type, capacities, location and layout of a private wastewater disposal system shall comply with all recommendations of the department of human resources of the state. No septic tank or cesspool shall be permitted to discharge to any natural outlet. (e) At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private wastewater disposal system, as provided in section 86-43, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer within 60 days in compliance with this article, and any septic tanks, cesspools and similar private wastewater disposal facilities shall be cleaned of sludge and filled with suitable material. (f) The owners shall operate and maintain the private wastewater disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, at no expense to the city. (g) No statement contained in this section shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by the health authorities. (Code 1981, § 22-29; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. III, §§ 1—7) Sec. 86-45. - Permit required for work involving building sewers and connections. No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter or disturb any public sewer. (Code 1981, § 22-30; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. IV, § 1) Sec. 86-46. - Responsibility for building sewer cost and for loss or damage. All costs and expenses incidental to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owners. The owners shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. (Code 1981, § 22-32; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. IV, § 3) Sec. 86-47. - Separate and independent building sewers. A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building; except that where one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard or driveway, the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer, but the city does not and will not assume any obligation or responsibility for damage caused by or resulting from any such single connection aforementioned. (Code 1981, § 22-33; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. IV, § 4) Sec. 86-48. - Old building sewers. Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the code enforcement officer, to meet all requirements of this article. (Code 1981, § 22-34; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. IV, § 5) Sec. 86-49. - Building sewer specifications. The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building sewer, and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing, testing and backfilling the trench, shall all conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing codes or other applicable rules and regulations of the city. In the absence of code provisions or in amplification thereof, the materials and procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the International Plumbing Code, 2010 edition (section 14-24) shall apply. (Code 1981, § 22-35; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. IV, § 6) Sec. 86-50. - Elevation of building sewer. Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted by an approved means and discharged to the building sewer. (Code 1981, § 22-36; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. IV, § 7) Sec. 86-51. - Connection of downspouts, etc. No person shall make connection of roof downspouts, foundation drains, areaway drains or other sources of surface water runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer unless such connection is approved by the code enforcement officer for purposes of disposal of polluted surface drainage. (Code 1981, § 22-37; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. IV, § 8) Sec. 86-52. - Connection specifications. The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing codes or other applicable rules and regulations of the city or the procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the International Plumbing Code (section 14-24). All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight and verified by proper testing. Any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the city manager before installation. (Code 1981, § 22-38; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. IV, § 9) Sec. 86-53. - Inspecting and testing of building sewer. The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the code enforcement officer when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection and testing shall be made under the supervision of the code enforcement officer or the officer's representative. (Code 1981, § 22-39; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. IV, § 10) Sec. 86-54. - Excavations for building sewer installation. All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city. (Code 1981, § 22-40; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. IV, § 11) Sec. 86-55. - Discharge of stormwater, etc.—To sanitary sewer. No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any unpolluted waters such as stormwater, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage or cooling water to any sanitary sewer, except that stormwater runoff from limited areas, which stormwater may be polluted at times, may be discharged to the sanitary sewer by permission of the code enforcement officer. (Code 1981, § 22-41; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. V, § 1) Sec. 86-56. - Same—To combined sewer, storm sewer and natural outlet. Stormwater other than that exempted under section 86-55, and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as combined sewers or storm sewers or to a natural outlet approved by the code enforcement officer and other regulatory agencies. Unpolluted industrial cooling water or process waters may be discharged, on approval of the code enforcement officer to a storm sewer, combined sewer or natural outlet. (Code 1981, § 22-42; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. V, § 2) Sec. 86-57. - Prohibited discharges to public sewers. No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described waters or wastes to any public sewers: (1) Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas. (2) Any waters containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, to injure or interfere with any waste treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a public nuisance, or create any hazard in the receiving waters of the wastewater treatment plant. (3) Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 6.0, greater than 9.0, or having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment or personnel of the wastewater works. (4) Solid or viscous substances in quantities or of such size capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers or other interference with the proper operation of the wastewater facilities such as, but not limited to, ashes, bones, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and fleshings, entrails, and paper dishes, cups, milk containers, etc., either whole or ground by garbage grinders. (Code 1981, § 22-43; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. V, § 3) Sec. 86-58. - Rejecting wastes or requiring treatment or controlling quantity. (a) If any waters or wastes are discharged or are proposed to be discharged to the public sewers, and which in the judgment of the treatment plant operator may have a deleterious effect upon the wastewater facilities processes, equipment or receiving waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the treatment plant operator may: (1) Reject the wastes; (2) Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewers; (3) Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge; and/or (4) Require payment to cover added cost of handling and treating the wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewer charges. (b) When considering the alternatives set forth in subsection (a) of this section, the treatment plant operator shall give consideration to the economic impact of each alternative on the discharger. If the treatment plant operator permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste flows, the design and installation of the plants and equipment shall be subject to the review by and approval of the treatment plant operator. (Code 1981, § 22-45; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. V, § 5) Sec. 86-59. - Interceptors. Grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the code enforcement officer, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing floatable grease in excessive amounts or any flammable wastes, sand or other harmful ingredients; except that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the code enforcement officer, and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. In the maintaining of these interceptors, the owners shall be responsible for the proper removal and disposal by appropriate means of the captured material and shall maintain records of the dates and means of disposal, which are subject to review by the code enforcement officer. Any removal and hauling of the collected materials not performed by the owners' personnel must be performed by currently licensed waste disposal firms. (Code 1981, § 22-46; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. V, § 6) Sec. 86-60. - Maintenance of facilities. Where pretreatment or flow-equalizing facilities are provided or required for any waters or wastes, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owners at the owners' expense. (Code 1981, § 22-47; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. V, § 7) Sec. 86-61. - Control structures. When required by the treatment plant operator, the owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable structure together with necessary meters and other appurtenances in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of the wastes. Such structure, when required, shall be accessibly and safely located and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the treatment plant operator. The structure shall be installed by the owner at such owner's expense and shall be maintained by the owner so as to be safe and accessible at all times. (Code 1981, § 22-48; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. V, § 8) Sec. 86-62. - Requiring information. The treatment plant operator may require a user of sewer services to provide information needed to determine compliance with this division. These requirements may include: (1) Wastewaters discharge peak rate and volume over a specified time period. (2) Chemical analyses of wastewaters. (3) Information on raw materials, processes and products affecting wastewater volume and quality. (4) Quantity and disposition of specific liquid, sludge, oil, solvent or other materials important to sewer use control. (5) A plot plan of sewers of the user's property showing sewer and pretreatment facility location. (6) Details of wastewater pretreatment facilities. (7) Details of systems to prevent and control the losses of materials through spills to the municipal sewer. (Code 1981, § 22-49; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. V, § 9) Sec. 86-63. - Standard methods for examination of waters. All measurements, tests and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in this article shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater," published by the American Public Health Association. Sampling methods, location, times, durations and frequencies are to be determined on an individual basis, subject to approval by the treatment plant operator. (Code 1981, § 22-50; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. V, § 10) Sec. 86-64. - Special agreements. No statement contained in this article shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the city and any industrial concern whereby any industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by the city for treatment. (Code 1981, § 22-51; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. V, § 11) Sec. 86-65. - Pretreatment by major contributing industry. Should any major contributing industry discharge its wastes to the treatment system it shall comply with the pretreatment requirements of federal and state law. A major contributing industry is one that: (1) Has a flow of 25,000 gallons or more per average day. (2) Has in its waste a toxic pollutant in toxic amounts as defined in standards issued under section 307(a) of Public Law 92-500. (3) Is found by the city in connection with its National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit, to have significant impact, either singly or in combination with other contributing industries, on that treatment works or upon the quality of effluent from that treatment works. (Code 1981, § 22-52; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. V, § 12) Sec. 86-66. - Damage to system. No person shall maliciously, willfully or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or equipment which is a part of the wastewater facilities. (Code 1981, § 22-53; Ord. of 11-9-1976, art. VI, § 1) Secs. 86-67—86-92. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - INDUSTRIAL COST RECOVERY
Sec. 86-93. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Industrial cost recovery means recovery from industrial users of a treatment works of the grant amount allocable to the treatment of wastes from such users. Industrial cost recovery period means a 30-year period during which the grant amount allocable to the treatment of wastes from industrial users is recovered from the industrial users of such works. Industrial user means any nongovernmental user of publicly owned treatment works identified in the Standard Industrial Classification Manual, 1972, Office of Management and Budget, as amended and supplemented under the following divisions: (1) Division A, Agriculture, Forestry and Fishing. (2) Division B, Mining. (3) Division D, Manufacturing. (4) Division E, Transportation, Communications, Electric, Gas and Sanitary Services. (5) Division I, Services. A user in a division listed in this definition may be excluded if it is determined that it will introduce primarily segregated domestic waste or waste from sanitary conveniences. Infiltration. (1) The term "infiltration" means the water entering a sewer system, including sewer service connections, from the ground, through such means as, but not limited to, defective pipes, pipe joints or manhole walls. (2) The term "infiltration" does not include and is distinguished from inflow. Infiltration/inflow means the total quantity of water from both infiltration and inflow without distinguishing the source. Inflow. (1) The term "inflow" means the water discharged into a sewer system, including service connections from such sources as, but not limited to, roof leaders, cellar, yard and area drains, fountain drains, cooling water discharges, drains from springs and swampy areas, manhole covers, cross connections from the storm sewers and combined sewers, catchbasins, storm meters, surface runoff, street washwaters or drainage. (2) The term "inflow" does not include and is distinguished from infiltration. Interceptor sewer means a sewer the primary purpose of which is to transport wastewaters from a collector sewer to a treatment facility. New industry means an industry that connects to a treatment works after such treatment works has been put into service. Reserved excess capacity means the capacity of a treatment works that is not currently being fully utilized, but which is reserved for a particular user through formally written agreement. Sanitary sewer means a sewer intended to carry only sanitary or sanitary and industrial wastewaters from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions. Treatment works means: (1) Any devices and systems used in the storage, treatment, recycling and reclamation of municipal sewage or industrial waste of a liquid nature, or necessary to recycle or reuse water at the most economical cost over the useful life of the works, including intercepting sewers, outfall sewers, sewage collection system, pumping, power and other equipment and their appurtenances; (2) Extensions, improvements, remodeling, additions and alterations thereof; (3) Elements essential to provide a reliable recycled supply such as standby treatment units and clear well facilities, and any works, including site acquisition of the land that will be an integral part of the treatment process or is used for ultimate disposal or residues resulting from such treatment; or (4) Any other method or system for preventing, abating, reducing, storing, treating, separating or disposing of municipal waste, including stormwater runoff or industrial waste, including waste in combined stormwater and sanitary sewer systems. (Code 1981, § 22-60; Ord. of 11-9-1976, § A(1)—(11)) Sec. 86-94. - Payment; cost factors. (a) The city will recover the proper amount of federal funds from industrial users and insure that each industrial user is treated fairly and consistently in accordance with Public Law 92-500 and generally accepted accounting principles. (b) The industrial cost recovery (hereinafter referred to as ICR) payments will be in proportion to those industrial wastewater characteristics which influence the cost of construction of the treatment works. These characteristics shall flow in thousands of gallons, biochemical oxygen demand (hereinafter referred to as BOD) in pounds per day and suspended solids (hereinafter referred to as SS) in pounds per day. (1) An industrial user's maximum flow rate shall be utilized in the computation of the portion of the ICR payment attributable to the collection portion of the treatment works. The ratio of the peak discharge from the industrial user to the peak capacity at the collection system, less allowances for unreserved capacity and nonexcessive infiltration/inflow shall be utilized. (2) An industrial user's average density flow, average daily biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) and average daily suspended solids (SS) discharge shall be utilized in the computation of the portion of the ICR payment attributable to the treatment plant portion of the treatment works. The ICR payment per unit of flow, BOD and SS shall be computed for each project funded under Public Law 92-500 on a weighted basis by the project engineer. The average discharge for an industrial user shall be multiplied by the unit cost as computed to arrive at the industry's ICR payment attributable to plant. (c) Industrial user discharging uncontaminated cooling water into the treatment works shall have these discharges included in its total flow ICR payments. (d) Industrial cost recovery must be based on step 3 construction and administrative costs, plus related step 1 and step 2 costs, as defined in Public Law 92-500. Step 1 or step 2 grant costs which do not result in actual step 3 construction are not allocable to individual industrial users and therefore shall not be recovered. (e) Industrial users who discharge pretreated process wastes into the treatment works shall have ICR payments based upon the characteristics of the pretreated process wastes. (f) Appendix A to the ordinance from which this section is derived shall provide the basis of the ICR payments attributable to project number C-130-357. (Code 1981, § 22-62; Ord. of 11-9-1976, § B(1)—(6)) Sec. 86-95. - Reserved capacity. (a) The city may enter into separate formal contracts with individual industrial users to reserve for that user a portion of the unused treatment works capacity. Such reserved capacity shall be in any quantity of units of flow, BOD and SS above the current discharge level of that user. (b) The industrial user entering into such an agreement shall be required to pay the full ICR allocable to the capacity reserved. In the event that the industrial user exceeds its reserved capacity it shall be required to pay ICR calculated on the full reserved capacity, plus additional ICR for use above the limits of the reserved capacity or any element thereof. (c) In the event the treatment works are expanded in the future with PL 92-500 grant assistance, an industrial user who has executed a reserve capacity agreement and has made ICR payments based upon full reserved capacity will not incur additional ICR charges associated with the cost of expansion until the industrial user's actual use of the treatment works exceeds its reserved capacity. (Code 1981, § 22-62; Ord. of 11-9-1976, § C(1)—(3)) Sec. 86-96. - Exclusions from application of ICR systems. (a) ICR shall not include allowances for the following grant costs: (1) Infiltration/inflow correction or treatment; (2) Correction of combined sewer overflows and collection or treatment of stormwaters; (3) Grants for projects which will not initially serve industrial users. (b) Certain industrial users shall be excluded if they fall within the following categories: (1) Industrial users who discharge only nonprocess, segregated domestic wastes or wastes from sanitary conveniences. (2) Industrial users who have reserved a portion of an existing treatment works under contract or agreement existing as of March 1, 1973, and who have paid a reasonable portion of the capital costs associates with that reserved capacity as determined by the environmental protection agency. Any capacity reserved after March 1, 1973, is subject to ICR payments in accordance with this division. (Code 1981, § 22-63; Ord. of 11-9-1976, § D(1), (2)) Sec. 86-97. - New industry. (a) ICR payments by a new industry shall begin on the date use is initiated and shall continue for the unexpired portion of the ICR period or until the industry ceases use of the facility, whichever occurs first. (b) Total ICR recovered from a new industry shall be the federal cost of the capacity used multiplied by the ratio of its period of use to the ICR period. (Code 1981, § 22-64; Ord. of 11-9-1976, § F(1), (2)) Sec. 86-98. - Monitoring. (a) The wastewater characteristics of each industrial user shall be determined by monitoring the discharges of each industry for flow, BOD and SS. (b) After the ICR system is put into operation those industries that contribute greater than ten percent of the total flow, BOD or SS shall be monitored at least annually for ICR purposes. (c) After the ICR system is put into operation those industries that contribute less than ten percent of the total flow, BOD or SS shall be monitored on a random basis, but not less often than once every five years. (d) Monitoring for ICR purposes shall be conducted at periods of normal discharge. (Code 1981, § 22-65; Ord. of 11-9-1976, § G(1)—(4)) Sec. 86-99. - Discontinuance of use by industrial users. (a) If an industrial user discontinues use of the treatment works, including termination of any agreement for reserve capacity, its payment for industrial cost recovery shall cease. (b) The total ICR recovered from an industry which discontinues use during the ICR period shall be the federal cost of the capacity multiplied by the ratio of its period of use to the ICR period. (Code 1981, § 22-66; Ord. of 11-9-1976, § H(1), (2)) Sec. 86-100. - Lump sum ICR payments. (a) An industrial user may elect to fulfill its ICR obligation by making a lump sum payment for its entire share of the federal cost of construction of the treatment works. (b) Such payments may be accepted by the city and processed in accordance with section 86101, or set aside in a separate account to be drawn on annually for the remainder of the ICR period. (c) Lump sum payments will not relieve an industrial user from making additional payments should its wastewater flow or load increase. (d) Discounts from the total ICR requirements will not be given to industrial users making advance ICR payments. (Code 1981, § 22-67; Ord. of 11-9-1976, § I(1)—(4)) Sec. 86-101. - Implementation of the ICR system. (a) Notification of implementation. (1) The industrial cost recovery period shall commence after all construction is complete or at any time any element of the project becomes operable. (2) The accounting period for ICR payments shall coincide with the fiscal year of the city. (3) The city will notify the Environmental Protection Agency within 30 days of implementing the ICR period. The first payment shall be made not later than one year after the beginning of the ICR period and can coincide with the fiscal year. (b) Deposit of recovered funds. (1) The city shall collect from an industrial user the ICR payment on a monthly basis. (2) All funds so received shall be deposited in interest-bearing accounts which are fully collateralized by obligations of the U.S. government or by obligations fully guaranteed as to principal and interest by the U.S. government or any agency thereof. (c) Annual payment to the Environmental Protection Agency. (1) No later than four months after the end of the city's annual accounting period, a check for the annual ICR payment made payable to the Environmental Protection Agency shall be mailed to the regional administrator of that agency. (2) The check shall be payable in the amount of 50 percent of the recovered amount for the accounting period plus all interest earned thereon. (d) Use of retained funds. (1) The city shall retain 50 percent of the amount received from industrial users. (2) Of the retained amount, 80 percent together with interest earned thereon shall be used solely for the EPA eligible costs of the expansion or reconstruction of treatment works associated with the project and necessary to meet the requirements of Public Law 92-500. Prior to use of these funds, the city shall obtain the approval of the regional administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. To make the determination as to the eligibility of the request, the city shall submit the following to the regional administrator: a. A preliminary engineering report sufficiently detailed so as to permit a determination of the eligible costs. b. An estimate of the eligible costs which may include but not be limited to: 1. Cost of salaries, benefits and expendable materials incurred by the city for the project. 2. Costs under construction contract. 3. Professional and consultant services. 4. Facility planning directly related to the treatment works. 5. Sewer system evaluation. 6. Project feasibility and engineering reports. 7. Preparation of construction drawings, specifications, estimates and construction contract drawings. 8. Landscaping. 9. Supervision of construction work. 10. Materials acquired, consumed or expended for the project. 11. Development and preparation of an operation and maintenance manual. (3) Of the retained amount, 20 percent may be used for any purpose except for construction of industrial pretreatment facilities or rebates to industrial users for costs incurred by such users in complying with federal user charge or industrial cost recovery requirements. (e) Recordkeeping. (1) The city shall retain for the duration of the ICR period the following documents and information: a. Documentation of the final grant amount. b. The originally approved ICR system and all documentation related thereto. c. All subsequent revisions to the ICR system and all documentation related thereto. d. A list of all contributing industries and their wastewater loads to the system. e. Information on the total wastewater loading of the system. f. The initial notification from the city to the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) of the initiation of operation of the ICR system. g. All approvals of the use of retained funds. h. The record of all annual payments to EPA and documentation related thereto. i. Records relating to retention and investment of those funds set aside for future expansion and reconstruction. (2) The records so retained shall be available to the EPA or the environmental protection division, department of natural resources of the state upon request of either of these agencies. (Code 1981, § 22-68; Ord. of 11-9-1976, § J(1)—(5)) Sec. 86-102. - Administrative appeal procedure. (a) Any industrial user shall have the right to appeal the reasonableness of the allocation and ICR assessments imposed upon it by this division in the following manner: first, the industrial user must notify, in writing, the public works director or the code enforcement officer that said industrial user would like a review of the allocation and assessments against it. The code enforcement officer or public works director shall schedule a conference with said user within ten days from the date of the receipt of the notification stated in this subsection to discuss and review the matter. The industrial user may employ, at its on expense, an independent firm to conduct tests of the characteristics of its wastewater; provided, however, that such test shall be performed in the presence of either the code enforcement officer or public works director in order for the results of said test to be used as a basis for any adjustments in the allocation and assessments imposed on the industrial user. (b) If the industrial user and code enforcement officer or public works director are unable to reconcile any differences, the industrial user shall notify, in writing, the code enforcement officer requesting a hearing before the council. The code enforcement officer shall place the matter on the agenda and the matter shall be heard at the next regularly scheduled meeting of the council or special meeting called for that purpose, at which time the industrial user shall have the right to introduce evidence, written or oral, relevant to the matter in question. (c) If, after the hearing, the council finds the allocation and assessments correct, the code enforcement officer shall so notify the industrial user within ten days from the date of said meeting. If the council determines that an adjustment is necessary, the city clerk shall so notify the industrial user of the nature of the adjustment and advise the industrial user that future payments from it shall be adjusted according to the determination of the council. (Code 1981, § 22-69; Ord. of 11-9-1976, § K) Sec. 86-103. - Penalties for nonpayment. If any industrial user shall not pay its ICR payments within 45 days from the date that said payment became due, the city shall disconnect said user from both water and sewer services, and shall not reconnect same until such time as said user has paid all of its current ICR payments and has paid a reconnection fee to said city. (Code 1981, § 22-70; Ord. of 11-9-1976, § L) Secs. 86-104—86-134. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - ADMINISTRATIVE CHARGE; SURCHARGE; USER CHARGE
Sec. 86-135. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Administrative charge means a charge levied on users of treatment works for the cost of billing, retirement of debt, funding of reserve accounts, funding of extension accounts, and all other costs associated with the treatment works except operation and maintenance costs. Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedures in five days of 20 degrees Celsius, expressed in milligrams per liter. Interceptor sewer means a sewer the primary purpose of which is to transport wastewaters from collection sewers to a treatment facility. Replacement means expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment, accessories or appurtenances which are necessary during the service life of the treatment works to maintain the capacity and performance for which such works were designed and constructed. The term "operation and maintenance" includes replacement. Sanitary sewer means a sewer intended to carry only sanitary or sanitary and industrial wastewaters from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions. Sewer service charge means a charge levied on users of treatment works equal to the sum of appropriate administrative charge, user charge and surcharge. Surcharge means an additional charge levied on users of treatment works whose waste characteristics exceed those of normal sewage the limits of which are established herein. Suspended solids (SS) means solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in, water, sewage or liquid; and which are removable by laboratory filtering. Treatment works means any devices and systems used in the storage, treatment, recycling and reclamation of municipal or industrial wastes of a liquid nature, or necessary to recycle or reuse water at the most economical cost over the useful life of the works, including intercepting sewers, outfall sewers, sewage collection systems, pumping, power and other equipment and their appurtenances; extensions, improvements, remodeling, additions and alterations thereof; elements essential to provide a reliable recycled supply such as standby treatment units and clear well facilities and any works, including site acquisition of the land that will be an integral part of the treatment process or is used for ultimate disposal or residue resulting from such treatment; or any other method or system for preventing, abating, reducing, storing, treating, separating or disposing of municipal wastes, including stormwater runoff, or industrial wastes, including waste in combined stormwater and sanitary sewer systems. User charge means a charge levied on users of treatment works for the cost of operation and maintenance of such works. (Code 1981, § 22-80; Ord. of 11-9-1976, § A(1)—(10)) Sec. 86-136. - Computation of user charge. (a) The basic user charge shall be computed according to the following formula: Cu = Ct Vt (Vu)
Where: Cu = A user's charge for operation and maintenance per unit of time Ct = Total operation and maintenance cost per unit of time Vt = Total volume contribution from all users per unit of time Vu = Volume contribution from a user per unit of time (b) For the first year of operation, the user charge shall be $0.32 per each 1,000 gallons used computed as follows: Cu = Ct Vt (Vu)
Where: Cu = $35,000 (plant) + $12,000.00 (lines)/365 days > (1,000 gallons/month) Cu + $0.32/1,000 gallons per month (c) For each succeeding year, the user charge shall be reviewed and revised to reflect the actual treatment works operation and maintenance costs. The user charge system must generate sufficient revenue to offset the cost of all treatment works operation and maintenance. (Code 1981, § 22-81; Ord. of 11-9-1976, § B(1)—(3)) Sec. 86-137. - Computation of administrative charge. (a) The basic administrative charge shall be computed per the following formula for each 1,000 gallons per month above 3,000 gallons per month. Ca = Cta Vt (Vu)
Where: Ca = A user's charge for administrative per unit of time Cta = Total administration cost per unit of time Vt = Total volume contribution from all users per unit of time Vu = Volume contribution from a user per unit of time (b) For the first year of operation, the administrative charge shall be $0.18 per each 1,000 gallons per month above 3,000 gallons per month computed as follows: Ca = Cta Vt (Vu)
Where: Ca = $26,500/365 day > (1,000 gallons/month) Ca = $0.18 (c) For each succeeding year, the administrative charge shall be reviewed and revised to reflect the actual administrative costs. (d) For the first year and each year thereafter, until amended, the administrative charge shall be as follows: 0—1,000 gallons $1.18 1,001—2,000 gallons $0.86 2,001—3,000 gallons $0.54
These charges reflect the cost for billing and debt service for users up to 3,000 gallons per month. (Code 1981, § 22-82; Ord. of 11-9-1976, § C(1)—(4)) Sec. 86-138. - Computation of surcharge. (a) When BOD or suspended solids from a user exceed 300 mg/l, a surcharge shall be added to the basic user charge computed in section 86-136 per the following formula: Ca + (Bc(B) + Sc(S))Vu Where: Ca = A surcharge for waste waters of excessive strength Bc = Operation and maintenance cost for treatment of a unit of BOD B = Concentration of BOD from a user above 300 mg/l Sc = Operation and maintenance cost for treatment of a unit of suspended solids S = Concentration of SS from a use above 300 mg/l (2.5 lbs./1,000 gals.) Vu = Volume contribution from a user per unit of time (b) For the first year of operation, the surcharge shall be based on: Bc = $0.01 per lb. BOD Sc = $0.01 per lb. SS B = Observed concentration of BOD above 300 mg/l S = Observed concentration of SS above 300 mg/l Vu = Monthly usage per customer exceeding base concentrations
(c) For each succeeding year, the surcharge shall be reviewed and revised to reflect the actual increase in operation and maintenance cost due to the excess strength wastes. (Code 1981, § 22-83; Ord. of 11-9-1976, § D(1)—(3)) Sec. 86-139. - Sewer service charge. The sewer service charge shall be computed by adding each of the user charge, administration charge and surcharge computed in sections 86-136 through 86-138 for each user. (Code 1981, § 22-84; Ord. of 11-9-1976, § E(1), (2))

div.head: Chapter 90 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 90-1—90-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - TAXICABS
Sec. 90-19. - Taxicab licenses as prescribed; approval by council. The license for the operation of taxicabs shall be that prescribed from year to year in the license schedule. No license shall be issued until approved by the council. (Code 1969, § 17-1; Code 1981, § 23-20) Sec. 90-20. - Liability insurance. The owner or operator of taxicabs shall continuously keep on file with the city clerk a liability insurance policy with a casualty company licensed and doing business under the laws of the state, in the amounts required by state law, covering each vehicle operated, with an endorsement attached to each policy that the same is on file with the city, and that the insurer is bound to notify the city promptly and within ten days if said policy should be cancelled for any reason whatsoever. (Code 1969, § 17-2; Code 1981, § 23-21) Sec. 90-21. - Fixed place of business required. All taxicabs must operate only from a fixed place of business. (Code 1969, § 17-3; Code 1981, § 23-22) Sec. 90-22. - Condition of vehicle. All taxicabs shall be kept in good and safe mechanical condition at all times. (Code 1969, § 17-4; Code 1981, § 23-23) Sec. 90-23. - Identifying vehicle as taxicab. The owner or operator of taxicabs shall paint on each side of each vehicle operated as such a permanent sign designating it as a taxicab. This sign shall be of such size as to be recognized by the general public. (Code 1969, § 17-5; Code 1981, § 23-24) Sec. 90-24. - Hiring only drivers of good character. For the protection of the general public, the owner of taxicabs shall employ only operators who are sober and careful drivers. (Code 1969, § 17-7; Code 1981, § 23-25) Sec. 90-25. - Taxicab driver's permit—Chauffeur's license required; permit fee; issuance of temporary permit. All persons desiring to drive a taxicab in the city shall first obtain a state chauffeur's license; and shall make application for a permit to the city clerk, who, upon receiving a fee from the applicant and upon a recommendation of the chief of police shall issue a temporary permit to the applicant. The amount of the fee shall be as established by the city council from time to time. (Code 1969, § 17-8; Code 1981, § 23-26) Sec. 90-26. - Same—Persons not entitled to temporary permit; issuance of annual permit. The temporary permit issued by the city clerk shall be valid from date of issue until the date of the next regular meeting of the city council. The applicant must, on the date of the next regular meeting of the council, appear before and be approved by the council. Upon approval by the council the applicant will be issued a permit valid for one year from date. (Code 1969, § 17-9; Code 1981, § 23-27) Sec. 90-27. - Same—Revocation for violation of law. Any permit issued to drive a taxicab whether temporary or annual, shall be revocable upon any violation of any law or ordinance of the city or state, traffic or otherwise. (Code 1969, § 17-10; Code 1981, § 23-28) Sec. 90-28. - Transporting alcoholic beverages. It shall be unlawful for any operator of a taxicab licensed to do business in the city to have or transport any alcoholic beverages in the taxicab which such person operates. (Code 1969, § 17-11; Code 1981, § 23-29) Sec. 90-29. - Transporting prostitutes. It shall be unlawful for the owner or operator of a taxicab to transport prostitutes therein. (Code 1969, § 17-12; Code 1981, § 23-30)

div.head: Chapter 94 - ZONING
div.p:
FOOTNOTE(S): --- (1) --- State Law reference— Authority of municipality to adopt plans and exercise the power of zoning, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ IV; the Zoning Procedures Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-1 et seq.; local government zoning powers, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-2. ARTICLE I. - AUTHORITY AND JURISDICTION
Sec. 94-1. - Authority. In pursuance of the authority granted by the 1983 Constitution of Georgia, article IX, section II, paragraph IV, the city council enacts and ordains the regulations contained in this chapter. (Ord. of 10-30-1972(1), § 11) Sec. 94-2. - Jurisdiction. The provisions of this chapter shall govern all land, buildings and structures within the corporate limits. (Ord. of 10-30-1972(1), § 12) Secs. 94-3—94-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PURPOSE AND SHORT TITLE
Sec. 94-21. - Purpose. The purpose of this chapter is to lessen congestion in the streets; to secure safety from fire, panic and other dangers; to promote health and the general welfare; to provide adequate light and air; to prevent the overcrowding of land; to avoid undue concentration of population; to facilitate the adequate provision of transportation, water, sewerage, schools, parks and other public requirements; to sustain the stability of neighborhoods; to protect property against blight and depreciation; to secure economy in governmental expenditures; to conserve the value of buildings; to encourage the most appropriate use of land and buildings; and to assist the orderly, efficient and integrated development of the city in accordance with the comprehensive plan. (Ord. of 10-30-1972(1), § 21) Sec. 94-22. - Short title. This chapter shall be known as and may be cited as the "Comprehensive Zoning Ordinance, City of Alma, Georgia." (Ord. of 10-30-1972(1), § 22) Secs. 94-23—94-40. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - TERMS USED IN CHAPTER
Sec. 94-41. - General definitions. (a) Except as specifically defined herein, all words used in this chapter shall carry their customary dictionary meanings. (b) The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Building. The word "building" includes the word "structure." City means the City of Alma, Georgia. Governing authority means the city council of the city. Lot. The word "lot" includes the word "plot" or "parcel." Map or zoning map means the comprehensive zoning map of the city. Number. Words used in the singular include the plural and words used in the plural include the singular. Person. The word "person" includes a firm, association, organization, partnership, trust, company or corporation as well as an individual. Shall. The word "shall" is always mandatory. Tense. Words used in the present tense include the future tense. Used, occupied. The word "used" or "occupied," as applied to any land or building, shall be construed to include the words "intended, arranged, or designed to be used or occupied." (Ord. of 10-30-1972(1), § 31) Sec. 94-42. - Special definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the special definitions ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Accessory building or use means a building or use customarily incidental and subordinate to the principal use or building and located on the same lot with such principal use or building. Alley means a vehicular travelway used primarily for service purposes, the right-of-way of which is not less than 20 feet, nor more than 50 feet. Alteration of building means any change in the supporting members of a building (such as bearing walls, beams, columns, girders) except such change as may be required for its safety; any addition to a building; or moving a building from one location to another. Boardinghouse or roominghouse means any dwelling in which three or more persons either individually or as families are housed or lodged for hire with or without meals. Building means any structure permanently attached to the ground and intended for shelter, housing or enclosure of persons, animals or chattels. (See also section 94-41.) Building, principal, means a building in which the main use of the lot takes place. Business sign means an attached or freestanding structure on which is announced the business use of the premises and/or the name of the operator of the business. The owner or operator of the business may also use a sign for the purposes of displaying announcements of a political, social, religious, charitable or community interest. Centerline of street means the line surveyed and monumented by the governing authority as such; or if centerline has not been surveyed and monumented, it shall be that line running midway between the abutting property lines of the street, if such exist. If such abutting properly lines are not clearly defined, the centerline shall be a line midway between the right-of-way lines of recorded streets or rights-of-way. Dwelling means a building designed or used for permanent living quarters for one or more families. Dwelling, multifamily, means a dwelling designed for or occupied by two or more families living independently of each other in separate dwelling units. Dwelling unit means a dwelling or portion thereof providing permanent living quarters for one or more persons living as a single housekeeping unit. Family means one or more persons occupying a dwelling and living as a single housekeeping unit. Lot means a parcel of land occupied or capable of being occupied by one building and the accessory buildings or uses customarily incidental to it, including such open spaces as are required by this chapter. (See also section 94-41.) Lot width means the distance between the side boundaries of the lot measured at the front yard setback line. Nursing home means any dwelling in which aged, chronically ill or incurable persons are housed and furnished with meals and nursing care for compensation, but excluding alcoholic patients. Outdoor advertising sign means an attached or freestanding structure other than a business sign conveying some information, knowledge or idea to the public. Street. The term "street" means, relates to and includes streets and avenues, boulevards, roads, highways, expressways, lanes, alleys, and other ways. For the purpose of this chapter, streets are classified by function as follows: Collector street means those streets indicated as such on the zoning map which serve as feeders to a major street, as collectors of traffic from minor streets, and for circulation around a residential neighborhood. Major street means those indicated as such on the zoning map, which serve primarily as major trafficways for travel through and within the city. Minor street means those streets provided for the primary purpose of furnishing access to abutting properties. Structure means anything constructed or erected on the ground or attached to something located on the ground. (See also Building and section 94-41.) Yard, front, means an open, unoccupied space on the same lot with a principal building, extending the full width of the lot and located between the street line and the front line of the building projected to the side lines of the lot. Yard, rear, means an open space on the same lot with a principal building, unoccupied except by permitted accessory building, or use, extending the full width of the lot and located between the rear line of the lot and the rear line of the building projected to the side lines of the lot. Yard, side, means an open unoccupied space on the same lot with a principal building, located between the side of the building and the sideline of the lot and extending from the rear line of the front yard. (Ord. of 10-30-1972(1), § 32; Ord. No. 1997-3, 10-20-1997) Secs. 94-43—94-60. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - ESTABLISHMENT OF DISTRICTS
Sec. 94-61. - Classes of districts. For the purpose of this chapter, the city is divided into the following classes of districts or zones: Residence districts to be known as "R" zones. Professional districts to be known as "P" zones. Business districts to be known as "B" zones. Industrial districts to be known as "I" zones. (Ord. of 10-30-1972(1), § 41) Sec. 94-62. - Rules governing district boundaries. Where uncertainty exists with respect to the boundaries of any aforementioned district as shown on the zoning map, the following rules shall apply: (1) Unless otherwise indicated, the district boundaries are the centerlines of streets, railroad rights-of-way, streams or such lines extended. Where district boundaries cut a block transversely or longitudinally, the line shall not cut through a lot, but shall coincide with the appropriate lot lines. (2) Where the district boundaries are indicated as approximately following the corporate limit, such corporate limit line shall be construed to be such boundary. (3) Where district boundaries are indicated as approximately parallel to the centerlines of streets or highways, such district boundaries shall be construed as being parallel and at such distance therefrom as indicated on the zoning map, except as stated in subsection (1) of this section. If no distance is given, such dimensions shall be determined by the use of the scale as shown on the zoning map. (Ord. of 10-30-1972(1), § 42) Secs. 94-63—94-80. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - APPLICATION OF REGULATIONS
Sec. 94-81. - Use. Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, no building or structure or land shall hereafter be used or occupied and no building or structure or part thereof shall be erected, constructed, reconstructed, moved or altered except in conformity with the regulations herein specified for the district in which it is located. (Ord. of 10-30-1972(1), § 51) Sec. 94-82. - Height and density. Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, no building or structure shall hereafter be erected, constructed, reconstructed or altered to: (1) Exceed the height limit; (2) House a greater number of families or occupy a smaller lot area per family; (3) Have narrower or smaller front or side yards, or courts; than are herein required. (Ord. of 10-30-1972(1), § 52) Sec. 94-83. - Lot size and occupancy. Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, no lot, even though it may consist of one or more adjacent lots in the same ownership at the time of passage of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, shall be reduced in size so that lot width or size of yards or lot area per family or any other requirements of this chapter are not maintained. This section shall not apply when a portion of a lot is acquired for public use. (Ord. of 10-30-1972(1), § 53) Sec. 94-84. - Yards and other spaces. Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, no part of a yard or other open space or the off-street parking or loading spaces required about any building for the purpose of complying with the provisions of this chapter shall be included as a part of the yard or off-street parking or loading spaces required for another building. (Ord. of 10-30-1972(1), § 54) Sec. 94-85. - One principal building on a lot. Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, except for group developments, only one principal building and its permitted customary accessory buildings may hereafter be erected on any one lot. (Ord. of 10-30-1972(1), § 55) Sec. 94-86. - Public street frontage. Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, no building shall be erected on a lot which does not abut a minimum of 20 feet on a public street. (Ord. of 10-30-1972(1), § 56) Secs. 94-87—94-110. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - GENERAL REGULATIONS
Sec. 94-111. - Continuance of nonconforming uses. The lawful use of any building or structure or land existing at the time of the enactment of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived may be continued even though such use does not conform with the provisions of this chapter except that the nonconforming structure or use shall not be: (1) Changed to another nonconforming use; (2) Reestablished after discontinuance for one year; (3) Extended except in conformity with this chapter; (4) Rebuilt, altered or repaired after damage exceeding 50 percent of its replacement cost at the time of destruction, except in conformity with this chapter. (Ord. of 10-30-1972(1), § 61) Sec. 94-112. - Off-street automobile parking. No structure hereafter shall be erected nor any of the following uses established unless the minimum number of parking spaces as specified below is provided. Each parking space shall be at least 200 square feet and shall have access for vehicles to a public street. Parking lots for more than five vehicles shall provide sufficient turning space to prevent cars from backing into the street: (1) Automobile repair garages. One space for each regular employee plus one space for each 250 square feet of floor area used for repair work. (2) Funeral parlors. One space for each four seats in the chapel. (3) Gasoline filling stations. Ten spaces for each grease rack or similar facility. (4) Hospitals and nursing homes. One space for each five beds plus one space for each staff or visiting doctor, plus one space for each four employees including nurses. (5) Hotels. One space for each two guest bedrooms plus one space for each four employees. (6) Industrial establishments. One space for each two employees at maximum employment on a single shift, plus one space for each company vehicle operating from the premises. (7) Lodges and clubs. One space for each eight members. (8) Offices. One space for each 300 square feet of floor space. (9) Places of amusement or public assembly without fixed seats. One space for each 70 square feet of floor space provided for use in the main assembly hall. (10) Places of amusement or public assembly with fixed seats. One space for each four seats in the main assembly hall. (11) Residential. Two spaces for each dwelling unit. (12) Restaurants. One space for each four chairs, plus one space for each four employees. (13) Retail business. One space for each 200 square feet of sales area. (14) Boardinghouses and roominghouses. One space for each two guestrooms. (15) Schools. One space for each 30 pupils in primary schools, one space for each four students in high schools and one space for each student in higher education, plus an additional space for each employee. (16) Tourist courts and motels. One space for each accommodation. (17) Mobile home parks. One space for each mobile home. (18) Wholesale business. One space for each 300 square feet. (Ord. of 10-30-1972(1), § 63) Sec. 94-113. - Location on other property. If the required automobile parking spaces cannot be provided on the same lot where the principal use is conducted, such spaces may be provided on other off-street property provided that such property lies within 400 feet of the main entrance to such principal use. Such automobile parking space shall be associated with the principal use and shall not thereafter be reduced or encroached upon in any manner. (Ord. of 10-30-1972(1), § 64) Sec. 94-114. - Extension of parking space in residential districts. Required parking space may extend up to 100 feet into a residential district provided that the parking space adjoins a commercial or industrial district and has its only access on the same street as the property for which it serves and is separated from abutting residences by an evergreen planted buffer strip at least ten feet wide. (Ord. of 10-30-1972(1), § 65) Sec. 94-115. - Off-street loading and unloading space. On every lot on which a business, trade or industry is hereafter established, space with access to a public street or alley shall be provided as indicated below for the loading and unloading of vehicles off the public street or alley: (1) Retail business. Ten percent of the floor area. (2) Wholesale and industrial. Five percent of the floor area. (3) Bus and truck terminals. Sufficient space to accommodate the maximum number of buses or trucks that will be stored and loading or unloading at the terminal at any one time. (Ord. of 10-30-1972(1), § 66) Sec. 94-116. - Unsafe buildings. Nothing in this chapter shall prevent the strengthening or restoring to a safe condition of any part of any building or structure declared unsafe by the building inspector, or from complying with his lawful requirements. (Ord. of 10-30-1972(1), § 67) Sec. 94-117. - Vision clearance. In all use districts except the B-1 central business district, no fence, wall, shrubbery, sign or other obstruction to vision between the heights of three feet and 12 feet shall be permitted within 60 feet of the intersection of the centerlines of streets or of streets and railroads. (Ord. of 10-30-1972(1), § 69) Secs. 94-118—94-140. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - USE REQUIREMENTS BY DISTRICTS
Sec. 94-141. - Use requirements for single-family residential district R-1A. Within the R-1A residential districts, the following uses are permitted: (1) Single-family dwellings. (2) Public and private schools offering general education courses. (3) Churches provided that: a. They are located on a major or collector street. b. The buildings are placed not less than 50 feet from any property line. c. There is an evergreen planted buffer strip at least ten feet wide along the side and rear property lines. (4) Public and semipublic recreation facilities and grounds. (5) Customary incidental home occupations including the office of a physician, dentist, lawyer, artist, musician, architect, engineer or the accommodation of not more than two boarders or roomers, provided there is no external evidence of such occupation except an announcement or professional sign not more than two square feet in area and that the operations are conducted within a dwelling by not more than one person in addition to those persons living therein and the place occupied is a part of the house. (6) The main structure/dwelling must be constructed prior to any customary accessory buildings, including private garages and noncommercial greenhouses and workshops, provided they are located in the rear yard and not closer than five feet to any lot line. (7) Nursery schools or kindergartens, provided that there are at least 150 square feet of outdoor play area for each child and the play area is enclosed by a woven wire fence at least five feet high. (8) Church bulletin boards not exceeding 12 square feet in area. (9) Signs not more than eight square feet in area advertising the sale or rental of the property on which they are located. (10) Electric transformers or gas regulator stations, if essential for the service to the zoning district in which they are proposed to be located, provided that: a. The structures are placed not less than 50 feet from any property line. b. No vehicles or equipment are stored on the premises. c. The lot is suitably landscaped. d. There is an evergreen planted buffer strip at least ten feet wide along the side and rear property lines. (11) Railroad lines and passenger stations. (12) Agriculture, but not including the commercial raising of livestock or poultry. (13) Subdivision signs with area not more than 30 square feet, one sign for each subdivision, to be located only on the subdivision site. (14) Upon approval of the planning commission, dwellings may be converted for multiple-family use, provided that the owner will reside in the dwelling structure. (Ord. of 10-30-1972(1), § 71-A; Ord. Within the P professional districts, the following uses are permitted: (1) Any use permitted in the R districts. Within the B-1 central business districts, the following uses are permitted. (5) Warehouses, truck terminals and storage. Residences are specifically prohibited in an I industrial district. (Ord. of 10-30-1972(1), § 75; Ord.
